question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Only ascending traffic ahead.
option_b: Steep ascent ahead.
option_c: Steep descent ahead.
option_d: Humpback bridge ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a steep ascent/upward hill ahead. You should react by selecting the appropriate gear.

question_text: What does this Garda signal mean?
option_a: Turn left.
option_b: Proceed if approaching from the front.
option_c: Stop if approaching from either the front or behind.
option_d: Turn right.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you must stop.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: No bridges ahead.
option_b: End of overhead bridge area.
option_c: End of motorway.
option_d: No overtaking.
explanation: This sign indicates the end of the motorway. You are leaving the motorway and its rules will no longer apply.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Double-decker buses only.
option_b: Contra-flow bus lane.
option_c: Two-way traffic system.
option_d: With-flow bus lane.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must drive on the left and not use the contra-flow bus lane day or night. A contra-flow bus lane is one where the buses are going in the opposite direction.

question_text: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from a minor road onto a major road?
explanation: The correct position from which to turn right from a minor road to a major road is just left of centre of the road. You should take up the correct position in good time and complete the turn by entering the left-hand side of the major road.

question_text: What action should the driver take?
option_a: Stop at the Stop line.
option_b: Signal the bus to proceed.
option_c: Proceed in front of the cyclist.
option_d: Proceed in front of the bus.
explanation: By law you must stop at a Stop line (or at a Stop sign if there is no Stop line), and wait for other traffic to clear before proceeding.

question_text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a trailer on national roads?
option_c: 80 km/h.
option_d: 60 km/h.
explanation: When towing a trailer on a national road, it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h - exceeding this speed will make the vehicle unstable.

question_text: Why might it be dangerous to drive on a poorly-lit street?
option_a: Drivers can only see the traffic in front of them.
option_b: Pedestrians crossing in a dark area might be difficult to see.
option_c: Drivers can only see the traffic coming against them.
option_d: Traffic lights will not be working.
explanation: When you are driving along a poorly-lit street, you should take extra care - vulnerable road users such as pedestrians might not be so easy to see. You should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: What should a driver be conscious of in this situation?
option_a: People crossing the street at the rear of the bus.
option_b: The bus may start to reverse.
option_c: Traffic emerging from the street on the left.
option_d: The bus driver will always signal before moving off.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to the changing traffic situation. In particular, you should be aware that pedestrians might emerge at the rear of the bus. In this situation you should also look out for pedestrians making their way towards the waiting Bus

question_text: There are pedestrians on the footpath ahead and there are pools of water on the road. What should a driver do?
option_a: Reduce speed and try to avoid the pools of water so as not to splash the pedestrians.
option_b: Sound the horn as a warning to the pedestrians and continue on.
option_c: Brake suddenly as you approach the pools of water.
option_d: Flash the headlights as a warning to the pedestrians.
explanation: During wet conditions, you should be aware that surface water can affect the stability of your vehicle. This is particularly so where the water lies in pools. As you drive through surface water, you should show consideration to pedestrians and cyclists and try not to splash them as you pass.

question_text: What should the driver do in this situation?
option_a: The driver must stop and allow all other traffic to proceed.
option_b: The driver must allow the blue car to proceed.
option_c: The driver may turn in front of the other two cars.
option_d: The driver must allow the red car to proceed.
explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic and only proceed when it is safe to do so. However, the drivers on the minor roads must give way to the traffic on the major road.

question_text: What should a driver who wants to turn right do in this situation?
option_a: Proceed straight ahead or turn left.
option_b: Turn right from the left lane.
option_c: Reverse and get into the right lane.
option_d: Proceed straight ahead and take a wide turn to the right.
explanation: As you approach a junction where you want to turn right, you should read the road ahead and take up the correct position for turning in good time.

question_text: After a heavy downpour, why should a driver keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front?
option_a: Because required stopping distances are decreased.
option_b: Because wheels rotate at a greater speed after rain.
option_c: Because wheel-spray may impair visibility.
option_d: Because wheels rotate at a slower speed after rain.
explanation: Heavy rain can affect how well you can see and how well you can be seen by other road users. Because of that you should slow down in heavy rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: Why is tailgating (driving too close behind the vehicle in front) dangerous?
option_a: The vehicle will exceed the speed limit.
option_b: The engine may overheat because of restricted air flow over the vehicle's engine.
option_c: The vehicle will not have sufficient distance to stop safely in an emergency.
option_d: The braking system is less efficient in the slipstream of the vehicle in front.
explanation: If you drive too close to the vehicle in front and it brakes suddenly, you will not have enough time to react. For that reason you should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. One way of calculating a safe distance in dry weather is the two-second rule: allow at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and your own vehicle passing a fixed point such as a lamp post or sign post.

question_text: When a driver is driving behind another vehicle that they do not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?
option_a: Signal to following traffic to overtake both vehicles.
option_b: Keep well back to allow following traffic to overtake.
option_c: Keep well back and to the centre of the road.
option_d: Drive close behind it in order to let following traffic overtake both vehicles.
explanation: You should always allow sufficient distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front. This will enable you to stop safely (within the distance you can see clear). It will also give overtaking vehicles enough room to pull in safely to the left lane after they have passed you.

question_text: What should a driver do in this situation?
option_a: Accelerate quickly to clear the crossing.
option_b: Continue ahead and overtake the blue van.
option_c: Allow the pedestrian to cross the road.
option_d: Sound the horn and drive on.
explanation: When approaching a zebra crossing, you must yield to pedestrians already on or about to cross the road.

question_text: What should drivers be aware of if they meet horses with riders on the road?
option_a: Drivers should be aware that all horse riders are experienced at handling horses.
option_b: Drivers should be aware that horse riders are obliged to dismount and control their horses while traffic is passing.
option_c: Drivers should be aware that loud noises from their vehicle will not frighten the horses.
option_d: Drivers should be aware that loud noises from their vehicle may frighten the horses and cause them to bolt.
explanation: You must know your responsibilities towards animal traffic on the road. Horses are easily startled and any sudden noises or activity could cause them to bolt.

question_text: When driving on a road with tram lines why should a driver take extra care?
option_a: Driving on the tracks can improve steering.
option_b: Driving on the tracks can reduce tyre grip.
option_c: Driving on the tracks can improve braking.
option_d: Driving on the tracks can improve tyre grip.
explanation: Different road surfaces can affect your vehicles grip on the road and its stopping distances. You should be aware of this when driving on different surfaces.

question_text: What should a driver do on the approach to this situation?
option_a: Reduce speed and stop if necessary.
option_b: Give way only if you are towing a trailer or caravan.
option_c: Drive on because the oncoming traffic must wait.
option_d: Increase speed in order to clear the bridge before the oncoming car.
explanation: When road priority is unclear you might have to yield to oncoming vehicles. Never drive a vehicle into an area that it might not be able to clear or where it could cause an obstruction or bottleneck.

question_text: What does a continuous white line along the centre of the road mean?
option_a: Parking allowed during business hours.
option_b: U-turn allowed during daylight hours.
option_c: No U-turn allowed.
option_d: Traffic can overtake
explanation: You must never do a U-turn on any stretch of road with a continuous white line along its centre. The restricted vision at such places would make doing a U-turn very unsafe.

question_text: What danger should a driver allow for over the brow of this hill?
option_a: Traffic calming measures may apply.
option_b: There may be no road markings.
option_c: There may be oncoming pedestrians.
option_d: A high-sided vehicle may be approaching.
explanation: On the approach to the brow of a hill you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: When dealing with crash victims, remember A B C. What does C stand for?
option_a: Circulation.
option_b: Coma.
option_c: Cough.
option_d: Coronary.
explanation: In assessing a crash victims vital signs, the following basic procedure should be used: First check the victim''s Airway is clear, then check they are Breathing and then check their Circulation (ABC).

question_text: What should a driver do if they see a red warning triangle on the road?
option_a: The driver should maintain speed, carry on and avoid the triangle.
option_b: The driver should stop and await instructions.
option_c: The driver should remove the triangle as it is causing an obstruction on the road.
option_d: The driver should slow down and expect a hazard up ahead.
explanation: Warning triangles are used to alert approaching traffic that there is a vehicle breakdown or collision ahead. When you come across a warning triangle, you should slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary. Do not allow yourself to be distracted by the incident.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
option_a: A driver should move to the left-hand side (nearside) in case the cyclist moves out.
option_b: The cyclist may move onto the roadway without paying attention to moving traffic.
option_c: The cyclist will stay on the cycle path.
option_d: The cyclist will stop at the end of the cycle path to allow traffic to pass by.
explanation: You should show extra care when approaching cyclists who are about to exit from a cycle lane and join the roadway.

question_text: Which vehicle is in the correct position to make a right turn from the major road into the minor road?
explanation: The correct position from which to turn right from a major road to a minor road is just left of centre. You should take up the correct position in good time and avoid cutting the corner or swan necking - that is going beyond the turning point as car 2 is in the picture.

question_text: An approaching driver notices that the boy on the children's bicycle has said goodbye to his friend. What is the correct action for the driver to take?
option_a: Slow down and beckon the boy to cross the road.
option_b: Stop the car until the boy has moved off.
option_c: Be prepared for the boy setting off at any moment.
option_d: Proceed as the boy is on the footpath.
explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children''s behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation or to stop.

question_text: Which car, if any, is parked incorrectly?
option_a: The red car.
option_b: Neither car.
option_c: The green car.
option_d: Both cars.
explanation: It is an offence to park within 15 metres before or 5 metres after a pedestrian crossing. Parking in this manner may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the crossing and endanger pedestrians.

question_text: What should a driver do in this situation?
option_a: Reduce speed and be prepared to stop as other children could follow.
option_b: Sound the horn as a warning and proceed.
option_c: Maintain speed and not expect other children.
option_d: Drive on quickly in order not to delay following traffic.
explanation: You should always be aware of other road users especially children, who can be unpredictable and show no road sense. You should drive with extra care in areas where there are children about - for example, near schools, playgrounds and in residential areas.

question_text: What should the driver do if there are cattle on the road ahead?
option_a: The driver should switch on the headlights and try to pass as quickly as possible.
option_b: The driver should sound the horn, switch on headlights, reduce speed and pass with care.
option_c: The driver should sound the horn to try to get the cattle to move aside.
option_d: The driver should reduce speed and pass them with care.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If you meet cattle or other animals on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Don''t use the horn or do anything that might frighten the animals. You must stop if directed to do so by the person in charge of animals.

question_text: What should a driver do if dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle?
option_a: Accelerate to get out of range of light as quickly as possible.
option_b: Flash the oncoming vehicle and move to the left.
option_c: Dazzle the oncoming vehicle with their own main beam and move to the right.
option_d: Look to the left-hand edge (nearside) of the roadway and slow down if necessary.
explanation: If you are dazzled by the lights of oncoming traffic, turn your eyes to the left edge (nearside) of the road. If necessary, stop and allow your eyes to recover before driving on.

question_text: What should a driver do when travelling behind this vehicle?
option_a: Pass the vehicle slowly by mounting the kerb on the left.
option_b: Overtake the vehicle in front.
option_c: Reduce speed and prepare to stop if necessary.
option_d: Drive as close as possible to the vehicle.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to the changing traffic situation as you approach junctions.

question_text: What should a driver do when continuing straight ahead in the middle lane?
option_a: Slow down and allow the driver in front to change lanes.
option_b: Take position in the right-hand lane even if proceeding straight ahead.
option_c: Overtake the other vehicles quickly on the right-hand side.
option_d: Take any lane as convenient.
explanation: You should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front especially when it is slowing down or stopping.

question_text: What should the driver do in this situation?
option_a: As the driver is entering the roundabout they have right of way.
option_b: The driver may proceed onto the roundabout in front of the yellow car.
option_c: The driver must wait for the yellow car to stop.
option_d: The driver must yield to the yellow car on the roundabout.
explanation: When you reach the roundabout, you must give way to traffic approaching from the right - unless signs, road markings or traffic lights tell you otherwise.

question_text: What danger should a driver allow for over the brow of this hill?
option_a: There may be a pelican crossing ahead.
option_b: A high-sided vehicle may be approaching.
option_c: Traffic calming measures may apply.
option_d: There may be hedge-cutting taking place.
explanation: On the approach to the brow of a hill you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: What procedure should a driver follow when intending to overtake a cyclist travelling in the same direction up ahead?
option_a: Mirror check, indicate and move out if it is safe to do so.
option_b: Mirror check, and move out to overtake without indicating.
option_c: Indicate, move out and check the mirror for following traffic.
option_d: Indicate, check the mirror, move out and overtake when safe to do so.
explanation: The sequence drivers should follow the mirror - signal - manoeuvre routine when overtaking. Drivers should overtake only when it is safe to do so. Give extra space to cyclists when overtaking them, as they may need to move out to avoid a pothole, or they could be blown into your path on windy days.

question_text: What danger should a driver allow for over the brow of this hill?
option_a: Safety cameras may be in operation.
option_b: There may be no road markings.
option_c: There may be livestock on the road.
option_d: There may be a bus stop ahead.
explanation: On approach to the brow of a hill you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: In this situation who should wait?
option_a: Neither vehicle should wait.
option_b: Whichever vehicle is furthest away from the van.
option_c: The oncoming vehicle must wait.
option_d: The driver behind the stopped van should wait.
explanation: When you are overtaking a parked vehicle or obstruction, you should yield to oncoming vehicles so that they don''t have to slow down or take evasive action.

question_text: What is the correct action to take in this situation?
option_a: Keep a close eye on the children and be prepared to brake in good time.
option_b: Continue to drive at the same speed.
option_c: Drive closer to the left-hand side (nearside) and sound the horn.
option_d: Speed up to pass the children quickly.
explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children''s behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation or to stop.

question_text: What should a driver do on a narrow road when another vehicle is coming in the opposite direction?
option_a: Maintain road position and speed. Then flash the vehicles lights to alert the other driver to your presence.
option_b: Reduce speed and allow reasonable clearance between their vehicle and the oncoming one before proceeding.
option_c: Position your vehicle along the middle of the road to encourage the other driver to pull in.
option_d: Maintain position and expect the other vehicle to move over.
explanation: You should always be prepared to react to hazards ahead. When you meet a vehicle coming against you on a narrow road, you should show consideration and slow down to a appropriate speed so that the two vehicles can pass each other safely.

question_text: Why might it be dangerous to drive on a poorly-lit street?
option_a: It may be difficult to make out poorly lit vehicles in the dark areas.
option_b: Drivers can only see the traffic in front of them.
option_c: Drivers can only see the traffic coming against them.
option_d: Traffic lights will not be working.
explanation: When you are driving along a poorly-lit street, you should take extra care and be prepared to react to hazards such as unlit parked vehicles.

question_text: What should the driver of the silver car do before turning left?
option_a: Overtake the cyclist on the left and complete the turn.
option_b: Sound the horn to alert the cyclist to the car's presence.
option_c: Increase speed to be able to complete the left turn before the cyclist.
option_d: Allow the cyclist heading straight on to pass.
explanation: Do not overtake a cyclist as you approach a junction at which you are turning left. The cyclist might be continuing ahead. Cyclists are vulnerable road users and may be unstable in slow-moving traffic and at junctions. Give them more room.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Dual carriageway ends.
option_b: Tunnel ahead.
option_c: Road narrows ahead
option_d: Oncoming traffic has priority.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of the end of a dual carriageway. You will soon be entering a 2-way road.

question_text: How does giving a late signal affect other road users?
option_a: They may not have been given sufficient time to react.
option_b: It only affects other road users at roundabouts.
option_c: They are not affected.
option_d: It only affects other road users at traffic lights.
explanation: Giving signals is a way of telling other road users what you intend to do. So, you should signal properly before moving off, turning right or left, changing lanes, overtaking, slowing down or stopping. Signal clearly and in good time, and keep in mind that giving a signal does not give you the right of way. Late signals may confuse other road users.

question_text: Why must a driver be particularly careful here?
option_a: Because a vehicle could come from the left.
option_b: The vehicle coming from the right has the right of way.
option_c: Because there is an increased danger of skidding.
option_d: The vehicle coming from the right is not required to signal.
explanation: Where there are fallen leaves on the road surface, your tyres might have reduced grip on the road surface and your braking distances might be greater.

question_text: The driver intends to turn right at this junction - what should the driver do?
option_a: Proceed in front of the bus and motorcyclist.
option_b: Proceed after the motorcycle and bus have passed.
option_c: Proceed in front of the bus only.
option_d: Proceed after the motorcycle only.
explanation: When you are turning right at a junction, you should yield to traffic on the major road, and to oncoming traffic at the junction.

question_text: What should a driver be alert to in this area?
option_a: Pedestrians may be hitch-hiking.
option_b: There may be refuse bins between the parked vehicles.
option_c: Pedestrians may cross between parked cars.
option_d: Parked vehicles may have trailers attached.
explanation: When driving in a built-up area, you should drive with caution and be prepared to react to pedestrians crossing from between parked vehicles.

question_text: When wanting to stop temporarily in a congested area where should the driver park?
option_a: Double park in a convenient place with your hazard lights on.
option_b: Park slightly up on the footpath with the hazard lights on.
option_c: Park on the footpath so as not to impede the free flow of traffic in the road.
option_d: Park in a safe, legal and convenient place.
explanation: You should park only where it is safe, legal and convenient to do so. Your parked vehicle must not cause a danger or an obstruction to other road users. The use of hazard warning lights does not excuse unsafe or illegal parking.

question_text: When approaching the pedestrian crossing, what should the driver do in this situation?
option_a: Maintain speed, because the pedestrians have not stepped on to the crossing.
option_b: Continue to drive on fast because the pedestrians have to wait.
option_c: Slow down in good time and be prepared to stop
option_d: Sound the horn to draw attention to your vehicle and continue to drive at the same speed.
explanation: When there are pedestrians at or near a zebra crossing, you should slow down on approach and be prepared to stop to allow the pedestrians to cross safely.

question_text: The silver car is overtaking the parked red car, what should the driver do in this situation?
option_a: Reduce speed considerably and be ready to stop.
option_b: The driver should drive on at the same speed.
option_c: The driver should drive on if he does not hit the ball.
option_d: The driver should move closer to the red car.
explanation: You should read the road and be extra careful while driving through an area where children might be playing. When a ball bounces out on the road you should expect that a child might follow to retrieve the ball.

question_text: When dealing with crash victims, remember A B C. What does A stand for?
option_a: Airway.
option_b: Arms.
option_c: Assist.
option_d: Accident.
explanation: In assessing a crash victims vital signs the following basic procedure should be used First check the victim''s Airway is clear, then check they are Breathing and then check their Circulation (ABC).

question_text: After a heavy downpour, why should a driver keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front?
option_a: Because wheels rotate at a greater speed after rain.
option_b: Because tyre grip improves when wet.
option_c: Because the required stopping distances is greater.
option_d: Because wheels rotate at a slower speed after rain.
explanation: On a wet road surface, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as in dry conditions and your required stopping distance is increased. Because of that you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: A driver wants to pull out of a driveway and turn right onto the road. At the same time a cyclist is approaching from the right and a pedestrian wants to cross. Who must wait?
option_a: The cyclist must wait.
option_b: The pedestrian and the cyclist must wait.
option_c: The driver must wait.
option_d: The pedestrian must wait.
explanation: By law you must give way to other road users, including pedestrians and cyclists, when you are entering or leaving a driveway.

question_text: When driving on a cobblestone road why should you take extra care?
option_a: The road surface is uneven and road grip varies.
option_b: The smoothness of the cobblestones helps to improve grip.
option_c: The road surface is particularly even and tyre grip is improved.
option_d: The gaps between the stones helps road holding and grip is improved.
explanation: Different road surfaces can affect your vehicles grip on the road and its stopping distances. You should be aware of this when driving on different surfaces.

question_text: What should a driver do in this situation when intending to turn left?
option_a: Stop and beckon both pedestrians to cross.
option_b: Proceed between both pedestrians.
option_c: Yield to pedestrians already crossing.
option_d: Sound the horn and accelerate to proceed promptly.
explanation: By law you must yield to pedestrians already crossing at a junction. Pedestrians are vulnerable road users and you should be extra careful driving at places where pedestrians are attempting to cross the road.

question_text: What should a driver do when travelling on a country road with following traffic, and they meet pedestrians?
option_a: Flash the lights to alert following traffic of a pedestrian on the road.
option_b: Leave a minimum clearance of 30 centimetres.
option_c: Signal their intention to overtake the pedestrians.
option_d: Gesture to the pedestrians to move in off the road.
explanation: When you are driving on a road without footpaths, drivers should take extra care when they come upon pedestrians on the road. When they intend to move out and overtake, they should check the mirrors and signal to following traffic in good time to alert drivers behind that they are changing direction because of the hazard ahead.

question_text: What should the driver do when approaching a humpbacked hill?
option_a: The driver should maintain normal speed and road position.
option_b: The driver should increase speed and make progress over the humpbacked hill.
option_c: The driver should reduce speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.
option_d: The driver should move to the centre in order to avoid vehicles that may be parked on the left.
explanation: As you approach a humpbacked bridge or hill, you should be aware that there might be hidden dangers ahead - for example, overtaking traffic coming towards you. You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations such as this.

question_text: What does this Garda signal mean?
option_a: Turn left.
option_b: Stop if approaching from behind.
option_c: Stop if approaching from front.
option_d: Turn right.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you must stop.

question_text: What should the driver do when there is a sharp dip in the road ahead?
option_a: Pull in, stop and switch on hazard warning lights.
option_b: Increase speed and make progress through the dip.
option_c: Reduce speed, keep to the left and be alert for hazards ahead.
option_d: Move to the centre of the road in order to avoid any vehicles that might be parked on the left.
explanation: As you approach a sharp dip in the road, you should be aware that there might be hidden dangers ahead. For example, there might be pedestrians, cyclists or other approaching traffic, or the road could be flooded in the dip. You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations - you might need to reduce your speed and drive with extra care.

question_text: When driving into a narrow gap between oncoming vehicles and vehicles parked on the left. What should a driver do?
option_a: Indicate right, stopping if necessary until oncoming traffic has passed by.
option_b: Signal to oncoming traffic to stop, and then move to the right and drive as normal.
option_c: Always slow down, stop and wait to be beckoned forward.
option_d: Indicate and drive on enforcing your priority.
explanation: When you meet approaching traffic at a narrow gap, you should show consideration and slow down to an appropriate speed so that you and the other vehicles can pass each other safely. If necessary, give way to the other vehicles.

question_text: What should a driver do if there is a large oil spill on the road?
option_a: Maintain normal speed in a lower gear and switch on hazard warning lights.
option_b: Reduce speed by gently applying the brakes and switch on the hazard warning lights.
option_c: Maintain normal speed and try to straddle the spill with the wheels.
option_d: Depress the clutch and brake sharply and switch on the hazard warning lights.
explanation: Where oil is spilt on the road, your tyres will have reduced grip, and you might be at risk of skidding if you brake sharply. If you do come across oil on the road, brake gently and switch on your hazard warning lights for a short period to alert other traffic to the hazard.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of before crossing railway or tram lines?
option_a: There may be an uneven surface and tyre grip may be reduced when crossing the rails.
option_b: The wheels may become caught in the rails, causing the tyres to deflate.
option_c: There may be a reduction in tyre noise while crossing the rails.
option_d: The tyre grip may be improved crossing the rails
explanation: You should be aware of the impact of changes in the road surface. For example, at railway and tram crossings the uneven surface or oil deposits could reduce the grip of your tyres. Slow down as you approach railway or tram crossings and increase your distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: What should the driver allow for when following the bus on an icy road?
option_a: Same braking distance as in wet conditions.
option_b: Same braking distance as in dry conditions.
option_c: A longer braking distance is required.
option_d: A shorter braking distance is required.
explanation: When driving in icy conditions, you should always reduce speed and allow a bigger gap to the vehicle in front in order to be able to stop safely if necessary.

question_text: What should the driver do in this situation?
option_a: The driver must allow the van to cross the junction.
option_b: The cyclist must proceed first.
option_c: The cyclist must allow the other vehicles to proceed.
option_d: The driver may continue ahead with caution.
explanation: On approaching a crossroads you should check the road sign to see which traffic has priority and be prepared for emerging traffic from either side. Vehicles do not have an automatic right of way on the road. The overriding rule is to proceed with caution in all circumstances. .

question_text: When driving on this one-way street with vehicles parked on both sides, what should a driver be prepared for?
option_a: A vehicle door may open on either side of the street.
option_b: Oncoming traffic as the driver overtakes the truck.
option_c: The truck may be a left-hand drive vehicle.
option_d: The truck may not have proper markings.
explanation: When driving on a one-way street, you should be extra careful and should be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: What should the driver do?
option_a: The driver must stop and yield to all traffic.
option_b: The driver should allow the oncoming cyclist to turn first.
option_c: The driver should allow the yellow car to proceed.
option_d: The driver may turn left first.
explanation: At a cross junction of equal importance the traffic approaching from the right has priority. It is important to understand that the right of way is not an absolute right. You must proceed with caution while showing regard for other road users.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
option_a: The bus may be towing a trailer.
option_b: There may be a car hidden from view in front of the bus.
option_c: The bus may be parked at a terminus.
option_d: Only buses may use this road.
explanation: On approach to an area with a restricted view you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: When should signals (for example, with indicators) be given to other road users?
option_a: Clearly and in good time to let other road users know your intentions.
option_b: When turning, except where road markings indicate your direction.
option_c: Only when it is necessary to warn oncoming traffic.
option_d: Only when it is necessary to warn following traffic.
explanation: Giving signals is a way of telling other road users what you intend to do. So, you should signal properly before moving off, turning right or left, changing lanes, overtaking, slowing down or stopping. Signal clearly and in good time, and keep in mind that giving a signal does not give you the right of way.

question_text: In this situation, who should wait?
option_a: Both drivers should wait.
option_b: Neither driver should wait.
option_c: The driver on the main road should wait.
option_d: The driver in the red car should wait.
explanation: A vehicle driving on the main road has priority over vehicles emerging from side roads. However, you must understand that the right of way is not an absolute right of way and you should be considerate of other road users at all times.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
option_a: A minor road to the left ahead.
option_b: A sharp dip in the road ahead.
option_c: A minor road to the right ahead.
option_d: A dangerous right-hand bend ahead.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations - in this case paying attention to the warning sign clearly indicating a right-hand bend ahead.

question_text: What should a driver do if they see horse riders on the road ahead?
option_a: The driver should reduce speed and sound the horn.
option_b: The driver should turn on hazard warning lights and continue at normal speed.
option_c: The driver should reduce speed, allow extra clearance and pass with care.
option_d: The driver should increase speed and allow extra clearance.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If you meet horses or other animals on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Don''t use the horn or do anything that might frighten the animals. You must stop if directed to do so by the person in charge of animals.

question_text: What should the car driver do in this situation?
option_a: The car driver must allow the bus to proceed.
option_b: The car driver is not allowed to turn right.
option_c: The car driver must allow the motorcycle to proceed.
option_d: The car driver may proceed first.
explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic. You should proceed only when it is safe to do so.

question_text: What does a continuous white line in the centre of the road mean?
option_a: Vehicles may perform a U-turn.
option_b: Vehicles may not cross or straddle the line.
option_c: Vehicles may cross the line for a short time.
option_d: Vehicles may park during daylight hours only.
explanation: You must not cross or straddle a continuous white line in the centre of the road unless you wish to enter land or premises and it is safe to do so.

question_text: What should a driver do when being overtaken by another vehicle?
option_a: Move to the right.
option_b: Slow down quickly.
option_c: Continue at the same pace.
option_d: Increase speed.
explanation: When you are being overtaken by another vehicle, you should continue at the same pace but be alert in case the overtaking vehicle suddenly pulls back in front you.

question_text: The driver is approaching traffic lights that they know have been green for some time. What should the driver do?
option_a: The driver should be aware that the lights may change and accelerate to clear the lights before they do.
option_b: The driver should be aware that the lights may change before they reach them and be prepared to stop.
option_c: The driver should stop as the lights are about to change to red.
option_d: The driver should maintain speed until the light changes to amber.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. Where traffic lights have been green for some time, you should be prepared to stop, as the lights are probably about to change to amber.

question_text: As the driver of the car, which conduct is correct?
option_a: A driver must drive on the right-hand side to allow clearance to the motorcyclist.
option_b: A driver may proceed with caution.
option_c: Slow down and beckon the motorcyclist to cross the road.
option_d: A driver must give way to traffic on the left.
explanation: You may proceed, but you should be aware of the presence of the motorcyclist. You should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation - for example, the motorcyclist might not have seen your vehicle.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of when following the motorcyclist, and the white car is reversing onto the road?
option_a: The motorcyclist may signal the reversing driver to stop.
option_b: The driver following the motorcycle may need a longer braking distance than normal.
option_c: The brake lights on the motorcycle may not be working.
option_d: The reversing driver will stop when they see the motorcyclist.
explanation: You should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front if it is slowing down or stopping. Always read the road and be prepared to react correctly to changes in the traffic ahead.

question_text: The driver is following these two vehicles and wishes to overtake - what must the driver consider before overtaking here?
option_a: The driver's field of view is not good enough to allow safe overtaking.
option_b: The driver of the silver car may decide to turn right.
option_c: The roadway markings forbid overtaking here.
option_d: The driver should overtake both vehicles together.
explanation: You should always make sure that the road ahead is clear so that there is enough distance to allow you to overtake and get back to the correct side of the road without forcing any other road user to alter speed or course. In this case, the brow of the hill is too close to allow a driver to overtake safely.

question_text: When driving behind a bus that is signalling to turn left and there is oncoming traffic, what should a driver do?
option_a: Overtake it on the right-hand side.
option_b: Stay back and allow it to complete the turn.
option_c: Tap the brakes and sound the horn to signal to other vehicles to slow down.
option_d: Overtake it on the left-hand side.
explanation: Always allow a bus to complete a left-hand turn, because your field of view is restricted, and it could be dangerous to attempt overtaking it.

question_text: What should a driver do where a person has been injured in a collision?
option_a: Move the victim to the side of the road.
option_b: Move the vehicles out of the way to avoid causing obstruction.
option_c: Move the victim only if there is a risk of fire or further injury.
option_d: Always move the victim and the vehicles.
explanation: Never move an injured person at the scene of a collision unless there is a risk of fire or further injury. Moving an injured person could add to their injuries. Trained personnel know best how to attend to injured persons. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

question_text: What should the driver do if there are children playing at the edge of the roadway?
option_a: Maintain the same speed because the children can see an oncoming vehicle quite clearly at this point.
option_b: Accelerate and move to the right-hand side of the road to avoid the children.
option_c: Reduce speed, drive cautiously and remain ready to brake.
option_d: Give a warning signal and drive past at the same speed.
explanation: Because it is difficult to predict children''s behaviour, you should always be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation and be prepared to stop.

question_text: What danger can arise during daylight when a driver enters an area that is heavily shaded by overhanging trees?
option_a: The tyre pressure could be reduced.
option_b: The vehicle's windscreen could fog up.
option_c: The vehicle engine could suddenly run cold.
option_d: Visibility could suddenly be reduced.
explanation: When you enter a heavily shaded area after driving in bright sunlight, it might take a while for your eyes to adjust to the change, and you might not see a hazard immediately ahead.

question_text: What should a driver do when turning right at this junction?
option_a: Allow the red car to proceed.
option_b: Allow the blue car to proceed.
option_c: Proceed ahead of both cars.
option_d: Allow both cars to proceed.
explanation: When you are turning right from a main road into a side road, you must give way to oncoming traffic on the main road even if they are turning left into the same road.

question_text: What danger should a driver allow for over the brow of this hill?
option_a: There may be a pelican crossing ahead.
option_b: A vehicle may be broken down.
option_c: A high-sided vehicle may be approaching.
option_d: Safety cameras may be in operation.
explanation: On the approach to the brow of a hill you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: When a driver is driving in a line of traffic and does not intend to overtake, what should the driver do?
option_a: Drive close to the vehicle in front.
option_b: Beckon to following traffic to overtake.
option_c: Indicate left as a signal to following traffic to overtake.
option_d: Stay back and leave a gap for other drivers to overtake.
explanation: You should always allow sufficient distance between your vehicle and the vehicle in front. This will enable you to stop safely (within the distance you can see clear). It will also give overtaking vehicles enough room to pull in safely to the left lane after they have passed you.

question_text: What should the driver do in this situation?
option_a: The driver must allow the orange car to cross.
option_b: The driver may turn right.
option_c: The driver must turn left.
option_d: The driver is not allowed to turn right.
explanation: You may turn right if there no oncoming traffic but you should also be aware that there might be traffic emerging from the minor roads.

question_text: What should the driver do in this situation?
option_a: The driver must allow the blue truck to proceed.
option_b: The driver must allow the red car to proceed.
option_c: The driver may proceed first.
option_d: The driver is not allowed to turn right.
explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic and proceed only when it is safe to do so. You should also be aware that there might be emerging from the minor road.

question_text: What should the driver be most conscious of in this situation?
option_a: One of the parked vehicles may reverse into the driver's path.
option_b: No vehicles should be parked on the left hand side of the road.
option_c: The pedestrian always has right of way to cross the road.
option_d: The pedestrian may suddenly cross the road in front of the vehicle.
explanation: It is often difficult to predict other road users behaviour. Where there are parked vehicles on both sides of the road you should approach with caution, and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation and to stop.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of when driving at night along a shopping street with many different light sources?
option_a: Parking spaces may be difficult to notice.
option_b: Other vehicles do not need to use their head lights.
option_c: It is easier to see pedestrians because of the bright lights.
option_d: Traffic lights may be difficult to distinguish from the other bright lights.
explanation: When driving at night in an area where there is a variety of light sources, you need to be extra careful, as potential hazards might be more difficult to see.

question_text: How should a driver overtake the cyclist in this situation?
option_a: Overtake the cyclist, but without crossing any of the lines.
option_b: By straddling both lines and keeping close to the cyclist.
option_c: By crossing the broken white line.
option_d: By sounding the horn to warn the cyclist they intend to pass.
explanation: Where there are two lines in the centre of the road, you must obey the one closest to you. So, if the closest line is a broken white line, by law you may overtake, so long as it is safe to do so.

question_text: What should a driver do when approaching a junction normally controlled by traffic lights and the traffic lights are not lighting?
option_a: Stop at the junction and give way to traffic on the left.
option_b: Treat it as an unmarked junction and proceed cautiously while watching out for other traffic.
option_c: Proceed smartly through the junction to avoid delay.
option_d: Switch on headlights, move to centre of the junction and proceed as quickly as possible.
explanation: You should always read the road ahead and be prepared to react to changing traffic situations. If the traffic lights are not working, you should approach the junction with extra care, and you should proceed only if it is safe to do so.

question_text: The bus ahead is moving away from a bus stop. What should a driver do?
option_a: Try to get past it to avoid being delayed.
option_b: Slow down and allow it to move out.
option_c: Drive alongside it because you have right of way.
option_d: Signal to the bus driver to let you pass.
explanation: A driver should allow signalling buses back into the stream of traffic when they are moving out from a stop. Be careful of pedestrians getting on and off buses, particularly of children near schools.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of when approaching a vehicle which is attempting to park?
option_a: That there may be a driveway at the point where the vehicle is parking.
option_b: The driver may have to stop and assist the driver parking the vehicle.
option_c: The vehicle may be parking at an area designated for loading.
option_d: That the vehicle being parked may move out without warning.
explanation: When you approach a vehicle that is being parked on the roadway, you should be aware that its driver will probably be concentrating on parking the vehicle and may not be aware of moving out into the road to correct its position.

question_text: What should a driver do when approaching traffic lights that change from green to amber?
option_a: Accelerate to clear the junction.
option_b: Stop the vehicle immediately.
option_c: Stop, unless it is unsafe to do so.
option_d: Sound the horn while proceeding through the junction.
explanation: When you are approaching a set of traffic lights showing green, you should take care and be prepared to stop if the amber light comes on.

question_text: When intending to turn right as shown, what should the car driver do?
option_a: Wait and allow the truck and the oncoming vehicle to proceed first.
option_b: Continue with care as the driver has right of way.
option_c: Wait and allow the truck to proceed first.
option_d: Wait and allow the oncoming vehicle to pass.
explanation: When you are turning right from a main road onto a side road, you must by law give way to oncoming traffic on the main road.

question_text: What do flashing amber beacons on an oncoming vehicle alert a driver to?
option_a: That the oncoming vehicle may be slow moving or extra wide.
option_b: That the oncoming vehicle is fast moving.
option_c: That the oncoming vehicle is an emergency vehicle.
option_d: That the oncoming vehicle is a military vehicle.
explanation: Flashing amber beacons are used by recovery vehicles and vehicles carrying abnormal loads. You should be aware that these vehicles may need extra room and could conceal following traffic. When you come across such vehicles, slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.

question_text: What should a driver do if they meet a vehicle with flashing amber beacons?
option_a: Increase speed while keeping left.
option_b: Slow down and prepare to stop.
option_c: Stop because it is an emergency vehicle.
option_d: Flash their headlights to acknowledge the beacons.
explanation: Flashing amber beacons are used by recovery vehicles and vehicles carrying abnormal loads. You should be aware that these vehicles may need extra room and could conceal following traffic. When you come across such vehicles, slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary.

question_text: What should the driver do when approaching this situation?
option_a: The driver should be prepared for the vehicle in front to increase speed.
option_b: Reduce speed and remain ready to brake since the girl on the footpath could suddenly cross the road.
option_c: The driver may overtake the car and the girl as the road is marked with a broken white line.
option_d: The driver should maintain current speed and reduce distance from the silver car.
explanation: It is often difficult to predict other road users behaviour. You should be prepared in case the pedestrian steps onto the road and the silver car stops suddenly.

question_text: What should a driver do to assist a person who is unconscious following a collision?
option_a: Try and get the person to drink something warm.
option_b: Try to keep the person warm with a blanket or overcoat.
option_c: Raise the person's head and hold it in that position.
option_d: Move the person to the nearest hospital immediately.
explanation: If a person is unconscious following a collision, a driver should try to keep them warm with a blanket or overcoat until the emergency services arrive. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

question_text: Is tailgating allowed on a motorway or dual carriageway?
option_a: No, because other vehicles do not have room to overtake.
option_b: No, because the vehicle in front may stop suddenly.
option_c: Yes, because all traffic moves in the one direction at the same time.
option_d: Yes, because there is oncoming traffic.
explanation: If you drive too close to the vehicle in front and it brakes suddenly, you will not have enough time to react. For that reason you should always keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. One way of calculating a safe distance in dry weather is the two-second rule: allow at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and your own vehicle passing a fixed point such as a lamp post or sign post.

question_text: What danger should a driver allow for over the brow of this hill?
option_a: There may be no road markings ahead.
option_b: There may be a bus stop ahead.
option_c: There may be a slow moving vehicle in your lane.
option_d: Traffic calming measures may apply.
explanation: On the approach to the brow of a hill you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: The driver intends to turn left at this junction - what should the driver do?
option_a: Allow the cyclist to continue before turning left.
option_b: Yield right of way to the van.
option_c: Turn left in front of the cyclist.
option_d: Allow the van and cyclist to proceed.
explanation: Do not overtake a cyclist as you approach a junction at which you are turning left. The cyclist might be continuing ahead. Cyclists are vulnerable road users and may be unstable in slow-moving traffic and at junctions. Give them more room.

question_text: What should the driver be aware of when crossing road markings such as lines and directional arrows in wet weather?
option_a: The required stopping distance is reduced due to improved tyre grip.
option_b: The required stopping distance is increased due to reduced tyre grip.
option_c: Steering control is improved.
option_d: The tyre grip is improved.
explanation: You should be aware of the impact of changes in the road surface. For example, road markings and directional arrows can become slippery when wet. Where possible, avoid driving on road markings, and be aware of the increased risk of skidding.

question_text: When preparing to stop, a driver notices the vehicle behind is towing a trailer. What should the driver do?
option_a: Stop quickly keeping a close eye on the rear-view mirror.
option_b: Indicate in good time and pull in gradually to allow the vehicle behind extra stopping distance.
option_c: Speed up temporarily to put distance between their vehicle and the vehicle behind.
option_d: Use the handbrake to slow down and stop.
explanation: When you are slowing down or stopping, you should be mindful of the type of vehicle that is following you. For example, if the vehicle following you is a large vehicle or one towing a trailer, you should think of indicating a little earlier than normal to allow the following vehicle enough time to react safely.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of in this situation?
option_a: The tram may move away without warning.
option_b: The pedestrian always has the right of way to cross in front of traffic.
option_c: There is no danger as the tram is on rails.
option_d: The pedestrian may leave the traffic island without paying attention.
explanation: You should read the road ahead and expect extra pedestrian activity when the tram is at the stop.

question_text: What lights should a driver use in dense fog?
option_a: Front and rear fog lights along with main beam lights.
option_b: Front and rear fog lights along with side lights.
option_c: Front and rear fog lights along with hazard warning lights.
option_d: Front and rear fog lights along with dipped headlights.
explanation: When driving in dense fog you should switch on your front and rear fog lights along with dipped headlights. You should not drive in fog with main beam headlights on.

question_text: What should the car driver do in this situation?
option_a: The driver must allow the cyclist to proceed.
option_b: The driver must allow the motorcyclist to proceed.
option_c: The driver must stop and yield right of way to the other road users.
option_d: The driver may turn right before the cyclist.
explanation: When you are turning right from a major road to a minor road, you must yield to oncoming traffic, and you should proceed only when it is safe to do so.

question_text: What should a driver do at an amber traffic light?
option_a: Continue only if sure that the junction is clear of pedestrians.
option_b: Continue as there is no traffic at the junction.
option_c: Make sure to pass the lights before they turn red.
option_d: Stop at the line unless it is not safe to do so.
explanation: By law you must stop at an amber traffic light if it is safe to do so.

question_text: When driving on this one-way street with vehicles parked on both sides, what should a driver be prepared for?
option_a: Pedestrians crossing between the vehicles.
option_b: Oncoming traffic as the driver overtakes the truck.
option_c: The truck may not have proper markings.
option_d: The truck may be a left-hand drive vehicle.
explanation: When driving on a one-way street, you should be extra careful and be prepared to react to a change in the traffic situation.

question_text: What should a driver do if they arrive at the scene of a collision involving a vehicle carrying hazardous materials?
option_a: Keep well clear and call the emergency services.
option_b: Try to prevent any further leakage of hazardous materials before raising the alarm.
option_c: Contact the haulage company who own the vehicle.
option_d: Try to move the vehicle to a safe place.
explanation: If a driver arrives at the scene of a collision involving a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, they should keep well clear of the scene. Call the emergency services on 999 or 112 and give them as much information as you can about the marking labels on the vehicle. You should also warn other road users about the danger. Allow the emergency services to do any rescuing.

question_text: What is the quickest way to warn other traffic of a crash?
option_a: Call local radio station.
option_b: Use hazard lights.
option_c: Stand in the road and wave arms.
option_d: Place a large object in the centre of the road.
explanation: If you arrive at the scene of a crash, find a safe place to stop so that you don''t endanger yourself or others, warn other road users of the incident by using hazard lights.

question_text: Where an injured person is discovered lying in the road, when should they be moved?
option_a: If the person has broken bones.
option_b: If the person is cold.
option_c: If the person needs CPR.
option_d: If the person is bleeding.
explanation: If a person discovered lying in the road is not breathing, it may be essential to move them in order to safely carry out emergency CPR. It may also be necessary to move them under other circumstances but an urgent assessment of the situation should be carried out first.

question_text: If a driver is involved in a serious collision with an uninsured motorist, where nobody is injured, who should it be reported to?
option_a: The local Motor Taxation Office.
option_b: The National Driver Licence Service (NDLS)
option_c: The Irish Insurance Federation.
option_d: The driver's insurance company and the GardaÌ_.
explanation: If you are involved in a serious collision, you should always report it to the GardaÌ_ and to your insurance company.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The cyclist intends to cross the road.
option_b: The cyclist intends to turn left.
option_c: The cyclist intends to stop.
option_d: The cyclist is signalling the driver to stop.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclist intends to turn left.

question_text: What is good basic first aid for a person who has been burned?
option_a: Apply grease to the burn.
option_b: Remove clothing covering the burn.
option_c: Apply warm water to the burn.
option_d: Apply cold water to the burn.
explanation: When a person has been burned firstly check the person for shock, then try to cool the burn if you can. Try to find water or other liquid that is clean, cold and non-toxic to pour on it. The cool liquid may cool the affected area down and reduce damage. The person should be advised to seek medical advice as soon as possible.

question_text: If a vehicle breaks down, where should the driver stop?
option_a: As far to the left as possible.
option_b: In the lane where the problem occurred.
option_c: As far to the right as possible.
option_d: As far to the right as possible.
explanation: When a vehicle breaks down it is important to move as far in to the left as possible for the convenience of other road users and the safety of the vehicles occupants

question_text: When calling for help on an emergency telephone on the motorway, who does the call go to?
option_a: The GardaÌ_.
option_b: National Roads Authority.
option_c: National Safety Council.
option_d: Road Safety Authority.
explanation: The emergency telephones at the side of a motorway are linked directly to An Garda SÌ_ochÌÁna in order for them to respond appropriately as soon as possible. The GardaÌ_ know precisely the location of each call using these phones.

question_text: Who should first be contacted where a person has been injured in a collision?
option_a: The injured person's insurance company.
option_b: The injured person's solicitor.
option_c: The person's relatives.
option_d: The emergency services.
explanation: Where somebody has been injured in a collision, it is important to call the emergency services immediately on 999 or 112. Trained emergency services personnel know best how to attend to injured persons.

question_text: What type of drink should be given to a person who has been injured in a collision?
option_a: A cold drink.
option_b: A hot drink.
option_c: A non-alcoholic drink.
option_d: No drink should be given.
explanation: A person who has been injured in a collision should not be given anything to drink, as this could cause them to choke. Ideally trained personnel should be consulted before attending to an injured person. Call the emergency services (on 999 or 112) or make sure that someone else has called them.

question_text: What should a driver do if involved in a collision with another vehicle where nobody is injured?
option_a: Exchange no details but report the incident to the GardaÌ_.
option_b: Exchange all relevant details with the other driver.
option_c: Give their name and address only to the other person.
option_d: Submit a written report to the Insurance Bureau of Ireland.
explanation: If a you are involved in a collision with another vehicle where nobody is injured, you should exchange all the relevant details with the other driver - including name, address, vehicle registration, make and model and all insurance details.

question_text: What should a driver do if involved in an incident where there is damage to property only?
option_a: It is not necessary to report it to the GardaÌ_ provided it has been reported to the property owner.
option_b: There is no need to report the incident if there is no damage to the vehicle.
option_c: Report the incident both to the property owner and the GardaÌ_ within 48 hours.
option_d: It is only necessary to report the incident to the GardaÌ_ within 10 days.
explanation: If the incident causes damage to property only and there is a Garda present, it must be reported to the Garda. If there is no Garda present, the owner or the person in charge of the property must be informed. If neither are present then the relevant information must be provided at a Garda Station as soon as possible.

question_text: In order to inform the emergency services of a crash what telephone number should be called?
explanation: If a driver arrives at or is involved in a crash it may be essential to obtain the assistance of the emergency services as a matter of urgency. The common European emergency number is 112 however in Ireland you may also use 999.

question_text: How would hydraulic power steering be affected if an engine stalled in slow-moving traffic?
option_a: The steering would become heavy and difficult to operate.
option_b: The steering fluid reservoir would lose all its fluid.
option_c: The steering wheel would automatically lock.
option_d: The steering would become much lighter and easier to operate.
explanation: Hydraulic power steering is operated by a pump which is driven by the engine. If the engine stalls, the pump stops working, and the steering becomes heavy and requires much more effort to turn.

question_text: How should a driver in a vehicle without anti-lock brakes (ABS) deal with a front-wheel straight-line skid?
option_a: Pull the handbrake and hold the footbrake down.
option_b: Press in the clutch and release the accelerator.
option_c: Turn the steering wheel gently from side to side.
option_d: Press and release the footbrake at rapid intervals.
explanation: If your vehicle does not have ABS and it goes into a straight-line front-wheel skid due to braking, press and release the brake pedal repeatedly and rapidly. This will help to restore tyre grip and enable you to regain control.

question_text: What should a driver do to avoid having to make an emergency stop?
option_a: Keep the left hand available to apply the handbrake.
option_b: Scan the road well ahead.
option_c: Drive with the left foot covering the clutch pedal.
option_d: Drive with the left foot covering the brake pedal.
explanation: When driving in traffic, read the road ahead and keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. Use the two-second rule to determine your safe distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: What should a driver do if they get a tyre blow-out on the road?
option_a: Switch off the engine ignition to bring the vehicle to a halt.
option_b: Apply the handbrake immediately to bring the vehicle to a halt.
option_c: Continue driving until they reach a garage.
option_d: Apply the footbrake gently and bring the vehicle to a halt.
explanation: If a tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, slow down gradually and find a safe and suitable place to stop. Switch on your hazard warning lights and change the wheel or call for assistance.

question_text: When driving along, a driver feels that the oncoming car may crash into their vehicle. What should they do?
option_a: Apply the handbrake immediately to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
option_b: Switch off the engine ignition to help bring the vehicle to a halt.
option_c: Apply the footbrake gently and bring the vehicle to a halt.
option_d: Sound the horn to attract the attention of the other driver and take evasive action.
explanation: If there is an oncoming vehicle in your path, take evasive action and sound your horn to alert the other driver. Bring your vehicle to a halt immediately.

question_text: What should a driver do when suddenly confronted by a hazard on the road?
option_a: Slowly brake and switch off the ignition.
option_b: Decelerate and apply the footbrake firmly.
option_c: Depress clutch and switch off the ignition.
option_d: Apply the handbrake and the footbrake together.
explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency, apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Children's play area ahead.
option_b: Children's play area ahead.
option_c: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
option_d: School ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a school ahead. You should adjust your speed and react accordingly as there may be children in the area.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a four-wheel sideways skid?
option_a: Turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction and apply the handbrake.
option_b: Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator.
option_c: Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and apply the handbrake.
option_d: Turn the steering wheel in the opposite direction to improve tyre grip.
explanation: If your vehicle goes into a four-wheel skid, turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the skid and ease off the accelerator. This should help to bring the wheels back into line and allow you to regain control.

question_text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
option_a: Ask a passenger to stand on the motorway to warn other traffic.
option_b: Place a red warning triangle to the left of the vehicle.
option_c: Wear a high visibility vest.
option_d: Turn on the full beam headlights.
explanation: Move the vehicle to the hard shoulder. Park as near to the left as possible. If this is not possible, take steps to warn other drivers, such as switching on the hazard warning lights. Wear a high visibility vest. Always carry at least two in the vehicle.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a rear-wheel sideways skid?
option_a: Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the rear wheels are heading.
option_b: Apply the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.
option_c: Apply the footbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.
option_d: Turn the steering wheel in the same direction as the front wheels are heading.
explanation: If your vehicle goes into a rear-wheel sideways skid, turn the steering in the direction the rear wheels are heading. This should be done very gradually, as too much steering could cause the vehicle to skid in the opposite direction.

question_text: What effect could a front-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?
option_a: Anti-lock brakes will be automatically disengaged.
option_b: The wheels will lock up and stop rotating.
option_c: The steering wheel will stay in the straight on position.
option_d: The steering wheel will pull to one side.
explanation: If a front tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, you will feel the effect of it through the steering wheel. The wheel will generally pull to the side of the blown-out tyre.

question_text: What should a driver do to avoid having to make an emergency stop?
option_a: Drive with the left foot covering the clutch pedal.
option_b: Drive with the left foot covering the brake pedal.
option_c: Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.
option_d: Keep the left hand available to apply the handbrake.
explanation: When driving in traffic, read the road ahead and keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front. Use the two-second rule to determine your safe distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: When driving along and required to stop suddenly, what should a driver do?
option_a: Apply the footbrake firmly.
option_b: Steer sharply to one side and apply the handbrake.
option_c: Apply the handbrake and the footbrake together.
option_d: Depress the clutch and then apply the handbrake.
explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency, apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping.

question_text: When required to stop in an emergency, what should a driver do?
option_a: Press the footbrake and engage a higher gear.
option_b: Apply firm pressure on the footbrake.
option_c: Apply gentle pressure to the footbrake.
option_d: Apply both the clutch and handbrake.
explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency, apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping.

question_text: What action should a driver take if the engine in their vehicle cuts out suddenly when they are driving along?
option_a: Signal and steer the vehicle to the side of the road.
option_b: Depress the accelerator and then release it.
option_c: Check the handbrake is fully off.
option_d: Engage a lower gear.
explanation: If the engine in the vehicle you are driving cuts out, signal and steer to the side of the road. Switch on the hazard warning lights and contact the relevant breakdown service to get assistance.

question_text: How should a driver apply the brakes in an emergency if the vehicle is fitted with anti-lock brakes (ABS)?
option_a: Press the brake pedal only lightly.
option_b: Press and release the brake at rapid intervals.
option_c: Press and release the brake at slow intervals.
option_d: Press the brake pedal firmly and hold.
explanation: If your vehicle is fitted with ABS, brake firmly. ABS will not stop the vehicle more quickly, it will only prevent the wheels from locking. This helps you to maintain control of the vehicle.

question_text: What should a driver do if a tyre bursts on the vehicle they are driving?
option_a: Apply the brakes as quickly as possible.
option_b: Pull on the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a stop.
option_c: Hold the steering wheel firmly and pull in on the side of the road.
option_d: Continue at the normal speed and stop at the next garage.
explanation: If a tyre bursts on your vehicle, keep a firm hold of the steering, slow down gradually and stop where it is safe to do so. Switch on the hazard warning lights.

question_text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
option_a: Place a red warning triangle to the left of the vehicle.
option_b: Turn on the full beam headlights.
option_c: Ask a passenger to stand on the motorway to warn other traffic.
option_d: Move the vehicle to the hard shoulder.
explanation: Move the vehicle to the hard shoulder. Park as near to the left as possible. If this is not possible, take steps to warn other drivers, such as switching on the hazard warning lights.

question_text: What effect could a rear-tyre blow-out have on a vehicle?
option_a: The handbrake will automatically come on.
option_b: It could cause the wheels to lock and stop rotating.
option_c: It could cause the vehicle to sway from side to side.
option_d: The steering wheel will pull to the right.
explanation: If a rear tyre on the vehicle you are driving blows out, the vehicle may sway from side to side, and this will affect its stability. Slow down, pull in where it is safe to do so, and switch on the hazard warning lights. Change the wheel or call for assistance.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets into a front-wheel sideways skid?
option_a: Apply the handbrake.
option_b: Continue to accelerate.
option_c: Release the accelerator.
option_d: Press the footbrake.
explanation: If your vehicle goes into a front-wheel sideways skid, release the accelerator and do not try to steer until the tyres regain some grip on the road.

question_text: When required to stop in an emergency, what should a driver do?
option_a: Apply the footbrake and engage a higher gear.
option_b: Apply the footbrake firmly.
option_c: Depress the clutch pedal and engage a lower gear.
option_d: Switch off the ABS system.
explanation: To stop your vehicle in an emergency, apply the footbrake firmly, and maintain the pressure until the vehicle stops. Depress the clutch pedal just before stopping.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down or they are involved in a collision in a tunnel?
option_a: Switch off all lights and remain in vehicle until help arrives.
option_b: Beckon other traffic to overtake.
option_c: Signal all other traffic to stop.
option_d: Switch on hazard warning lights and walk to emergency station to call for help.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

question_text: A driver wishes to go straight ahead at a cross junction of equal importance. If they encounter other traffic, what is the general rule that applies?
option_a: Give way to traffic approaching from the left only.
option_b: Carry on as normal as they always have the right of way.
option_c: Traffic approaching from the driver's right has right of way.
option_d: Give way to traffic approaching firstly from the left and then the right.
explanation: If a driver is at a junction where the roads are of equal importance, traffic on the driver''s right has the right of way. The driver must let that traffic pass before moving on. It is important to understand that the right of way is not an absolute right. Drivers must proceed with caution whilst showing regard for other users of the road.

question_text: What is the main difference between driving on a motorway and driving on other types of road?
option_a: Traffic generally travels at lower speeds on a motorway than on a dual-carriageway.
option_b: Traffic travelling at 120 km/h must only use the outside lane of a motorway.
option_c: Traffic is generally permitted to travel at a higher speed on a motorway.
option_d: Learner permit holders must be accompanied by a full licence holder.
explanation: Motorways are designed so that traffic can move faster and more freely, without traffic lights, crossroads, level crossings and other road features that might slow down traffic. There are also restrictions on who may use a motorway - for example L-drivers and motorcycles under 50 cc are prohibited.

question_text: In general, when turning right on a two-way road, where should a driver position the vehicle?
option_a: At either side of the middle of the road.
option_b: At the far left-hand side of the road.
option_c: At the far right-hand side of the road.
option_d: Just left of the middle of the road.
explanation: In general, the correct position to be in before turning right is just left of the centre of the road. Where the road is wide enough, this position allows traffic coming from behind and going straight ahead to pass safely on the left. The driver should be alert for road markings which direct them to follow a certain course.

question_text: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?
option_a: Two motorway lanes and one non-motorway lane in two directions.
option_b: Two motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
option_c: Two non-motorway lanes and one motorway lane in two directions.
option_d: Two non-motorway lanes in one direction and one non-motorway lane in the opposite direction.
explanation: A 2-plus-1 road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. The two-lane section allows for safe overtaking and alternates with a one-lane section roughly every 2 kilometres.

question_text: What is a clearway?
option_a: An area where stopping and parking is reserved for buses and taxis only.
option_b: An area where stopping and parking is not permitted during certain times.
option_c: An area that is strictly reserved for the loading and unloading of HGVs.
option_d: An area that is reserved for pedestrians and motorised wheelchairs.
explanation: A clearway is an area of road that must be kept clear for moving traffic during certain times of the day ( usually busy periods). The times when stopping or parking is prohibited are shown on an information plate under the sign.

question_text: What should a driver do before turning right from a major road into a minor road?
option_a: Stop and signal traffic to exit right from the minor road.
option_b: Commence turn in front of oncoming traffic as they must yield to traffic turning right.
