option_c: Yield right of way to oncoming traffic and to pedestrians crossing at the junction.
option_d: Stop and signal traffic to exit left from the minor road.
explanation: The driver must yield to oncoming traffic and to pedestrians who are already crossing when turning right from a major road to a minor road.

question_text: What traffic may use a with-flow bus lane during the times specified on information signs at the start of the lane?
option_a: Buses, taxis and cyclists.
option_b: All traffic
option_c: Vehicles with more than one passenger.
option_d: Buses only.
explanation: A bus lane is a special lane for the use of buses. A with-flow bus lane is one that runs in the same direction as the traffic beside it. Taxis and cyclists may also use with-flow bus lanes. Other traffic may use them outside the hours posted on the accompanying plate.

question_text: When approaching a roundabout, to whom should a driver give way ?
option_a: The driver must only give way to heavy goods vehicles on the roundabout.
option_b: The driver must give way to traffic approaching from the right or already on the roundabout.
option_c: The driver approaching the roundabout always has right of way.
option_d: The driver must only give way to pedestrians and cyclists on the roundabout.
explanation: Drivers should always approach roundabouts with caution. They should be prepared to give way to traffic on the right, traffic already on the roundabout, pedestrians already crossing and to always stop if necessary.

question_text: What should a driver do when joining a motorway from a slip road?
option_a: Drive directly onto the motorway as the driver on the acceleration lane has right of way.
option_b: Try to match the vehicle speed to that of traffic already on the motorway and merge into it in a suitable gap.
option_c: Always stop at the end of the acceleration lane and yield to traffic on the motorway
option_d: Drive along the hard shoulder until a suitable gap appears in the motorway traffic to allow the driver to merge into it.
explanation: When joining a motorway a driver should try to match their speed to that of the motorway traffic and merge into it when a suitable gap appears, avoiding driving in the hard shoulder, while yielding to traffic already on the motorway.

question_text: The driver intends to turn right at this junction - what should the driver do?
option_a: Proceed in front of the motorcycle and the bus.
option_b: Stop in front of the bus.
option_c: Stop at the line.
option_d: Stop in front of the motorcycle.
explanation: You must stop at the line where a junction is controlled by a Stop sign and Stop line. Do not proceed until it is safe to do so.

question_text: When a driver wants to turn left into a property and there is a bus lane on the left, what should the driver do?
option_a: A driver should give way to buses only.
option_b: Give way to cyclists and taxis which may be using the bus lane.
option_c: Give way to cyclists, taxis and buses which may be using the bus lane.
option_d: A driver should never turn left across a bus lane.
explanation: If a driver needs to cross a bus lane on their left in order to enter a property, they should take extra care that there are no buses, taxis or cyclists in the bus lane. They should check mirrors, signal and turn into the property when it is safe to do so.

question_text: What should a driver do if there is very heavy traffic congestion in a tunnel?
option_a: Leave the vehicle.
option_b: Switch on hazard warning lights.
option_c: Stop at the nearest emergency exit.
option_d: Keep close to the vehicle in front.
explanation: If there is traffic congestion in a tunnel, you should switch on hazard lights and remain patient. Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front even in slow-moving traffic. Listen for traffic messages on the tunnel radio station, if available.

question_text: If a driver wishes to drive a vehicle but the tax disc is expired, what should they do?
option_a: They should renew it within 10 days of expiry.
option_b: They should contact the GardaÌ_ for approval.
option_c: They should tax it immediately.
option_d: They should drive it only in case of an emergency.
explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display the up-to-date tax disc before it may be taken on the road.

question_text: What should a driver do when travelling on a motorway or dual carriageway?
option_a: Be alert for other drivers who may suddenly change lanes or reduce speed.
option_b: Match the speed to that of the vehicle in front.
option_c: Relax because there will be no oncoming traffic.
option_d: Match the speed to that of the vehicle in the adjoining lane.
explanation: Motorways and dual carriageways are designed to help traffic travel faster and more safely between destinations. Traffic conditions can change very quickly because of the speed and increased volumes of traffic and lanes, and you need to be particularly alert to other drivers changing lanes or reducing speed.

question_text: What position should a driver generally adopt on approach to a roundabout when intending to take the first exit to the left?
option_a: Approach in the left-hand lane.
option_b: Approach in any lane available.
option_c: Approach by straddling both lanes.
option_d: Approach in the right-hand lane.
explanation: When a driver intends to take any exit between the 6 o'clock and 12 o'clock positions they should generally approach the roundabout in the left lane unless road markings dictate otherwise.

question_text: Is a driver permitted to pick up or set down a passenger on a motorway?
option_a: It is permitted provided that the driver stops on the hard-shoulder.
option_b: A driver is never permitted to pick up or set down passengers on a motorway.
option_c: It is not permitted, except during daylight hours.
option_d: It is only permitted within 200 metres of a slip-road.
explanation: Motorways are designed so that traffic can move faster and more freely. It is illegal and dangerous to stop a vehicle on any part of a motorway except in an emergency or when signalled to do so by a Garda.

question_text: After exiting the motorway and coming towards a junction at the end of the deceleration lane (slip road) what should a driver do?
option_a: Maintain motorway speeds to the end of the slip road.
option_b: The driver must always stop at the end of a slip road.
option_c: Be alert for oncoming and crossing traffic at the end of the slip road.
option_d: The driver should continue at the junction as traffic on the slip road has right of way.
explanation: The driver should check for signs showing a lower speed; Use the speedometer to make sure that they are obeying the reduced speed limit; remember that the slip roads and link roads between motorways may include sharp bends and that they may encounter junctions and other traffic. Remember that motorway rules no longer apply.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
option_a: Use the emergency telephone to call for help.
option_b: Hitch a lift to the nearest service area and get help.
option_c: Walk to the end of the tunnel to call the GardaÌ_.
option_d: Flag down a passing motorist and ask for help.
explanation: If a driver''s vehicle stops in a tunnel due to a breakdown, switch off the engine, switch on the hazard warning lights, check the radio for instructions and use the emergency phone at the emergency station to call for help, check all electronic signs in the tunnel for information.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle goes on fire in a tunnel?
option_a: Drive to the nearest emergency station.
option_b: Leave the vehicle and use the fire extinguishers provided in the tunnel to extinguish the fire.
option_c: Leave the vehicle and follow the emergency escape route.
option_d: Drive to the nearest fire exit.
explanation: If your vehicle goes on fire in a tunnel, you should stop the vehicle as soon as possible, evacuate any passengers to a safe place, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

question_text: In what direction should a driver turn when entering a roundabout?
option_a: To the right when controlled by a traffic light.
option_b: To either left or right.
option_c: To the right.
option_d: To the left.
explanation: By law you must enter a roundabout by turning to the left and giving way to traffic already on the roundabout.

question_text: In general, where two lanes are provided on the approach to a roundabout, which lane should a driver select when they intend taking an exit to the right (past the 12 o''clock position) of the roundabout?
option_a: By straddling both lanes.
option_b: The right-hand lane.
option_c: The left-hand lane.
option_d: Either lane.
explanation: When a driver approaches a roundabout where two lanes are provided, they should choose the most suitable one based on the road markings and the exit they intend to take off the roundabout. The left lane is generally used for vehicles exiting to the left (9 o''clock) or straight ahead (12 o''clock) and the right is for vehicles exiting at any exit after 12 o''clock.

question_text: Where may a driver overtake on a 2-plus-1 road?
option_a: In the two-lane stretch.
option_b: In the one-lane stretch if there is no oncoming traffic.
option_c: In the one-lane stretch.
option_d: In either the one-lane stretch or the two-lane stretch.
explanation: A 2-plus-1 road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. When you need to overtake, you should wait until you reach the 2-lane section which occurs approximately every 2 kilometres.

question_text: When joining a motorway from a slip road, what should a driver do?
option_a: Adjust speed to match that of the motorway traffic, and merge into a suitable gap.
option_b: Use the size of the vehicle to assert its position on the motorway.
option_c: Drive on the hard shoulder for a distance until a suitable gap appears in the traffic.
option_d: Stop on the slip road until a suitable gap appears in the traffic.
explanation: When joining a motorway from a slip road, drivers should adjust their speed to that of the motorway traffic on the acceleration lane and merge into a suitable gap in Lane 1. Do not force other traffic to swerve or slow down to avoid your vehicle.

question_text: In general, which of the following should a driver do before entering a tunnel?
option_a: Ensure that full headlights are switched on.
option_b: Only use dipped headlights if there is other traffic in the tunnel.
option_c: Ensure that dipped headlights are switched on.
option_d: Switch on hazard warning lights to alert other traffic of their presence.
explanation: In general, a driver should switch on their dipped headlights before entering a tunnel.

question_text: What may the hard shoulder of a motorway be used for?
option_a: Stopping to use a mobile phone.
option_b: Exiting the motorway.
option_c: Joining the motorway.
option_d: Stopping in an emergency.
explanation: There are extra dangers when driving on a motorway because of the increased volume of traffic and higher speed. For safety reasons a driver should not drive or stop on the hard shoulder of a motorway except in an emergency or breakdown.

question_text: On a 2-lane motorway, what procedure should a driver adopt when wishing to overtake another vehicle safely?
option_a: Check for following traffic and overtake in either lane.
option_b: Use their mirrors, signal and overtake in the left-hand lane only.
option_c: Use their mirrors, signal and overtake in the right-hand lane when it is safe to do so.
option_d: Signal, use their mirrors and overtake in any available lane when it is safe to do so.
explanation: When a driver wants to overtake on a motorway, they should generally only overtake on the right unless traffic is travelling in slow moving queues. The driver should use the Mirror-Signal-Mirror (blind spots)-Manoeuvre routine. Check mirrors, signal intention, check mirrors again (and blind spots), and complete the manoeuvre when it is safe to do so. They should pay particular attention to the speed of the traffic behind them before they move out. When they have finished overtaking, they should move back into the left-hand lane smoothly.

question_text: What does a 2-plus-1 road have?
option_a: Two lanes of traffic in one direction and one in the opposite direction.
option_b: Two lanes for cars and one lane for trucks and buses.
option_c: Barriers between the hard shoulder and the verge.
option_d: Barriers between lanes of traffic going in the same direction.
explanation: A 2-plus-1 road consists of two lanes in one direction of travel and one lane in the other direction. The two-lane section allows for safe overtaking and alternates with a one-lane section roughly every 2 kilometres.

question_text: When wishing to turn right at the end of a one-way street, where should a driver position their vehicle?
option_a: Drive as close as possible to the left-hand side of the road.
option_b: Drive occupying both lanes when approaching the end of the street.
option_c: Drive in either lane as there is no oncoming traffic
option_d: Drive as close as is possible to the right-hand side of the road.
explanation: When a driver wants to turn right on a one way street, they should check their mirrors, signal right and manoeuvre into the right-hand side when it is safe to do so. Then complete the turn into the appropriate lane of the street they are entering.

question_text: What should a driver do in the event of a breakdown or incident in a tunnel?
option_a: Switch off the engine and switch on the hazard lights.
option_b: Beckon other traffic to overtake.
option_c: Reverse the vehicle if necessary to make room for overtaking traffic.
option_d: Signal the vehicle behind to stop and ask the driver to summon help at the other end of the tunnel.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

question_text: What should a driver do when entering a slip road after leaving a motorway?
option_a: Comply with the speed limit on the road the driver is joining.
option_b: Brake severely when entering the slip road in order to slow down.
option_c: There is never a need to adjust speed when on a slip road.
option_d: Always reduce speed gradually for a few kilometres.
explanation: When a driver is leaving a motorway, they should enter the deceleration lane and reduce their speed. They should comply with the speed limit of the road they are entering.

question_text: In normal driving conditions on a motorway, which lane should the driver occupy?
option_a: Constantly manoeuvre between whichever lane has the least volume of traffic.
option_b: Drive in the nearside (left-hand) lane unless intending to overtake.
option_c: Drive in the offside (right-hand) lane as the nearside (left-hand)lane is for HGVs and buses only.
option_d: Drive in the offside (right-hand) lane unless intending to take a left exit.
explanation: The normal keep left rules apply when you are driving on a motorway - a driver should stay in the nearside (left hand) lane unless they are overtaking.

question_text: What should a driver do when entering a tunnel?
option_a: Always switch off your radio to avoid distractions.
option_b: Keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front.
option_c: Drive closer to the vehicle in front.
option_d: Never drive below the posted speed limit.
explanation: The driver should keep a safe distance from the vehicle in front remembering that they are entering a tunnel and tailgating could create an emergency. The minimum recommended safe distance for a car or motor cycle is 50 metres and is 100 metres for all other vehicles. Always remember the 2 second rule.

question_text: What should a driver do if traffic comes to a halt in a tunnel?
option_a: Switch off the engine.
option_b: Select a low gear and keep the engine running.
option_c: Switch on front and rear fog lights.
option_d: Reverse out of the tunnel.
explanation: If traffic comes to a halt in a tunnel, switch off your engine to prevent a build up of fumes in the tunnel. Stay patient and follow the instructions of the tunnel operators.

question_text: What should a driver do if they drive past their intended exit by mistake?
option_a: Use the emergency telephone to ask for advice.
option_b: Stop on the hard shoulder and reverse back to the exit.
option_c: Carefully complete a U-turn.
option_d: Drive on and leave at the next exit.
explanation: If a driver misses their intended exit when driving on a motorway, they should proceed to the next junction exit where they can leave the motorway and then rejoin it in the opposite direction.

question_text: When driving on a motorway, what should a driver do if they miss their exit?
option_a: Leave the motorway at the next exit and cross to the other side using the fly-over (or underpass)
option_b: Stop on the hard shoulder, switch on their hazard lights and reverse back to the desired exit.
option_c: Wait on the hard shoulder until a suitable gap appears in traffic from both directions and then cross to the opposite side of the motorway.
option_d: Cross to the opposite side of the motorway when there is a suitable gap in the oncoming traffic.
explanation: If a driver misses their intended exit when driving on a motorway, they should proceed to the next junction exit where they can leave the motorway and then rejoin it on the opposite side of the motorway.

question_text: What traffic may use a contra-flow bus lane?
option_a: Buses, taxis and cyclists.
option_b: Buses and motorised wheelchairs only.
option_c: Buses, taxis and motorcycles.
option_d: Buses on a scheduled service.
explanation: A contra-flow bus lane is one that runs in the opposite direction to traffic beside it. Only buses on a scheduled service may use a contra-flow bus lane.

question_text: When driving along a dual carriageway in normal driving conditions, which lane should a driver be in?
option_a: In the right-hand lane.
option_b: In the right-hand lane except when driving a works vehicle or HGV.
option_c: In the left-hand lane unless the driver wishes to overtake or turn right.
option_d: In either lane.
explanation: You must normally drive in the left-hand lane of a dual carriageway, except when overtaking or turning right a short distance ahead.

question_text: Which of the following statements is true in relation to tyre pressure and driving on a motorway?

question_text: Where is black ice likely to occur on the road?

question_text: When driving, what effect could icy roads have on the vehicle?

option_d: The vehicle would be more likely to skid.

question_text: When can a driver expect to encounter black ice?

question_text: What should a driver do after passing through a flooded section of road?
option_a: Apply the handbrake gradually to dry out the rear brakes only.
option_b: Apply the brakes firmly to check if they are still effective.

explanation: When driving through a flooded section of road, brakes may become less effective. If they have been affected, press gently on the brake pedal when driving until they dry out and return to normal.

question_text: Apart from the risk of skidding, what should the driver be aware of when driving in snow?
option_a: The power steering fluid may freeze causing the steering to fail.
option_b: The air in the tyres may freeze, causing them to burst.
option_c: The brake fluid may freeze, causing the brakes to fail.
option_d: Road signs and road markings may become obscured.
explanation: Road signs and road markings may become obscured by snow. If this happens you may have difficulty reading regulatory, warning and information signs. This is the main reason why these signs are different shapes. Drivers should pay particular attention when travelling in these conditions.

question_text: What should a driver be aware of when driving through a section of road where roadworks are ongoing?
option_a: That road workers are always aware of the movement of traffic.
option_b: That the driver always has the right of way over works vehicles.
option_c: Narrower lanes than usual and restricted shoulder areas.
option_d: That the area will be cleared for the driver so that there are no traffic delays.
explanation: When travelling through a section of roadworks, a driver needs to be extra careful, as the road surface area may be considerably reduced. It may be narrower, uneven, slippery or there may be loose chippings which may pose a danger for road workers and other road users.

question_text: What should a driver do when approaching roadworks warning signs?
option_a: Increase speed and move to the centre of the road.
option_b: Engage a higher gear to avoid getting stuck in soft tar.
option_c: Reduce speed and be prepared to stop for works vehicles or a flagman.
option_d: Increase speed until signalled to slow down by a flagman.
explanation: A driver should always approach roadworks with caution as there are many possible hazards to deal with - including road workers, works vehicles, uneven road surfaces and temporary traffic controls.

question_text: A driver has been driving regularly in daylight and must now undertake a journey at night. What should the driver do?
option_a: Drive at a slower speed than in the day as visibility is reduced at night.
option_b: Drive at a higher speed than during the day to minimise the chances of falling asleep.
option_c: Drive at the same speed as during the day as there is no extra danger.
option_d: Drive at a higher speed than during the day as traffic is lighter at night.
explanation: If you are not familiar with driving at night time, it can take quite a while to adjust to conditions. For that reason, you might need to drive slower until you get used to the reduced visibility at night.

question_text: What should a driver do when driving in slippery road conditions?
option_a: Use gentle acceleration and braking.
option_b: Brake regularly to improve tyre grip.
option_c: Drive slower than normal keeping a close distance to the vehicle in front.
option_d: Accelerate harder using only the lower gears.
explanation: Tyres have less grip on the road when it is wet or icy. Slow down in slippery conditions, and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: When driving at night, what is the safest approach for a driver to adopt?
option_a: Drive with full headlights on at all times.

explanation: When driving at night in good driving conditions the dipped headlights of a car will typically let you see 30 metres ahead. So, you should travel at a speed that allows you to stop in that distance.

question_text: With regard to vehicle speed, what should a driver do when driving at night?

question_text: What should a driver do where a section of road ahead has a shallow flooded area?
option_a: Drive in a low gear as slowly as possible keeping the revs high.

question_text: To whom should a driver report aggressive driving?

question_text: What effect does spilt diesel have on a road?

question_text: What should a driver do to minimise fuel consumption in their vehicle?
option_a: Brake hard on approach to traffic lights to stop quickly.
option_b: Drive gently in a low gear.
option_c: Use gentle acceleration and braking.
option_d: Use maximum acceleration between gear changes.
explanation: Driving smoothly will help reduce fuel consumption. Read the road ahead and adjust speed in good time, and avoid harsh acceleration and late braking.

question_text: When driving late at night what should a driver be aware of?

option_c: That trucks may drive in the outside lane of a motorway.

After this they should then get some fresh air and stretch their legs for a few minutes before setting off again. The only cure for fatigue is proper sleep. Never ever drive when tired.

question_text: What lights should a driver have on when driving behind other traffic at night?

question_text: How should a driver negotiate a steep hill or humpbacked bridge when the road is slippery?

explanation: Be extra careful when negotiating steep hills or humpbacked bridges in slippery conditions. Slow down gently on the approach, select the appropriate gear for the speed of the vehicle and use gentle steering and acceleration.

question_text: What is the safest practice when driving on icy roads?
option_a: Drive at a slower speed than usual using gentle acceleration and braking.

explanation: When driving on icy roads a driver should avoid harsh braking, steering and acceleration. This will help reduce the risk of skidding.

question_text: When dazzled by the lights of an oncoming vehicle, what should a driver do?

question_text: What should a driver do when they encounter mud on the road?

question_text: When meeting an oncoming vehicle at night, what should a driver do?

question_text: What should a driver do when involved in an incident where nobody is injured but the vehicles are causing a danger or obstruction on the road?
option_a: Wait for the GardaÌ_ to arrive before moving the vehicles.
option_b: Move all passengers and put a red warning triangle on the road.
option_c: Halt all traffic until it has been established who is at fault.
option_d: Take care when moving damaged vehicles and make every effort to warn other traffic.
explanation: In a collision where nobody is injured and there is only minor damage to vehicles, the vehicles should be moved to the side of the road to ensure that they do not cause an obstruction or endanger other road users.

question_text: If a driver wishes to drive another vehicle which is not currently taxed, would they be allowed to transfer the current tax disc from their own vehicle onto it?
option_a: Under no circumstances should a tax disc be transferred to another vehicle.
option_b: Yes, provided their own vehicle is not being used at the same time.
option_c: Only on a temporary basis if the other vehicle is subject to a lower rate of tax.
option_d: Under circumstances when the proper form has been completed and sent to the local Motor Tax Office.
explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display its own current tax disc before it may be taken on the road. The tax disc includes information about the vehicle, including its make and model, colour and registration number.

question_text: Is it permitted to use a vehicle in a public place without a current tax disc displayed?
option_a: No, only vintage vehicles are exempt from displaying a tax disc.
option_b: Yes, but for not more than 10 days after the expiry of the previous disc.
option_c: Yes, but for not more than one month after the expiry of the previous disc.
option_d: No, all motor vehicles must display a current tax disc.
explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed and must display the up-to-date tax disk before it may be taken on the road.

question_text: When must a current tax disc be displayed on a new vehicle on a public road?
option_a: Only when driving on motorways.
option_b: At all times when the vehicle is on a public road.
option_c: Not later than 10 days after registration.
option_d: Not later than 1 month after registration.
explanation: A motor vehicle must be taxed before it may be taken on the road, and it must always display an up-to-date tax disc.

question_text: If a driver passes their test using a vehicle with automatic transmission, which vehicles are they licensed to drive?
option_a: Only manual vehicles in the licence category.
option_b: Only automatic vehicles in the licence category.
option_c: All vehicles in the licence category.
option_d: All vehicles in the licence category but only automatic vehicles on a motorway.
explanation: If you pass your driving test in an automatic or adapted vehicle, your full licence will apply to that type of vehicle only. A licence restricted to automatic vehicles will have a code 78 indicated in the restrictions/information column of the licence.

question_text: If a vehicle is being driven by someone who is not the owner but has the owner''s consent, who should ensure that the driver is properly insured?
option_a: The driver only.
option_b: The driver and the vehicle owner.
option_c: The vehicle owner only.
option_d: The insurance company.
explanation: All drivers must have insurance covering them to drive a vehicle on a public road. It is a serious offence to drive a vehicle that is not insured. It is also an offence to allow a vehicle that you own to be driven by an uninsured driver.

question_text: How should an L-plate be composed?
option_a: A red L on a transparent background.
option_b: A white L on a red background.
option_c: A red L on a white background.
option_d: A green L on a white background.
explanation: L-plates should be displayed front and rear. The plates should be a red L on a white background and should be not less than 15 cm high with a border of at least 2 cm. A learner motorcyclist must wear a yellow tabard displaying L-plates front and rear. The L-plates must be not less than 15 cm high on a white background.

question_text: Who is entitled to see a driver's vehicle registration document?
option_a: Any person with whom the driver is involved in a collision.
option_b: A member of the car recovery company or anyone assisting in the recovery.
option_c: A Garda may ask you to produce the vehicles registration document at a named Garda station.
option_d: Any fire brigade or ambulance personnel at the scene of a collision the driver has been involved in.
explanation: A Garda may demand to see your driving licence at any time, and you should always carry this with you when driving. A Garda may also examine your insurance disc, tax disc and NCT disc (if applicable). A Garda may ask you to produce other documents (including the vehicles registration document) at a named Garda station within 10 days.

question_text: When a vehicle is being driven by a person who is not the owner, who is responsible for ensuring that the vehicle is taxed and that a current tax disc is displayed?
option_a: The driver is the only one responsible.
option_b: The driver and/or the owner of the vehicle are responsible.
option_c: The owner is the only one responsible.
option_d: The GardaÌ_ have total responsibility in this area.
explanation: If you are the owner or the driver of a vehicle, you must ensure that it is taxed and that it displays an up-to-date tax disc before you take it on the road.

question_text: Where can drivers locate the Maximum Authorised Mass (MAM) of their vehicle?
option_a: On the NCT disc.
option_b: On the insurance disc.
option_c: On the tax disc.
option_d: On a metal plate on the vehicle.
explanation: The plate displaying the maximum Authorised Mass (MAM) of a vehicle is normally located under the bonnet or in the passenger compartment. If you are not sure where it is located on your vehicle, check the drivers handbook supplied with the vehicle.

question_text: When a driver wishes to drive a vehicle and they are not sure if they are covered by insurance, what should they do?
option_a: They should not drive until their insurance company confirms that they are insured.
option_b: They should check with their local NDLS office to see if they are insured.
option_c: They should check with their local Motor Taxation Office to see if they are insured.
option_d: They should check with their local Garda Station to see if they are insured.
explanation: If you are in any doubt about your insurance cover, you should discuss the matter with your insurance company. It is a serious offence to drive without insurance.

question_text: Which roads are learner permit holders not allowed to drive on?
option_a: They may not drive on rural roads.
option_b: They may not drive on dual carriageways.
option_c: They may not drive on motorways.
option_d: They may not drive on national roads.
explanation: A learner permit holder must not drive on a motorway. It is a serious offence to do so.

question_text: If a driver wishes to drive another privately-owned vehicle but they are uncertain if they are insured to drive that vehicle, what should they do?
option_a: Transfer the insurance disc from their own vehicle on to the vehicle they wish to drive.
option_b: Drive it provided that they tell their insurance company within 10 days and agree to pay any additional premium.
option_c: Drive if there is an insurance disc on the vehicle.
option_d: A driver should contact their own insurer to confirm whether or not their insurance policy covers the driving of other vehicles.
explanation: If you are in any doubt about your insurance cover, you should discuss the matter with your insurance company. It is a serious offence to drive without insurance.

question_text: What should a driver who wishes to perform a U-turn do?
option_a: Check behind for approaching traffic and signal them to stop.
option_b: Check that the road is not one way.
option_c: Check ahead for approaching traffic and signal them to stop.
option_d: Only perform a U-turn outside the urban speed limit area.
explanation: If you want to do a U-turn you must first choose a place where it is safe and legal to do it. Check all around for other road users and do not impede their right of way. Complete the manoeuvre efficiently and safely.

question_text: What should a driver who wishes to perform a turnabout do?
option_a: Drive into somebody's driveway and reverse back onto the road.
option_b: Check ahead and behind for oncoming traffic and turn briskly while still keeping a look out.
option_c: Drive onto a footpath if necessary in order to ensure that they have sufficient room to turn.
option_d: It is not permissible to perform a turnabout in any circumstance.
explanation: If you want to do a turnabout, you must first choose a place where it is safe and legal to do so. Check all around for other road users and do not impede their right of way. Complete the manoeuvre efficiently and safely.

question_text: When should a driver use the vehicle's rear view mirror?
option_a: Before switching on the rear demister.
option_b: Before moving off only.
option_c: Before reversing only.
option_d: Before changing direction.
explanation: You should use your mirrors to stay aware of traffic situations behind and around you. Always check your mirror before you change direction on a road, and before you signal or begin a manoeuvre.

question_text: What should a driver do when driving on a wide road behind a vehicle that has signalled to turn right ahead?
option_a: Overtake on the left-hand side and carry on if safe to do so.
option_b: Stay behind and tap the brakes to signal other drivers to slow down.
option_c: Overtake on the right-hand side and carry on.
option_d: Overtake on the left, but only if turning left a short distance ahead.
explanation: You may overtake on the left when the driver in front has moved out and signalled their intent to turn right and you intend to go straight ahead - provided there is enough room to do so safely and your path will not be obstructed by the swing of a large vehicle turning right.

question_text: How should a driver proceed if their view is obstructed at a junction?
option_a: Sound the horn several times and proceed.
option_b: Move out slowly onto the road while watching carefully for other traffic.
option_c: Flash headlights on and off before moving out.
option_d: Ask a passer-by for guidance onto the other road.
explanation: At junctions where the view is obstructed, move carefully into a position where you can see without interfering with other road users. Then assess the situation before you continue.

question_text: How does rain affect driving in this situation?
option_a: It increases visibility.
option_b: It increases tyre grip on the road.
option_c: It reduces the danger of skidding.
option_d: It increases the danger of skidding.
explanation: When it is wet, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as when it is dry, your stopping distance is increased and you are more likely to skid. For these reasons you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: When is it permissible to overtake another vehicle on the nearside (left-hand side)?
option_a: When there are three lanes available in fast moving traffic.
option_b: Only when there is no cycle lane.
option_c: When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn right.
option_d: A driver must never overtake on the left.
explanation: You may overtake on the left when the driver in front has moved out and signalled their intent to turn right and you intend to go straight ahead - provided there is enough room to do so safely and your path will not be obstructed by the swing of a large vehicle turning right.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Entry to motorway.
option_b: Low bridge ahead.
option_c: End of motorway.
option_d: Toll bridge ahead.
explanation: This is a motorway information sign informing road users they are now entering the motorway and must obey motorway rules. This sign usually appears beside a motorway ahead sign.

question_text: When a driver is at a junction where visibility is extremely limited, what should the driver do?
option_a: Seek help from a passer-by.
option_b: Move out with extreme care, watching carefully to the left and right.
option_c: Drive the front of the vehicle out onto the road to enable other drivers to see you.
option_d: Sound the horn and quickly proceed.
explanation: Where your view is obstructed at a junction, you should move carefully into a position where you can see, but without interfering with other road users. You should then assess the situation before you continue.

question_text: What effect does patches of oil or diesel have on a road surface?
option_a: It improves the vehicle's braking ability.
option_b: It increases tyre surface noise.
option_c: It improves tyre surface grip.
option_d: It reduces the tyre surface grip.
explanation: A patch of oil or diesel on the road can seriously reduce the grip of your tyres on the road, which may result in a possible skid.

question_text: What should a driver do when travelling downhill on snow or ice?
option_a: Avoid using the brake and use a high gear.
option_b: Keep close to the left and brake sharply to reduce speed.
option_c: Select an appropriate gear and brake gently to control speed.
option_d: Use a higher gear than normal in order to avoid wheel spin.
explanation: When travelling downhill in snow or ice, you should select a lower gear to take advantage of engine braking and use the brakes very gently when you need to.

question_text: What effect does a wet road surface have on a vehicle's braking ability?
option_a: It makes no difference to the required braking distance.
option_b: Modern tyres provide grip on a wet road as effectively as on a dry road.
option_c: It reduces the braking distance of that required on a dry surface.
option_d: Generally, it doubles the braking distance of that required on a dry surface.
explanation: When it is wet, your tyres do not grip the road surface as well as when it is dry and your stopping distance is increased. For these reasons you should slow down during or after rain and keep a greater distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: Why does it take longer to stop the vehicle on a wet road?
option_a: The brake fluid is less effective in wet weather.
option_b: The tyres have more grip than in dry weather.
option_c: The tyres have less road grip than in dry weather.
option_d: The suspension of the vehicle is lighter in wet weather.
explanation: When driving on wet road surfaces the grip of your tyres is reduced which may lead to significantly longer stopping distances. Drivers should be aware of these conditions and reduce speed as stopping quickly may result in skidding.

question_text: After overtaking another vehicle, what should a driver do?
option_a: Move back in front of the vehicle and reduce speed.
option_b: Gradually move back into the left when the vehicle has been passed.
option_c: Continue to signal right for a distance.
option_d: Move immediately into the left after passing the vehicle.
explanation: After overtaking, check your mirrors, signal and return to your normal lane position as soon as it is safe. Take a smooth easy line, gradually moving back in and allowing the other vehicle plenty of space and don''t cut in sharply.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Series of bends ahead.
option_b: Steep hill ahead.
option_c: Road narrows from right.
option_d: Slippery road ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of the potential danger of slippery road surfaces ahead.

option_a: Only a fool breaks the three second rule.

question_text: What should a driver do when overtaking parked vehicles in a residential area?
option_a: Allow sufficient clearance when passing.
option_b: Move as far to the right as possible.
option_c: Increase speed to overtake the vehicles as quickly as possible.
option_d: Keep close to the parked vehicles allowing maximum room for oncoming traffic.
explanation: When you are passing parked vehicles in a residential area, move into a safe overtaking position in good time and leave plenty of clearance between your vehicle and the parked vehicles to increase visibility of small children in the area and in case someone opens their car door in front of you.

question_text: What should a driver do when driving in slippery road conditions?
option_a: Apply the brakes sharply from time to time to test the road surface.
option_b: Drive at normal speed but allow extra stopping distance.
option_c: Maintain a normal distance from the vehicle in front.
option_d: Drive at lower speeds and use gentle acceleration and braking.
explanation: When driving in slippery road conditions, drivers should be particularly smooth and gradual in the way they accelerate and brake. This will help to avoid skidding or slipping and helps to maintain control of the vehicle.

question_text: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 50 km/h on a dry road?
option_a: 15 metres.
option_b: 55 metres.
option_c: 25 metres.
option_d: 5 metres.
explanation: The total minimum stopping distance of a vehicle depends on four things; perception time, reaction time, the vehicles reaction time and the vehicle braking capability. The recommend minimum stopping distance of a car driving at 50 km/h under dry conditions is 25 metres.

question_text: What should a driver do if they encounter loose chippings on a road?
option_a: A driver should press their hand against the windscreen.
option_b: Slow down and allow extra clearance to other traffic.
option_c: Stop the vehicle until the loose chippings can be removed.
option_d: Increase speed so as to avoid causing damage to the vehicle.
explanation: Where there are loose chippings on the road, you should slow down and comply with any reduced speed limit and leave extra room (or clearance) between your vehicle and other traffic. This will also give you more time to stop if you need to, and it will help to reduce the amount of chippings your vehicle throws up against other vehicles and possible injury to pedestrians.

question_text: Which of the following affects the braking distance of a vehicle?
option_a: The speed and weight of the vehicle.
option_b: The use of unleaded fuel.
option_c: The power of the engine.
option_d: The brake-pad clearance.
explanation: The overall stopping distance of your vehicle depends on its speed and weight - faster and heavier vehicles require greater stopping distances.

question_text: In wet weather how might a driver judge what is a safe following distance from the vehicle in front?
option_a: By allowing at least four seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and the driver's own vehicle passing a fixed point.
option_b: By allowing two vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
option_c: By allowing four vehicle lengths between the vehicles.
option_d: By allowing at least two seconds to elapse between the vehicle in front and the driver's own vehicle passing a fixed point.
explanation: In wet conditions you should maintain a gap of at least four seconds from the vehicle in front - at least twice as long as in dry conditions.

question_text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum permissible speed for cars or motorcycles on national roads?
option_b: 80 km/h.
option_d: 60 km/h.
explanation: It is illegal to exceed 100 km/h when driving on a single carriageway national road.

question_text: What would happen if a driver cuts in too soon when overtaking another vehicle?
option_a: It would force the other vehicle to suddenly slow or change direction causing danger.
option_b: It will force oncoming vehicles to suddenly slow causing danger.
option_c: The driver would not need to indicate when moving in.
option_d: The safety gap between the vehicles increases.
explanation: When overtaking make sure the road ahead is clear so you have enough distance to overtake and get back to your own side of the road without forcing any other road user to adjust speed or direction. When you are well past the vehicle, check the mirrors, signal and gradually return to the original lane, making sure not to cut across the vehicle you have passed.

question_text: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 100 km/h on a dry road?
option_a: 30 metres.
option_b: 120 metres.
option_c: 70 metres.
option_d: 90 metres.
explanation: The total minimum stopping distance of a vehicle depends on four things; perception time, reaction time, the vehicles reaction time and the vehicle braking capability. The recommend minimum stopping distance of a car driving at 100 km/h under dry conditions is 70 metres.

question_text: What effect does carrying a load have on a vehicle's braking ability?
option_a: It has no effect provided the brakes are good.
option_b: It increases the distance required to stop.
option_c: It reduces the distance required to stop.
option_d: It increases the efficiency of the brakes.
explanation: When driving a vehicle which is carrying a load, the driver should be aware that the forces acting on the vehicle will increase the distance required to stop. The driver should allow for this by increasing the distance from the vehicle in front.

explanation: A driver can judge a safe distance from the vehicle in front by using the two second rule. This is measured by picking a fixed point. question_text: What is the effect on the control of the vehicle if there is a film of water between the vehicle's tyres and the road surface?
option_a: Braking only will be less effective.
option_b: Steering will be more effective.
option_c: Steering and braking will be less effective.
option_d: Steering and braking will be more effective.
explanation: When driving on a road where there is a lot of surface water, a film of water can build up between the tyres and the road surface. When this occurs it is called aquaplaning, it reduces the grip of the tyres on the road and can result in the total loss of control over the vehicles steering and braking.

question_text: What lights should a driver use when driving in dense fog?
option_a: Drive with dipped headlights and fog lights.
option_b: Drive with full headlights and fog lights.
option_c: Drive with sidelights and hazard warning lights.
option_d: Drive with sidelights and fog lights.
explanation: In dense fog you should use dipped headlights and fog lights (where fitted). Sidelights are not strong enough in fog, and full headlights can reflect off the fog and make it harder to see where you are going.

question_text: How does driving at high speed affect a vehicle's road holding?
option_a: The wheel alignment keeps the tyres in full contact with the road.
option_b: The road holding ability of the vehicle is reduced.
option_c: The road holding ability of the vehicle is increased.
option_d: The suspension compensates for any unevenness in the road surface.
explanation: Driving at high speed is a factor that affects road holding. At higher speeds the airflow under a vehicle reduces tyre grip on the road and when you are approaching a bend or corner, the momentum of the vehicle makes it more difficult to change direction.

question_text: What effect does towing a loaded trailer have on stopping ability?
option_a: It increases the stopping distance.
option_b: It has no effect on stopping distance.
option_c: It increases the efficiency of the brakes.
option_d: It reduces the stopping distance.
explanation: If you are towing a loaded trailer, you need to be aware that your braking distance could be considerably greater, depending on the weight and size of the trailer. The driver should allow for this by increasing the distance from the vehicle in front.

question_text: What is the recommended minimum stopping distance for a car travelling at 50 km/h on a wet road?
option_a: 16 metres.
option_b: 56 metres.
option_c: 36 metres.
option_d: 76 metres.
explanation: The total minimum stopping distance of a vehicle depends on four things; perception time, reaction time, the vehicles reaction time and the vehicle braking capability. The recommend minimum stopping distance of a car driving at 50 km/h under wet conditions is 36 metres.

question_text: What clearance should drivers normally allow for when passing parked vehicles?
option_a: A car width.
option_b: The width of a side mirror.
option_c: The width of an average person.
option_d: A door width.
explanation: When you are passing parked vehicles, you should leave at least a door''s width of clearance in case somebody opens their car door unexpectedly, this will also increase visibility of pedestrians in the area.

question_text: What should a driver do when driving in dense fog?
option_a: Reduce speed and use full headlights.
option_b: Drive along the hard shoulder and watch for the reflective markers.
option_c: Drive along the central dividing line and watch for the reflective markings.
option_d: Reduce speed and use dipped headlights.
explanation: In dense fog you should reduce your speed and use dipped headlights and fog lights (where fitted). Sidelights are not strong enough in fog, and full headlights can reflect off the fog and make it harder to see where you are going.

question_text: What is a likely consequence of sudden braking?
option_a: There will be no consequences as the vehicle's brake lights will come on.
option_b: The vehicle could be overtaken.
option_c: The vehicle could be hit from behind.
option_d: The vehicle's braking system could overheat.
explanation: As well as reading the road ahead, you should also be aware of traffic travelling behind you. This will help you react correctly in a situation where you need to brake suddenly.

question_text: What stopping distance should a driver allow for when driving in snow or icy conditions?
option_a: Twice the normal distance.
option_b: Up to ten times the normal distance.
option_c: Up to half the normal distance.
option_d: The normal distance.
explanation: When driving in snow or icy conditions a driver should allow a greater distance from the vehicle in front as stopping distances can be increased by up to ten times the normal.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Maximum speed is is 30 km/h.
option_b: Motorway continues for 30 kilometres.
option_c: Parking not allowed for more than 30 minutes.
option_d: Minimum speed is 30 km/h.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 30 km/h. These signs are commonly found in slow zones in residential areas.

question_text: If driving from A to B, what do these road markings mean?
option_a: A driver may not overtake.
option_b: Road narrows ahead.
option_c: A driver may overtake if it is safe to do so.
option_d: Dual carriageway ahead.
explanation: Where there is a broken white line and a continuous white line along the centre of the road, you must obey the line that is nearest to you. In this case you may cross the lines as long as it is safe to do so.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Temporary road surface ahead.
option_b: Railway crossing ahead.
option_c: School children crossing ahead.
option_d: Temporary traffic signals ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that temporary traffic signals are in use ahead. You should prepare to slow down, approach with caution and comply with the signal displayed.

question_text: What lights should a vehicle show at dusk?
option_a: Full headlights.
option_b: Dipped headlights.
option_c: Daytime Running Lights (DRLs) only.
option_d: Fog lights.
explanation: Drivers need to see and be seen during all periods of low light levels - for example, at dusk and dawn and in some bad weather conditions. At times of low light, you should turn on dipped headlights. The Road Safety Authority recommends that motorcyclists and drivers turn on their dipped headlights or daytime running lights during daylight hours.

question_text: What does the broken yellow line road marking mean?
option_a: Slow lane for heavy vehicles only.
option_b: No stopping for any reason except in an emergency.
option_c: The edge of the carriageway or hard shoulder.
option_d: Parking prohibited at all times.
explanation: A single broken yellow line along the side of the road marks the edge of the carriageway/hard shoulder. This is normally for the use of pedestrians and cyclists. As a driver, however, you may use it briefly to allow faster traffic to overtake, but only where it is safe to do so.

question_text: When is parking permitted on a footpath?
option_a: When no more than half of the vehicle is on the footpath.
option_b: When at least half of the footpath remains free for pedestrians.
option_c: It is never permitted to park on a footpath.
option_d: When cars are parked on both sides of the road.
explanation: It is an offence to park on a footpath. Where a vehicle is parked on a footpath, pedestrians may have to step onto the road to go around the vehicle and so place themselves in danger.

question_text: What does this Garda signal mean?
option_a: Traffic approaching from the front may proceed.
option_b: Traffic approaching from the right may proceed.
option_c: Traffic approaching from behind must stop.
option_d: Traffic approaching from the front must stop.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you may proceed.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Minor road ahead.
option_b: Y-Junction ahead with roads of lesser importance.
option_c: Y-junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
option_d: Junction ahead with dual carriageway.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a Y-junction ahead with roads of equal importance. Approach such a junction with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

question_text: What lights indicate a zebra crossing?
option_a: Continuously lit red beacons.
option_b: Flashing red beacons.
option_c: Flashing amber beacons.
option_d: Continuously lit amber beacons.
explanation: A zebra crossing is indicated by amber flashing beacons on poles and black and white stripes on the road. You must stop for pedestrians on the crossing and for those about to cross.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: No stopping, except in offside lane.
option_b: Corner ahead on offside lane.
option_c: Offside lane closed ahead.
option_d: End of dual carriageway.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that that the offside (right hand) lane of three is closed ahead. Drivers in the nearside or centre lanes should be aware that traffic may merge from the right.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: One-way traffic to the left ahead.
option_b: Sharp corner to the left ahead.
option_c: Diversion to the left ahead.
option_d: Turn left ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn left ahead. It is usually displayed on the approach to a one-way system.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Restricted weight limit for road segment indicated
option_b: Restricted road width ahead.
option_c: Low bridge up ahead.
option_d: Road narrows ahead - maximum length of vehicle is indicated.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that you are approaching a low bridge, with restricted headroom as shown on the sign.

question_text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
option_a: Service station ahead.
option_b: Toll collector operating lane.
option_c: Garda checkpoint to the left.
option_d: This lane closed - keep left.
explanation: This sign is used at toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge may be paid directly to a cashier. This lane would normally be used by motorists who have neither the exact change nor an electronic tag on their vehicle.

question_text: What does this sign mean?

option_b: School crossing ahead.
option_c: Automatic level crossing ahead.
option_d: Animals crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of an automatic level crossing ahead. Drivers should approach with caution and be prepared to slow down or stop as necessary.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Minimum permitted weight is 3 tonnes.

option_c: 3-axled vehicles are not permitted.
option_d: Only 3-axled vehicles are permitted.
explanation: This sign tells you that that you must not enter this area if your vehicle is over 3 tonnes or 3,000 kg

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: End of major roadworks ahead.
option_b: Major roadworks ahead.
option_c: Level crossing ahead guarded by gates or barriers.
option_d: Level crossing ahead unguarded by gates or barriers.
explanation: This sign gives advanced warning of an unguarded level crossing ahead. This is a crossing without gates or barriers and you should cross it with extreme caution.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Cattle grid ahead.
option_b: Possibility of cattle or farm animals ahead.
option_c: Livestock mart ahead.
option_d: Veterinary surgery ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be cattle or other farm animals on the road ahead. Slow down if required and be prepared to stop.

question_text: What does this road marking mean?

option_b: A driver may overtake.
option_c: Road narrows ahead.
option_d: A driver is approaching a Stop sign.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Possibility of low flying aircraft.
option_b: Aircraft museum ahead.
option_c: Direction of prevailing wind.
option_d: Airport ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be low-flying aircraft in the area. Low-flying aircraft can cause distraction due to a sudden loud noise.

question_text: What does this Garda signal mean?
option_a: The Garda is beckoning on traffic approaching from either side.
option_b: The Garda is beckoning on traffic from the front.
option_c: The driver must not proceed to the left.
option_d: The driver must not proceed to the right
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you may proceed.

question_text: What does this sign mean?

question_text: What does this sign mean?

question_text: If a driver suspects that their vehicle indicators have not been seen, what should the driver do?
option_a: Shout your intentions out of the window.
option_b: Use a clear, decisive hand signal as well.
option_c: The driver's position on the road is a sufficient enough signal.
option_d: It is unnecessary to give signals provided observation is taken.
explanation: If the driver is concerned that for whatever reason the indicators are not giving an adequate signal, they should use clear decisive hand signals as well to advise other road users of their intention.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Cyclists must dismount ahead.
option_b: Track reserved for motorcyclist.
option_c: Start of cycle track.
option_d: Bicycle race track.
explanation: This sign indicates the start of a cycle track. If the track is bounded by a broken white line, other road users should avoid using it wherever possible. If it is bounded by a continuous white line, drivers of cars and other vehicles must not drive on it.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: End of dual carriageway.
option_b: Dual carriageway ahead.
option_c: Road narrows on both sides.
option_d: Tunnel ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road is narrowing on both sides ahead. You should show caution and prepare to slow down.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Traffic signals ahead.
option_b: School children crossing ahead.
option_c: Stop at zebra crossing.
option_d: Railway level crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a traffic light controlled junction ahead. This sign is generally found in areas where the lights may not be visible to drivers in good time - for example, following a bend in the road.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Unguarded level crossing ahead.
option_b: Crossroads with dual carriageway ahead.
option_c: T-junction with crossroads ahead.
option_d: Level crossing ahead guarded by gates.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a crossroads junction at a dual carriageway ahead. Drivers need to be observant, taking extra care for traffic coming from each direction. Yield and/or stop as appropriate.

question_text: If driving from A to B, what do these road markings mean?
option_a: Only motorcyclists may cross the lines to overtake
option_b: A driver may cross the lines to overtake.
option_c: Oncoming traffic may not cross the lines to overtake.
option_d: A driver may not cross the lines to overtake.
explanation: Where there is a broken white line and a continuous white line along the centre of the road, you must obey the line that is nearest to you. In this case you may not cross the lines.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Racecourse ahead.
option_b: Entrance to horse riding school.
option_c: Riding path - no vehicles allowed.
option_d: Accompanied horses and ponies ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be horses on the road ahead. You should show due regard for horses and their riders.

question_text: What distance before a zebra crossing is parking prohibited?
option_a: 15 metres.
option_b: 10 metres.
option_c: 20 metres.
option_d: 5 metres.
explanation: It is an offence to park 15 metres before or 5 metres after a pedestrian crossing. Parking in this manner may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the crossing and endanger pedestrians.

question_text: At roadworks, what does this sign mean?
option_a: Proceed with caution.
option_b: Proceed with hazard warning lights on.
option_c: Proceed using hand signals only.
option_d: Proceed only when beckoned to do so.
explanation: This traffic control sign tells you that you may proceed with caution through road works.

question_text: Apart from cyclists and motorised wheelchairs, what other road users may use an unoccupied cycle lane accompanied by a broken white line?
option_a: Only hackneys and taxis.
option_b: All drivers may make temporary use.
option_c: Only buses and taxis.
option_d: Only moped riders and motorcyclists.
explanation: Drivers may make temporary use of a cycle track with a broken white line on the right hand side if it is not occupied.

question_text: What does this sign mean?

option_d: Railway crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a Y-junction ahead with a road of equal importance. Approach such a junction with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

question_text: What does this sign mean?

option_c: Parking without a disc is allowed during the hours shown.
option_d: Parking is prohibited during the hours shown.
explanation: This sign tells you that vehicles must display a parking disc when parked during the hours shown on the information plate.

question_text: What does this sign mean at a roundabout?
option_a: Yield to traffic coming from the left.

option_c: Yield to cyclists and motorcyclists only.
option_d: Yield to traffic coming from the right, or already on the roundabout.
explanation: At a roundabout, the YIELD sign tells you that you must slow down and be prepared to stop. You must yield (give way) to traffic already on the roundabout or coming from the right.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Only taxis may turn right or left.
option_b: Private vehicles may pick up or set down passengers.
option_c: Designated rank for taxis.
option_d: Private parking is permitted when the taxi rank is empty.
explanation: A Taxi Rank sign indicates that this is an area reserved for taxis, and parking or stopping by other road users is not permitted.

question_text: What does this sign mean?

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?

option_d: The cyclist intends to slow down.
explanation: This hand signal tells other road users that the cyclist intends to either move out or make a right hand turn. Drivers should be aware that cyclists could cross the path of their vehicle.

question_text: What must a driver do when this sign is accompanied by a white stop line on the road?
option_a: Stop at the line.
option_b: Stop only if there is traffic on the major road.
option_c: Stop past the line.
option_d: Stop no more than one car length past the line.
explanation: When accompanied by a STOP sign, the white stop line indicates the point at which you must stop your vehicle.

question_text: What does this sign mean at a junction?
option_a: Yield to traffic on the major road.

option_c: Yield to traffic coming from your right only.
option_d: Yield to all heavy goods vehicles.
explanation: At a junction, the YIELD sign tells you that you must give way to traffic on a major road ahead. This means that you must slow down and be prepared to stop.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Turn right ahead.

explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 50 km/h.

question_text: When may you pass another vehicle on the left-hand side?
option_a: When a driver cannot pass on the right-hand side because of oncoming traffic.
option_b: A driver must never overtake on the left.
option_c: When there is sufficient space to do so.
option_d: When the vehicle in front is signalling to turn right or in slow moving lanes of traffic.
explanation: Normally you must overtake on the right. There are, however, circumstances where you may overtake on the left - for example, when the vehicle has moved out and signalled to turn right.

question_text: When should pedestrians wear reflective clothing at night?
option_a: When walking two abreast.
option_b: When in urban areas.
option_c: Only when it is raining.
option_d: At night, when walking outside built-up areas.
explanation: Outside built-up areas, pedestrians should wear reflective clothing at all times when walking at night. This is particularly important where there is no street lighting and no footpath for pedestrians.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: No overtaking ahead.
option_b: Parking not allowed ahead.
option_c: No entry ahead.
option_d: Cul-de-sac ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must not proceed in the direction of the arrow. This is displayed to prevent traffic going in the wrong direction - for example, the wrong way up a one-way street.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Traffic merging from the left.
option_b: End of dual carriageway ahead.
option_c: Traffic merging from the right.
option_d: Traffic from the left has priority.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of traffic merging from the left. You should expect vehicles to join from the left. You may need to slow down, allowing them to merge safely.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Level crossing ahead unprotected by lights and barriers.
option_b: Railway bridge ahead.
option_c: Level crossing ahead protected by lights and barriers.
option_d: Railway station ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a railway level crossing ahead protected by lights and barriers. The crossing may also have an audible warning alarm. You should be prepared to stop.

question_text: At a railway level crossing with unattended gates, what should a car driver do?
option_a: Telephone the nearest railway station before opening a gate.
option_b: Open both gates and after passing the first, stop and close it.
option_c: Open both gates before proceeding to cross.
option_d: Drive half way across and close the first gate before opening the second.
explanation: At a level crossing with unattended gates a driver must stop, look for trains and listen for the sound of a horn or approaching trains. If it is safe, open both gates, complete the crossing and then close both gates.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Dangerous corner ahead.
option_b: Turn left.
option_c: No turn left.
option_d: Dangerous bend ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a dangerous bend to the left. You may need to slow down and react to any changes in the traffic situation ahead.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Soft margin on left.
option_b: Slippery surface.
option_c: Uneven surface.
option_d: Parking on left only.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road surface may be uneven, possibly due to the resurfacing of part of a lane. Proceed with caution.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Sharp depression or dip ahead.
option_b: Road damaged ahead.
option_c: Road flooded ahead.
option_d: Road divides ahead - pass on the left or right.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a dip or depression in the road ahead which may be hidden and could obscure your view of oncoming traffic. You should reduce your speed accordingly and be aware that overtaking is dangerous in these areas.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Slippery road.
option_b: Steep hill ahead.
option_c: Road narrows from the right.
option_d: Series of bends ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the surface ahead is slippery due to mud or debris and there is an increased risk of skidding.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Uneven surface ahead.
option_b: Series of steep hills ahead.
option_c: Pipe laying ahead.
option_d: Industrial estate ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the surface ahead is uneven and you should approach with caution.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Crossroads ahead with roads of lesser importance.
option_b: Railway crossing ahead.
option_c: Major road ahead.
option_d: Crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a crossroad junction ahead where the roads are of equal importance. At this type of junction you should yield to traffic approaching from the right and traffic already turning.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Radio transmission mast ahead.
option_b: Crosswinds ahead.
option_c: Sharp corners ahead.
option_d: Overhead electric cables.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of electric cables overhead. Drivers with a high load should be particularly careful.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The driver intends to turn right.

option_d: The driver intends to go straight ahead.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to turn left and the vehicle will change direction.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The driver intends to move out or turn right.

option_d: The driver intends to turn left.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to move out or turn right and the vehicle will change direction.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: No hunting ahead.

option_c: Deer or wild animals ahead.
option_d: Wildlife reserve - no stopping.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be deer or other wild animals coming onto the roadway. Be prepared to slow down or stop suddenly if required.

question_text: When should a driver use dipped headlights?
option_a: When visibility is less than 300 metres.
option_b: When visibility is less than 200 metres.
option_c: From 00:00 hrs to 06:00 hrs.
option_d: From just after dusk to just before dawn.
explanation: Lighting up hours are defined as the period of time during which drivers should turn on dipped headlights in order to be seen. This period normally starts half an hour after sunset and ends half an hour before sunrise.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Vehicle broken down ahead on right.

option_c: Loose chippings on road.
option_d: Uneven surface on left.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the road ahead has been resurfaced and there may be loose chippings. You should reduce speed while driving through this area as the loose chippings could affect your vehicles road holding and braking.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Low bridge 500 metres ahead.
option_b: Motorway ends 500 metres ahead.
option_c: Bridge repair 500 metres ahead.
option_d: No overtaking for 500 metres.
explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the motorway will end in 500 metres ahead. Motorway rules will no longer apply, for example a lower speed limit may be applicable.

question_text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a caravan on national roads?
option_a: 80 km/h.
option_d: 60 km/h.
explanation: When towing a caravan on a national road, it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h - excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Bus and tram lane on left.
option_b: Tram lane on left.
option_c: No parking inside the white line.
option_d: Trams emerging from left.
explanation: This sign tells you there is a tram lane on the left. Be aware that there might be pedestrians in the area and crossing the road.

question_text: What is the purpose of traffic calming measures?
option_a: To prioritise heavy goods traffic.
option_b: To alert drivers to road flooding ahead.
option_c: To slow down traffic in the vicinity.
option_d: To inform the driver of an increased speed limit ahead.
explanation: The purpose of traffic calming measures is to slow down fast-moving traffic to a speed more suitable for the area they are entering. These measures are usually found in rural areas on the entry points to towns or villages.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The driver intends to proceed straight ahead.
option_b: The driver intends to slow down or stop.
option_c: The driver intends to turn left.
option_d: The driver intends to reverse.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a Garda directing traffic that the driver intends to proceed straight ahead.

question_text: When is double parking permitted?
option_a: When there are double white lines.
option_b: When there are double yellow lines.
option_c: It is never permitted.
option_d: When there is a hard shoulder.
explanation: Double parking is never permitted. Parking is never permitted where it might interfere in any way with the normal flow of traffic or obstruct or endanger other road users.

option_d: Flagman ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the traffic flow ahead is controlled manually by a flagman. Be aware and follow directions given by the flagman.

option_d: Speed control ramp.

option_a: Traffic must not enter unless they can clear the box junction without stopping, or when turning right.

option_c: Taxi set-down area.
option_d: Traffic entering a box junction from right and left has the right of way unless continuing straight on.
explanation: You must not enter the yellow box junction unless you can clear it without stopping or unless you are turning right and are prevented from doing so by oncoming traffic.

question_text: In general, above what gross vehicle weight must a trailer have brakes fitted?
option_a: 850 kg
option_b: 750 kg
option_c: 900 kg
option_d: 500 kg
explanation: Brakes must be fitted to a trailer if its gross vehicle weight exceeds either 750 kg or half the weight of the towing vehicle.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Entry to tunnel prohibited.

option_c: U-turn not permitted.
option_d: Two-way traffic prohibited.
explanation: This sign tells you that you are not permitted to make a U-turn. It is commonly displayed on approach to junctions on dual carriageways. Drivers should also be aware that U-turns are also not permitted anywhere there is a continuous white line along the centre of the road or on a one-way street.

question_text: At roadworks, what does this sign mean?
option_a: Stop only if faced by oncoming traffic.
option_b: Proceed if road ahead is clear.
option_c: Stop for school warden.
option_d: Stop before or at the sign.
explanation: This traffic control sign at roadworks means you must stop.

option_d: Tunnel ahead.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Only buses, cyclists and taxis are allowed to use the lane ahead during the hours indicated.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: No right turn.
