option_c: Cul-de-sac to the right.
option_d: Turn right if there is no oncoming traffic.
explanation: This sign is displayed at a junction where you may not turn right.

question_text: What do temporary traffic lights at road works mean?
option_a: A driver must comply with the lights when workers are on site only.
option_b: A driver need not comply if a convoy of traffic is going in the same direction.
option_c: A driver need only comply when there is oncoming traffic.
option_d: A driver must comply with the lights at all times.
explanation: You must comply with any temporary traffic lights used to control vehicle movements at or near road works. It is an offence not to obey these lights.

question_text: Where is a driver allowed to park?
option_a: On a footpath.
option_b: Where the driver is not blocking other road users their view of traffic signals or the road ahead.
option_c: At road works.
option_d: Where there is a continuous white line along the centre of the road.
explanation: It is an offence to park at the side of a road that has a single or double continuous white line along its centre. Parking on such a road could create an obstruction and may cause inconvenience or danger to other road users.

question_text: When must drivers stop at an automated railway level crossing with barriers and red flashing lights?
option_a: When the red and amber lights stop flashing.
option_b: When the barrier is fully up.
option_c: Stop safely when the amber light shows, or when red lights start to flash.
option_d: When there are no lights visible.
explanation: You must stop safely when the amber light shows. Flashing red lights have the same meaning as a steady red traffic light - stop safely when they show.

question_text: What road users must comply with traffic lights (including pedestrian lights)?
option_a: Pedestrians only.
option_b: Drivers only.
option_c: All road users.
option_d: School children only.
explanation: As road users, pedestrians must comply with traffic controls. Drivers should be aware that traffic lights and pedestrian lights can be combined at junctions and should show caution and consideration to pedestrians.

question_text: What do flashing amber arrows indicate at a junction?
option_a: It is prohibited to proceed in the direction indicated.
option_b: The direction indicated is a cul-de-sac.
option_c: Proceed smartly through junction to avoid delay.
option_d: When safe, drivers should proceed in the direction indicated.
explanation: When you meet a flashing amber arrow at a junction, you should proceed in the direction indicated provided it is safe to do so.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Motorway to the left.
option_b: Traffic from the right has priority.
option_c: Turn left only.
option_d: Diversion ahead to the left.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn left. It is usually displayed at a junction where all traffic must turn left - for example, in a one-way system that incorporates a junction.

question_text: What colour traffic light comes on after the green?
option_a: Amber only.
option_b: Flashing amber.
option_c: Green arrow.
option_d: Red only.
explanation: The normal sequence of traffic lights is red-green-amber.

question_text: What must a driver do when this sign is NOT accompanied by a white stop line on the road?
option_a: Stop past the sign.
option_b: Stop no more than one car length past the sign
option_c: Stop only if there is traffic on the major road.
option_d: Stop at the sign.
explanation: Where a STOP sign is not accompanied by a white stop line, you must stop at the sign.

question_text: What do these signs together mean?
option_a: Loose chippings on the road ahead.
option_b: Beware of children crossing.
option_c: People jogging have right of way.
option_d: Slippery road - children may fall.
explanation: These signs are usually displayed in residential areas, and they give advance warning that children might be crossing ahead. You should proceed cautiously and be prepared to stop suddenly.

question_text: What should a driver do when approaching traffic lights stuck on red?
option_a: Sound the horn and proceed ahead.
option_b: Stop and proceed with great caution.
option_c: Indicate and increase speed.
option_d: Check that there are no oncoming vehicles and increase speed.
explanation: On approach to traffic lights that are stuck on red, a driver should stop and proceed with caution when the way is clear.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: End of dual carriageway.
option_b: No overtaking.
option_c: No stopping/parking on the right.
option_d: Double parking not allowed.
explanation: This sign tells you that overtaking is prohibited. These signs are usually found in places where overtaking may be dangerous, such as in areas with reduced visibility.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The cyclist is signalling following traffic to overtake.
option_b: The cyclist intends to move out.
option_c: The cyclist intends to slow down or stop.
option_d: The cyclist intends to turn left.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that cyclist intends to slow down or stop. This may indicate that the cyclist is aware of some hazard ahead, so drive with extra care.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: The driver must overtake on the right only.
option_b: Road narrows on the left.
option_c: Merging traffic from the left.
option_d: End of dual carriageway
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road narrows on the left ahead. You should show caution and prepare to adjust your road position.

question_text: What does this Garda signal mean?
option_a: Proceed if approaching from the front.
option_b: Stop if approaching from behind.
option_c: Stop if approaching from the front.
option_d: Proceed if approaching from behind.
explanation: When approaching a Garda giving this signal you must stop.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Beware of vehicle with a wide load.
option_b: Tunnel ends ahead.
option_c: End of central reserve or obstruction.
option_d: Dual carriageway ends ahead.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that traffic previously separated by the central reserve or an obstruction will revert to two-way traffic.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Level crossing ahead with pedestrian walkway.
option_b: School children crossing ahead.
option_c: Playground ahead.
option_d: Picnic area ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be school children crossing the road ahead, slow down if required and be prepared to stop.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Dual carriageway ahead.
option_b: Two-way traffic ahead.
option_c: One-way street ahead.
option_d: Traffic may not stop.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of two-way traffic ahead, with oncoming traffic in the opposite lane.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Road narrows from right.
option_b: A driver may overtake on the right only.
option_c: Overtaking lane ends ahead.
option_d: Right hand lane has an uneven surface.
explanation: Where there are roadworks up ahead, this warning sign tells you that the road narrows from the right creating a potential hazard.

question_text: What do flashing amber lights at a pelican crossing mean?
option_a: Danger ahead. A driver must stop and wait until the light stops flashing.
option_b: A driver is entering a special speed limit area.
option_c: Drivers have right of way.
option_d: Stop and give way to pedestrians - proceed if the way is clear.
explanation: A flashing amber light at a pelican crossing means you must yield to pedestrians. You may proceed, however, if the crossing is clear.

question_text: What do these signs together mean?
option_a: End of detour.
option_b: End of speed limit.
option_c: End of road.
option_d: End of road works.
explanation: Together these two signs indicate that a detour has ended.

question_text: When is parking permitted at a sharp bend?
option_a: When parking no more than 45 centimetres from the kerb or edge of the road.
option_b: When drivers coming from behind can see the parked vehicle.
option_c: When the hazard warning lights of the parked vehicle are on.
option_d: Parking is never permitted at a sharp bend.
explanation: Parking is never permitted where it might interfere in any way with the normal flow of traffic or obstruct or endanger other road users - for example, by forcing other drivers into the path of oncoming traffic.

question_text: What does this traffic light mean?
option_a: Proceed if the way is clear.
option_b: The traffic lights are out of order.
option_c: Stop, unless it is unsafe to do so.
option_d: Prepare to move off.
explanation: When the traffic light is showing amber you must not go beyond the stop line unless you so close to the traffic lights that stopping would be dangerous.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Road closed during the times shown.
option_b: Clearway - no stopping or parking during the times shown.
option_c: Crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
option_d: Pedestrianised street - no access for vehicles.
explanation: A Clearway sign means that stopping or parking is not permitted in this area during the times shown on the information plate.

question_text: What does this traffic light mean?
option_a: Traffic may proceed if turning left.
option_b: Traffic must stop at the traffic light.
option_c: Traffic may proceed if safe to do so.
option_d: Traffic may stop if safe to do so.
explanation: A red light means STOP. You must not go beyond the stop line or (if there is no stop line) beyond the light.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The driver intends to turn right.
option_b: The driver intends to turn left.
option_c: The driver intends to begin a U-turn.
option_d: The driver intends to slow down or stop.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the driver intends to slow down or stop and following traffic should be prepared to slow down also.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The driver intends to stop.
option_b: The driver intends to slow down.
option_c: The driver intends to turn left.
option_d: The driver intends to turn right.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a Garda directing traffic (facing this vehicle), that the driver intends to make a left hand turn.

question_text: What colour traffic light comes on after a non-flashing amber light?
option_a: Flashing red light.
option_b: Flashing amber light.
option_c: Green only.
option_d: Red only.
explanation: The normal sequence of traffic lights is red-green-amber.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: No right turn.
option_b: Keep right
option_c: Traffic crossing from the left.
option_d: Steep decline from the left.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must keep right. It is usually found in a one-way system where the traffic is required to keep to the right and also used on occasion to control traffic at roadworks.

question_text: If there is no footpath, where must a pedestrian walk?
option_a: Left-hand side of the road.
option_b: There is no regulation.
option_c: Right-hand side of the road.
option_d: 1 metre from the edge of the road.
explanation: Where there is no footpath provided, pedestrians should walk on the right-hand side of the road facing oncoming traffic. Drivers should be aware of the Rules of the Road for pedestrians, drive with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Three lanes ahead.
option_b: Crossing traffic ahead.
option_c: Three hundred meters to the next exit.
option_d: Parking for three vehicles only.
explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the next exit off the motorway is 300 metres ahead.

question_text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
option_a: Payment in euros only in this lane.
option_b: Electronic toll not accepted in this lane.
option_c: Electronic toll out of order in this lane.
option_d: Electronic toll accepted in any lane.
explanation: This sign is used at toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge is collected electronically. When the vehicle passes through the plaza it is identified by means of an electronic tag fitted to the front windscreen. Payment will be collected via the users account. Only vehicles fitted with the tags are allowed to use those lanes.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: The driver must stop when vehicles ahead show brake lights.
option_b: The driver must stop when red lights show.
option_c: Emerging vehicles have priority. The driver must stop if necessary.
option_d: Stop and wait for green light before proceeding.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that you must stop when red lights show. This sign may be displayed at a railway level crossing.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Y-Junction where main road bears to the left.
option_b: Y-Junction where heavy vehicles must go left.
option_c: Y-Junction where main road bears to the right
option_d: Y-Junction where vehicles must go left.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a Y-junction with a minor road ahead. The wider arm of the Y indicates the course of the main road.

question_text: Is a driver permitted to park at an entrance to a property?
option_a: Yes, with the property owner''s consent.
option_b: Yes, outside business hours.
option_c: Yes, for 1 hour between 23.30 hrs to 07.00 hrs.
option_d: Yes, for 1 hour between 07.00 hrs to 23.30 hrs.
explanation: You may park across the entrance to a property only with the owners consent. Parking across an entrance may cause inconvenience and danger to persons entering or leaving the property.

question_text: What does this traffic light mean?
option_a: The driver may proceed in the direction of the green arrow if the way is clear.
option_b: All traffic must turn right.
option_c: The driver must stop and wait until the full green light appears.
option_d: Traffic is not allowed to turn right.
explanation: A green arrow (filter light) means that traffic may proceed in the direction of the arrow if it is safe to do so.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: 100 metres to the next exit.
option_b: Sharp descent for 100 metres.
option_c: Sharp ascent in 100 metres.
option_d: Low bridge ahead.
explanation: This is a motorway information sign that tells you that the next exit off the motorway is 100 metres ahead.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Series of bumps or hollows ahead.
option_b: Traffic island ahead
option_c: Road falls from centre to left and right.
option_d: Sharp rise in the road ahead - for example, a humpback bridge.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a hump in the road. You should adjust your speed accordingly.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
option_b: Beware of pedestrians at night.
option_c: Lane reserved for pedestrians.
option_d: School ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a pedestrian crossing ahead. You should show caution and be prepared to stop.

question_text: When do temporary speed limits apply at roadworks?
option_a: During business hours only.
option_b: Only when road workers are on site.
option_c: For the duration of the roadworks.
option_d: Only when there is oncoming traffic.
explanation: Temporary speed limits at road works apply for the duration of the works. When road works are completed, normal speed limits apply.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Straight ahead only.
option_b: Motorway ahead.
option_c: Two-way street ahead.
option_d: Overtaking lane ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must proceed straight ahead. This sign is usually displayed on the entry to a one-way street.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Sharp change of direction to the left.
option_b: Series of speed ramps ahead.
option_c: Road closed - drivers must turn back.
option_d: Sharp change of direction to the right.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a sharp change of direction to the right. You should slow down as you approach the hazard.

question_text: When is parking permitted at a taxi rank?
option_a: When waiting to collect passengers from a taxi.
option_b: Parking at a taxi rank is prohibited unless driving a taxi.
option_c: When the rank is unoccupied.
option_d: When parking for less than 15 minutes.
explanation: Stopping or parking within an area marked as a taxi rank is prohibited as this may obstruct taxis entering or leaving the rank.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Uneven road surface ahead.
option_b: Steep descent ahead.
option_c: River or unprotected quay ahead.
option_d: Steep ascent ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a steep descent/downward slope ahead. You should react accordingly by adjusting speed and selecting the appropriate gear.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Private grounds - no entry.
option_b: Level crossing ahead guarded by gates or barriers.
option_c: Road fencing ahead.
option_d: Farm machinery crossing ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a railway crossing ahead that is protected by gates or lifting barriers. You should be prepared to stop and follow the required procedure.

question_text: What does this road marking mean?
option_a: A driver may not park along this road.
option_b: A driver must not cross the broken white line unless it is safe to do so.
option_c: A driver may not overtake along this road.
option_d: A driver may overtake provided they do not cross the broken white line.
explanation: A broken white line along the centre of the road means you must not cross the line unless it is safe to do so when overtaking or passing.

question_text: When traffic lights are green, when should a driver not proceed?
option_a: When traffic is stopped waiting to turn from the road on the left.
option_b: When traffic is stopped waiting to turn from the road on the right.
option_c: When oncoming traffic is waiting to turn left.
option_d: When it would be unsafe to do so.
explanation: Although a green traffic light means proceed with caution, you should not enter a junction if the way is not clear or if by doing so you would cause an obstruction to other road users.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The driver will begin to reverse
option_b: The driver intends to turn left.
option_c: The driver intends to slow down.
option_d: The driver intends to turn right.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users or a Garda directing traffic (facing this vehicle) that the driver intends to turn right.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Contra-flow bus lane ahead.
option_b: With-flow bus lane on the left.
option_c: With-flow bus lane on the right
option_d: Buses may block the driver's view of cyclists.
explanation: This sign indicates a with-flow off-side bus lane on the right. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

question_text: Who can use a signed cycle track accompanied by a continuous white line on the left-hand side?
option_a: Cyclists and motorcyclists.
option_b: Drivers, when it is not being used by a cyclist.
option_c: Cyclists and users of motorised wheelchairs.
option_d: Drivers when overtaking a vehicle turning right.
explanation: A cycle track is for the use of cyclists and motorised wheelchairs only. No other vehicles may cross into or over a mandatory cycle track unless this is necessary in order to leave or enter a side road or a property adjacent to the cycle track.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Rugged coast ahead.
option_b: Steep descent ahead.
option_c: Falling leaves ahead.
option_d: Danger of falling rocks ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there is a danger of rocks and other debris falling onto the road. Drive with caution.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Slippery road ahead.
option_b: Overhead electric cables.
option_c: Series of dangerous corners ahead.
option_d: Series of dangerous bends ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of dangerous corners ahead. You should slow down and react to any changes in the traffic situation.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: With-flow bus and cycle lane on left.
option_b: Cycle track ahead may be crossed by buses only.
option_c: Bicycles and buses not allowed on left.
option_d: Parking for buses and bicycles on left.
explanation: This sign indicates a near side with-flow bus lane on the left. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Level crossing ahead.
option_b: Tramway crossing ahead.
option_c: Bus and tramway crossing ahead.
option_d: Railway station.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning sign of a tram crossing ahead. You should be prepared to stop and yield to the tram, if required.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Nearside lane of three closed.
option_b: No left turn.
option_c: Do not drive on the hard shoulder.
option_d: Overtaking permitted, except on the left lane.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that that the nearside (left hand) lane of three is closed up ahead. If you are in this lane you will need to move to the centre (middle) lane when it is safe to do so.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Cyclists must give way to buses ahead.
option_b: Buses must give way to other traffic ahead
option_c: Buses must give way to cyclists ahead.
option_d: Bus and cycle lane ahead on right.
explanation: This sign tells you that there is an off side bus lane ahead on the right. Only buses, taxis and cyclists may use the bus lane during the stated operational hours.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: School children crossing ahead.
option_b: Railway crossing ahead.
option_c: School playground ahead.
option_d: Children's play area ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be school children crossing the road ahead, slow down if required and be prepared to stop.

question_text: When may a trailer be towed on a public road without a rear number plate?
option_a: When being towed by an agricultural tractor.
option_b: When the tailboard is removed.
option_c: Never, a number plate must always be displayed.
option_d: When carrying a load that overhangs the trailer.
explanation: The law requires all motorised vehicles to display a rear number plate that is clean and legible.

question_text: What does this road marking mean?
option_a: Keep outside the yellow lines.
option_b: Parking prohibited during business hours.
option_c: Parking prohibited at all times.
option_d: Taxi parking only.
explanation: A double yellow line along the edge of the road means parking is not allowed at any time.

question_text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a trailer on a motorway?
option_a: 60 km/h.
option_c: 80 km/h.
explanation: When towing a trailer on a motorway it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h - excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

question_text: What does this traffic light mean?
option_a: All traffic must turn left only.
option_b: Traffic turning left should prepare for full green to move off.
option_c: Traffic is not allowed to turn left.
option_d: Traffic turning left may proceed if the way is clear.
explanation: A green arrow (filter light) means that traffic may proceed in the direction of the arrow if it is safe to do so

question_text: What is the maximum permissible speed for cars and motorcycles on motorways?
option_a: 80 km/h.
option_d: 60 km/h.
explanation: It is illegal to exceed 120 km/h when driving on a motorway.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Guarded level crossing ahead.
option_b: T-junction with dual carriageway ahead.
option_c: Unguarded level crossing ahead.
option_d: Low bridge ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction at a dual carriageway ahead. Drivers need to be observant, taking extra care for traffic coming from each direction. Yield and/or stop as appropriate.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: 80 metres to the end of motorway.
option_b: Minimum speed is 80 km/h.
option_c: Maximum speed is 80 km/h.
option_d: 80 metres to the start of motorway.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 80 km/h.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Series of rumble strips ahead.
option_b: Steep hills ahead.
option_c: Road works ahead.
option_d: Series of bumps or hollows ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of bumps or hollows ahead. Be prepared to reduce your speed as necessary.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Mud slide ahead.
option_b: Tree planting ahead.
option_c: Building site ahead.
option_d: Roadworks ahead.
explanation: This warning sign tells you that there are roadworks ahead. You should approach with caution and be alert for a change in the road surface, and for the presence of machinery and road workers.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Offside lane of two closed.
option_b: Traffic in nearside lane must turn left.
option_c: Nearside lane of two closed.
option_d: T-junction ahead in the left lane.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that that the nearside (left hand) lane is closed ahead. If you are in this lane you will need to move to the offside (right hand) lane when it is safe to do so.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The cyclist intends to dismount.
option_b: The cyclist intends to turn left.
option_c: The cyclist intends to stop.
option_d: The cyclist intends to overtake.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclist intends to make a left-hand turn.

question_text: What does this road marking mean?
option_a: No parking in this area.
option_b: A driver may overtake in this area.
option_c: Road surface is uneven.
option_d: Set down area only.
explanation: White zig zag lines indicate that you are approaching a pedestrian crossing. You must not park or overtake within this area.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Parking permitted during the times shown.
option_b: Parking reserved for people with disabilities.
option_c: Maximum parking for one hour during times shown.
option_d: Parking prohibited at the times shown.
explanation: These signs tells you that parking is permitted in both directions, but only at the times shown on the information plate.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The cyclist intends to stop.
option_b: The cyclist intends to turn left.
option_c: The cyclist intends to go straight on.
option_d: The cyclist is giving way to other traffic.
explanation: This hand signal informs other road users that the cyclists intends to proceed straight ahead at a junction and drivers should show caution.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Stop your vehicle.
option_b: Other traffic must give way to you.
option_c: Stop for school crossing ahead.
option_d: Give way to traffic coming from your right.
explanation: This sign appears at junctions where a minor road joins a major road. You must stop your vehicle completely at a STOP sign.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Parking permitted.
option_b: Parking prohibited.
option_c: Private vehicles prohibited.
option_d: Public service vehicles prohibited.
explanation: This sign tells you that parking is prohibited in both directions.

question_text: What does this road marking mean?
option_a: Drivers may cross the line to overtake.
option_b: Drivers must keep left of the continuous white line.
option_c: Only motorcyclists may cross the lines to overtake.
option_d: Oncoming traffic may cross the line to overtake.
explanation: A single continuous white line along the centre of the road means all traffic must keep to the left of the line. You are not permitted to overtake or perform a U-turn on this section of road.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Dual carriageway ahead.
option_b: Traffic may not stop.
option_c: One-way street.
option_d: Two-way traffic.
explanation: This warning sign tells you that during roadworks there will be two-way traffic in operation ahead. Continue to drive with extra care.

question_text: What does this hand signal mean?
option_a: The cyclist intends to move in or turn left.
option_b: The cyclist intends to slow down.
option_c: The cyclist intends to move out or turn right.
option_d: The cyclist intends to stop.
explanation: This hand signal tells other road users that the cyclist intends to either move out or make a right hand turn. Drivers should be aware that cyclists could move out into the path of their vehicle without looking.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Steep climb ahead.
option_b: Slippery road ahead.
option_c: Series of dangerous corners ahead.
option_d: Series of dangerous bends ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a series of dangerous bends ahead. You should slow down and react to any changes in the traffic situation.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Railway tunnel ahead.
option_b: Tramline ahead.
option_c: Overtake only on the left ahead.
option_d: Road divides ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that the road divides ahead. You should prepare to move to the left.

question_text: What does this road marking indicate?
option_a: Traffic calming.
option_b: Cycle lane.
option_c: Zebra crossing.
option_d: Pedestrian island.
explanation: A zebra crossing is a designated area for pedestrians to cross the road. As a driver you must always yield to pedestrians on a zebra crossing.

question_text: When is parking permitted on the brow of a hill?
option_a: When the driver angles the wheels towards the kerb.
option_b: Parking is permitted when a vehicle has an efficient handbrake.
option_c: Only when there is no traffic on the road.
option_d: Parking is never permitted on the brow of a hill.
explanation: Parking on the brow of a hill or on a humpbacked bridge is prohibited. Parking in such a place may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the hill and force them into the path of oncoming traffic.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Maximum speed is 60 km/h.
option_b: Parking not allowed for more than 60 minutes.
option_c: Distance to junction is 60 metres.
option_d: Minimum speed is 60 km/h.
explanation: This sign tells you that the maximum legal speed limit permitted for this section of road is 60 km/h.

question_text: What does this road marking and information plate together mean?
option_a: Parking only at times and days shown.
option_b: Taxi parking only outside the times and days shown.
option_c: Parking not allowed at the times and days shown.
option_d: Taxi parking only at the times and days shown.
explanation: A single yellow line along the edge of a road means that you must not park there during the times shown on the accompanying information plate

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Turn right only.
option_b: Diversion ahead to the right.
option_c: Overtake only on the right.
option_d: Major road joining from the left.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn right. It is usually displayed at a junction where all traffic must turn right - for example, in a one-way system that incorporates a junction.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Roads closed ahead to both left and right.
option_b: Traffic calming ramps ahead.
option_c: Staggered crossroads ahead with roads of equal importance.
option_d: Cul-de-sac to both left and right
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a staggered junction ahead with roads to the left and right. Be aware that vehicles may be emerging from these roads.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Diversion to the right ahead.
option_b: You must turn right ahead.
option_c: Sharp bend to the right ahead.
option_d: One-way traffic to the right ahead.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must turn right ahead. It is usually displayed on the approach to a one-way system.

question_text: What do these signs together mean?
option_a: Clearway ahead - no stopping or parking during times shown.
option_b: Pedestrianised street ahead - traffic not allowed except during times shown.
option_c: Access for buses and taxis only during times shown.
option_d: Parking not allowed during times shown.
explanation: When posted together these signs tells you that there is a Pedestrianised street ahead and that traffic is not allowed to enter except during the times stated on the information plate.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Junction ahead with railway crossing.
option_b: Junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
option_c: Junction ahead with roads of lesser importance.
option_d: Junction ahead with roads of greater importance.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a junction ahead with minor roads on either side. Be aware that vehicles may be emerging from the minor roads.

question_text: What traffic may use a cycle lane accompanied by a continuous white line?
option_a: Buses and cyclists.
option_b: Cyclists and taxis.
option_c: Cyclists and motorcyclists.
option_d: Cyclists and motorised wheelchairs.
explanation: A cycle track is for the use of cyclists and motorised wheelchairs. No other vehicles may cross into or over a mandatory cycle track unless this is necessary in order to leave a side road or a property adjacent to the cycle track.

question_text: On a narrow busy road, what should pedestrians do when walking?
option_a: Walk in single file.
option_b: Walk more than two abreast.
option_c: Walk two abreast.
option_d: Walk in groups of no more than three.
explanation: Pedestrians should walk in single file on busy narrow roads. Drivers should be aware of the Rules of the Road for pedestrians, drive with caution and be prepared to react to any changes in the traffic situation.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Traffic should cross back to the left-hand lane ahead.
option_b: Lay-by ahead.
option_c: Bend in the road to the left ahead.
option_d: Slow lane ahead for heavy traffic.
explanation: This roadworks warning sign tells you that the course of the road will return to the left ahead. This usually appears after a stretch where traffic was diverted to a right-hand lane.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: T-junction ahead with a road of major importance.
option_b: Cul-de-sac to the right.
option_c: T-junction ahead with a road of minor importance.
option_d: Cul-de-sac to the left and right.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction ahead with a major road. Be prepared to yield or stop as necessary.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Diversion at junction ahead.
option_b: Traffic merging/diverging ahead.
option_c: Road narrows briefly ahead.
option_d: Yield to merging/diverging traffic ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of roads both merging (entering onto the main road) and diverging (exiting the main road). Drivers should be prepared for traffic changing speed and direction as vehicles enter or exit at the junctions on the left ahead.

question_text: Within what distance of a road junction is parking prohibited?
option_a: 10 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
option_b: 5 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
option_c: 20 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
option_d: 15 metres, unless parking spaces are clearly marked.
explanation: It is an offence to park within 5 metres of a road junction unless parking spaces are clearly marked. Parking in that area may restrict the zone of vision of drivers approaching the junction and may cause an obstruction to large vehicles wishing to turn.

question_text: What does this sign mean when displayed on the approach to a toll plaza?
option_a: Coin basket in this lane.
option_b: Cashier in this lane.
option_c: Ticket dispenser in this lane.
option_d: Electronic toll collection.
explanation: This sign is used at toll plazas to direct traffic into a lane where the toll charge may be paid by putting the exact change into an automatic coin machine. This lane usually has a height barrier fitted to prevent large vehicles using it.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: A driver must merge from the left.
option_b: A driver must drive on the left-hand side.
option_c: A driver must overtake on the left-hand side.
option_d: A driver may park on the left.
explanation: This sign is generally in areas where tourists might be travelling and reminds motorists to drive on the left. These signs are commonly found around airports and ferry ports.

question_text: What does this road marking and information plate together mean?
option_a: Parking not allowed at the times shown.
option_b: Loading bay at times shown.
option_c: Taxi rank at times shown.
option_d: No parking at any time
explanation: A single yellow line along the edge of a road means that you must not park there during the times shown on the accompanying information plate.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Road narrows from left.
option_b: Left-hand lane has an uneven surface.
option_c: A driver may overtake on the right only.
option_d: Slow lane ends ahead.
explanation: This warning sign tells you that there are roadworks up ahead where the road narrows from the left creating a potential hazard.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Golf course ahead.
option_b: Crosswinds ahead.
option_c: Falling rocks ahead.
option_d: Airport ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning that there may be crosswinds ahead. Crosswinds can affect the stability of your vehicle on the road. Be prepared to slow down if necessary.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Parking in loading area is not allowed.

option_c: Parking of vehicles under the weight shown is not allowed
option_d: Parking of vehicles exceeding the weight shown is not allowed.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must not park in this area if your vehicle is over the weight limit indicated.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: With-flow bus lane to right.
option_b: Buses emerging from right.
option_c: Contra-flow bus lane on the right.
option_d: Cycle track may be crossed by buses.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must drive on the left and not use the contra-flow bus lane day or night. A contraflow bus lane is one where the buses are going in the opposite direction.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Steep decline to the left.
option_b: Pass on the left.
option_c: Keep left.
option_d: No left turn.
explanation: This sign tells you that you must keep left. It is usually displayed at a traffic island in the centre of the road and also used on occasion to control traffic at roadworks.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: T-junction ahead with merging traffic.
option_b: T-junction ahead with road of less importance.
option_c: T-junction ahead with roads of equal importance.
option_d: T-junction ahead with dual carriageway.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a T-junction ahead with a road of equal importance. You must give way to traffic already on the road you are joining.

question_text: Unless otherwise indicated, what is the maximum permissible speed of a car towing a caravan on a motorway?
option_a: 90 km/h.
option_c: 80 km/h.
explanation: When towing a caravan on a motorway it is illegal to exceed 80 km/h - excessive speed will make such a vehicle unstable.

question_text: What do these road markings mean?
option_a: No parking allowed.
option_b: No overtaking allowed.
option_c: Continuous white lines ahead.
option_d: Dual carriageway ahead.
explanation: Double broken white lines along the centre of the road alert you to continuous white lines ahead. Do not cross them unless it is safe to do so.

question_text: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, which of the following should be checked soon afterwards?
option_a: The brake pad clearance.
option_b: The tyre tread depth
option_c: The air valve.
option_d: The wheel nuts.
explanation: After changing a wheel on a vehicle it is recommended to check the wheel nuts after a short period of driving to ensure they are still properly secured.

question_text: What does a flashing amber arrow pointing left at a traffic light mean?
option_a: A driver must not proceed in this direction.
option_b: The driver must wait until the traffic lights turn green.
option_c: A driver may turn left but yield to traffic on the other road.
option_d: A driver may proceed before traffic on the other road.
explanation: A flashing left amber arrow at a junction means you may proceed left but must give way to pedestrians and traffic already coming through the junction on the other road.

question_text: What does this sign mean?
option_a: Road passing under a bridge ahead.
option_b: Crossroads with dual carriageway ahead
option_c: T-junction ahead with roads of major importance.
option_d: Crossroads with major road ahead.
explanation: This sign gives advance warning of a crossroads junction with a major road ahead. Be prepared to stop.

question_text: What is the penalty for a vehicle owner who allows a learner driver to drive their vehicle unaccompanied?
option_a: Their vehicle will be seized.
option_b: They will lose their driving licence.
option_c: They will be fined €2,000.
option_d: They will incur 2 penalty points on their licence.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that driving unaccompanied in a vehicle, even where the owner has given their consent to drive, may result in the vehicle being seized.

question_text: How many penalty points will an unaccompanied learner driver receive on conviction?
option_a: 3 penalty points.

option_c: 4 penalty points.
option_d: 5 penalty points.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that driving unaccompanied increases the penalty points to 4 on conviction.

explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware of the legal requirements to display ‰Û÷L' plates front and rear and the implications of not doing so.

question_text: Are there any occasions when a learner driver can drive unaccompanied?
option_a: No, learner drivers must be accompanied at all times by a qualified driver.
option_b: Yes, when driving to the test centre before the driving test.
option_c: Yes, when meeting an approved driving instructor (ADI).
option_d: Yes, after completing a driving test.
explanation: Learner drivers must be aware that they must be accompanied by a qualified driver at all times.

question_text: Is a learner driver permitted to drive unaccompanied if they have the consent of the vehicle owner?
option_a: No, a learner driver is not permitted to drive unaccompanied even with the owner''s consent.
option_b: Yes, provided the vehicle owner has given their consent.
option_c: Yes, provided the vehicle owner has open drive insurance.
option_d: Yes, provided the owner is a family member and has given their consent.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that, even with the consent of the owner of the vehicle, they are not permitted to drive unaccompanied.

question_text: A learner driver detected of driving unaccompanied faces a minimum of how many penalty points?
option_a: 4 penalty points.
option_b: 2 penalty points.
option_c: 5 penalty points.
option_d: 3 penalty points.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that driving unaccompanied will result in a penalty point offence.

question_text: What is the fine for a learner driver for driving a vehicle unaccompanied?
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that driving unaccompanied increases the fine to €120 on conviction.

question_text: When a learner driver has passed their driving test, are they permitted to drive unaccompanied as the holder of a Certificate of Competency?
option_a: No, a learner driver is not permitted to drive unaccompanied until they have been issued with a full driving licence in that category.
option_b: No, a learner driver is not permitted to drive unaccompanied on a Certificate of Competency unless they continue to display ‰Û÷L'' plates.

option_d: Yes, a learner driver is permitted to drive unaccompanied on a Certificate of Competency once they have notified their insurance company.
explanation: A learner driver who successfully passes their driving test needs to be aware that the rules that apply to learner permit holders still apply to them until they are in possession of a full driving licence in that category. A Certificate of Competency is not a full licence.

question_text: What are the fixed charge amount and penalties incurred for a learner driver who drives unaccompanied?
option_a: €80 fine and 2 penalty points.
option_b: €80 fine and 3 penalty points.
option_c: €60 fine and 5 penalty points.
option_d: €100 fine and 2 penalty points.
explanation: A learner driver needs to know that there are penalties for driving unaccompanied.

question_text: A learner driver who has been stopped by a Garda for driving unaccompanied faces a minimum fine of how much?
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that, if they are stopped by a Garda for driving unaccompanied, it will lead to a financial penalty.

question_text: What specific observations should a driver make before reversing their vehicle?
option_a: Look over both shoulders and behind.
option_b: Look over right-hand shoulder.
option_c: Look in door mirrors only.
option_d: Look in interior mirror only.
explanation: Before reversing, look over both shoulders and to the rear to check all around that there are no children or other road users around the vehicle and that it is safe to reverse.

question_text: Can a person who has passed their car driving test within the last two years act as an accompanying driver?
option_a: Yes, as long as they have their full licence with them.
option_b: No, unless they are a qualified approved driving instructor (ADI).
option_c: No, they must hold the full driving licence for a minimum of 2 years.
option_d: Yes, as long as they have completed their Essential Driver Training (EDT).
explanation: To be an accompanying driver for a learner driver, you must have a full driving licence for at least 2 years.

question_text: A learner permit driver who receives 7 penalty points in a 36 month period (three years) will be banned from driving for how many months?
option_a: 12 months.
option_b: 9 months.
option_c: 3 months.
option_d: 6 months.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that there is a lower penalty point threshold for learner or novice drivers

question_text: For how long is a learner driver's accompanying driver required to have held their full licence in Category B?
option_a: 3 years.
option_b: 1 year.
option_c: 6 months.
option_d: 2 years.
explanation: A learner driver needs to be aware that not just anyone can be an accompanying driver. An accompanying driver has to have held a full licence for at least 2 years and have built up good driving experience.

question_text: How does the driver know the vehicle's total load-carrying capacity?
option_a: By checking the horse power of the engine.
option_b: By referring to the vehicle manufacturer's specification.
option_c: By measuring the size of the boot.
option_d: By counting the number of seats.
explanation: Design Gross Vehicle Weight is the term used by manufacturers for the weight of the vehicle together with the maximum load it is designed to carry. Drivers must understand the carrying capacity of their vehicle. Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control, and its an offence.

question_text: What would be the effect of overloading a vehicle with passengers or goods?
option_a: It would improve the vehicle's road-holding ability.
option_b: Overloading will not reduce the ability to control the vehicle.
option_c: It would reduce the driver's ability to control the vehicle.
option_d: It would not have any effect provided speed is reduced.
explanation: Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control, and will increase the risk of a collision.

question_text: What determines the maximum allowed towing capacity of a vehicle?
option_a: The combined weight of the vehicle and its trailer.
option_b: The size of the tyres on the vehicle.
option_c: The strength of the tow bar.
option_d: The manufacturer's specifications.
explanation: The maximum weight that your vehicle can safely tow is specified by the manufacturer, and is usually set out in the drivers handbook for the vehicle, and in some cases on a plate attached to the vehicle. This is the safe towing limit for the vehicle and you should not exceed it.

question_text: What effect can overloading a vehicle have on its road-holding?
option_a: The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control, but only when reversing.
option_b: The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control.
option_c: Provided the load is evenly distributed, it improves the stability of the vehicle.
option_d: The load can make the vehicle more difficult to control, but only when going downhill.
explanation: Overloading your vehicle will make it more difficult to control. Remember: its an offence to overload a vehicle.

question_text: What effect could an unevenly distributed load have on a vehicle?
option_a: It could cause the clutch to slip while accelerating.
option_b: It could cause the vehicle to overheat.
option_c: It could cause the gear box to overheat.
option_d: It could make the vehicle unstable while turning.
explanation: When loading a vehicle you should ensure that the load is distributed evenly. An unevenly distributed load may change the vehicles centre of gravity and this could affect the braking and steering.

question_text: What should a driver do to avoid the need for harsh braking?
option_a: Drive with cruise control engaged.
option_b: Drive with one foot resting on the brake pedal.
option_c: Drive with one foot resting on the clutch pedal.
option_d: Look ahead and anticipate what others may do.
explanation: You should know what speed you''re travelling at and you should always drive at a speed that is appropriate to the conditions you are driving in, and you should be able to stop smoothly and safely within the distance you can see to be clear ahead.

question_text: How could towing an overloaded trailer affect a vehicle?
option_a: It could improve braking ability when going downhill.
option_b: It could impair the vehicle's steering and braking.
option_c: It could improve the vehicle's fuel consumption.
option_d: It could improve road holding on bends.
explanation: You should not take an overloaded trailer onto a public road. An overloaded trailer impairs the stability, steering and braking of the towing vehicle.

question_text: When is a tractor most likely to overturn?
option_a: When driving uphill.
option_b: When reversing slowly.
option_c: When turning sharply.
option_d: When driving on the flat.
explanation: When you are driving a tractor, you should be aware that tractors are less stable than other vehicles and take extra care when manoeuvring.

question_text: What is meant by the term jack-knifing?
option_a: When the trailer is too heavy to be drawn by the tractor.
option_b: When the trailer is travelling faster than the drawing vehicle.
option_c: When the vehicle slides due to ice or water on the road.
option_d: When the jack is not strong enough to lift an axle.
explanation: Towing a trailer or caravan dramatically reduces the stability of the towing vehicle. If a driver brakes sharply or slows down quickly, the trailer may pivot around the tow hitch coupling, causing both vehicles to go off course, and possibly overturn.

question_text: When changing a wheel on a public road, what should a person do to ensure their own safety?
option_a: Ensure the vehicle is in first gear and the wheels are facing the roadway.
option_b: Ensure the vehicle is in reverse gear and front wheels are facing the roadway.
option_c: Wear reflective clothing and switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights.
option_d: Ask a bystander to warn traffic by beckoning them from the middle of the road.
explanation: When changing a wheel at the side of the road, switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights, and wear reflective or light-coloured clothing. This will help other motorists to react and slow down when passing.

question_text: When attaching a trailer to their vehicle, what must a driver check?
option_a: That the load is positioned to the front of the trailer.
option_b: That the trailer coupling is attached securely.
option_c: That the trailer springs are well greased.
option_d: That the trailer has a spare wheel.
explanation: Before towing a trailer or a caravan, check that the tow bar is securely attached to the towing vehicle, that the trailer coupling is properly attached to the tow bar and locked in place, and that the breakaway cable is properly connected.

question_text: At what point is a vehicle load more likely to shift?
option_a: When braking gently.
option_b: When cornering.
option_c: When reversing.
option_d: When overtaking.
explanation: It is the drivers responsibility to ensure that the load is properly secured and evenly distributed, so that the vehicle can be properly controlled when changing direction and when braking.

question_text: When may the holder of a Category W learner permit carry a passenger on a tractor or works vehicle?
option_a: When there is proper passenger seating and the passenger holds a full Category W licence.
option_b: When the passenger has personal insurance cover.
option_c: When there is a need for their assistance.
option_d: When the passenger holds a full Category M licence and has personal insurance cover.
explanation: The holder of a Category W licence may carry a passenger in the vehicle only if: 1. the vehicle is designed to take a passenger, and 2. the passenger has held a full driving licence in Category W for two or more years.

question_text: What should a driver do when requested to drive a vehicle that they feel is overloaded?
option_a: Refuse to drive the vehicle.
option_b: Drive at a slower speed than normal.
option_c: Drive the vehicle only if accompanied.
option_d: Ensure that the load is properly restrained.
explanation: You should not take a vehicle that you believe to be overloaded onto a public road. Overloading is dangerous, as it affects the stability and braking capabilities of the vehicle.

question_text: Why should a tractor be driven more slowly on uneven road surfaces?
option_a: To maintain tyre pressure.
option_b: To avoid severe bouncing.
option_c: To reduce road noise.
option_d: To avoid fuel spilling from the tank.
explanation: Drivers should drive more slowly on an uneven road surface because driving a tractor at speed could cause the vehicle or the trailer to become unstable and difficult to control. During severe bouncing the tractor''s wheels can lose contact with the road, negatively affecting steering and braking.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle is forced to stop in a tunnel due to a breakdown or a crash?
option_a: Beckon other traffic to overtake.
option_b: Call for help from an emergency station.
option_c: Wait in the vehicle for help to arrive.
option_d: Reverse the vehicle to the exit.
explanation: If there is a breakdown or crash in a tunnel, stop, switch off the engine, switch on the hazard warning lights, check the radio for instructions and use the emergency phone at the emergency station to call for help, check all electronic signs in the tunnel for information.

question_text: Are children allowed to be left unattended in a vehicle?
option_a: Only when there is adequate ventilation.
option_b: Only when the vehicle is not parked on a hill.
option_c: Only when the vehicle is parked in a supervised car park.
option_d: Children should never be left unattended in a vehicle.
explanation: Children must not be left unattended in a vehicle, even for a short period of time. Children might interfere with the vehicles controls, and would not be able to deal with an emergency situation, such as a fire or electrical malfunction which could result in serious injury or death.

question_text: When should rear fog lights be used?
option_a: When both the rear tail lights are broken.
option_b: Rear fog lights should be used only at dawn and dusk.
option_c: When driving in dense fog or falling snow.
option_d: Rear fog lights should always be used.
explanation: A driver must only use rear fog lights in dense fog or falling snow. Using fog lights in normal road and weather conditions can dazzle or blind following motorists. Also, fog lights may make brake lights harder to see.

question_text: What should a driver do before starting a journey in adverse weather conditions?
option_a: Increase tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
option_b: Reduce tyre pressures to ensure better grip on the road.
option_c: Top up the windscreen washer reservoir with coolant.
option_d: Check the weather forecast for the planned route.
explanation: Driving in adverse weather conditions is more dangerous and more tiring. Drivers should check the weather forecast and weather warnings and other sources for information on the expected conditions on the intended route, and allow extra time to complete the journey.

question_text: Before driving through a tunnel, what should a driver do?
option_a: Check that you have sufficient fuel.
option_b: Disengage the global positioning system (GPS).
option_c: Register at the first tunnel station.
option_d: Turn on side lights only.
explanation: If your route takes you through a tunnel, you must ensure that your vehicle has sufficient fuel to safely pass through.

question_text: When is jack-knifing most likely to occur?
option_a: When the trailer springs are over-greased.
option_b: When travelling uphill.
option_c: When trying to reduce speed sharply while travelling downhill.
option_d: When travelling sideways across a slope.
explanation: Towing a trailer or caravan dramatically reduces the stability of the towing vehicle. If a driver brakes sharply or slows down quickly, the trailer may pivot around the tow hitch coupling, causing both vehicles to go off course, and possibly overturn.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
option_a: Wait in the vehicle for help to arrive.
option_b: Switch on the hazard warning lights.
option_c: Reverse the vehicle to the exit.
option_d: Beckon other traffic to overtake.
explanation: If a driver''s vehicle stops in a tunnel due to a breakdown, switch off the engine, switch on the hazard warning lights, check the radio for instructions and use the emergency phone at the emergency station to call for help, check all electronic signs in the tunnel for information.

question_text: What danger can arise from the power take-off shaft of a tractor?
option_a: If it is not disengaged, the steering will lock.
option_b: If it is not covered, the tractor will speed up rapidly.
option_c: If it is not covered, clothing can get caught in it.
option_d: If it is not disengaged, the battery will run flat.
explanation: If you are working at the rear of a tractor, you should bear in mind that if the power take-off shaft is not covered, loose clothing might get caught in it and lead to injury or death.

question_text: When driving a tractor and trailer, what should the driver do on entering a roundabout to avoid possible roll-over?
option_a: Drive in a high gear.
option_b: Reduce speed.
option_c: Increase speed.
option_d: Engage the parking brake.
explanation: When you are driving a tractor with a trailer, you need to take extra care because of the vehicles instability. Always drive at a safe speed, in particular when changing direction, such as on a roundabout.

question_text: What should a driver do before starting a journey in bad weather?
option_a: Top up the gearbox with coolant.
option_b: Top up the windscreen washer reservoir.
option_c: Reduce tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
option_d: Increase tyre pressure to ensure better grip on the road.
explanation: Before starting a long journey in adverse weather the driver should ensure that there is sufficient fluid in the windscreen washer bottle in order to keep the windscreen clear in these conditions.

question_text: A driver has stalled in the middle of an unguarded level crossing and cannot restart the engine. The warning bell is ringing. What should the driver do?
option_a: Push the vehicle clear of the crossing.
option_b: Stay at the vehicle and warn the approaching train.
option_c: Walk clear of the crossing and phone the signal operator so that trains can be stopped.
option_d: Try to restart the engine in first gear.
explanation: In this situation, the driver and all passengers should get out of the vehicle and immediately use the emergency phone at the crossing to contact the signal operator so that trains can be stopped. If necessary, warn other motorists. Do not return to the vehicle until instructed by the signal operator or emergency services.

question_text: Where are the blind spots that a driver needs to be aware of when towing a loaded trailer?
option_a: Parts of the road ahead which are obscured by other large vehicles.
option_b: The goods or cargo area on the back of the trailer.
option_c: The area to the side and rear of the vehicle and the trailer that the driver cannot see.
option_d: The view to the front hidden by the sun-visor.
explanation: A blind spot is an area that a driver cannot see when looking forward or when looking in the mirrors. You should check your blind spots before changing direction or changing lane. The bigger the vehicle, the bigger the blind spots, and you should keep this in mind if you are driving behind a large vehicle, such as one towing a loaded trailer. In this situation, if you cannot see the towing vehicles mirror, then the driver of that vehicle cannot see you.

question_text: Why is it dangerous to allow children to stand in the space between the front seats of a car?
option_a: They could become ill from the motion of the car.
option_b: They could be thrown backward if the brakes are applied suddenly.
option_c: They could distract other drivers thus drawing attention away from the road.
option_d: They could be thrown forward if the brakes are applied suddenly.
explanation: When carrying children in a car or goods vehicle, it is the drivers responsibility to make sure that they are suitably restrained.

question_text: When are children allowed to stand with their heads up through an open sun roof?
option_a: When they are aged more than 12 years.
option_b: Children are never allowed to do so.
option_c: When travelling at speeds below 30 km/h.
option_d: When they are wearing eye protection.
explanation: When carrying children in a car or goods vehicle, it is the drivers responsibility to make sure that they are suitably restrained.

question_text: What would a lightness in the steering MOST likely indicate?
option_a: Icy surface.
option_b: Smooth surface.
option_c: Wet surface.
option_d: Gravelled surface.
explanation: Lightness in steering indicates a loss of traction. This generally happens when the road surface is icy. Ice provides a harder, smoother surface than rain, or snow so it is difficult to avoid skidding and drivers should allow up to 10 times the normal braking distance in order to stop safely.

question_text: At night, what effect could driving with a single headlight have on oncoming drivers?
option_a: It could dazzle them.
option_b: It would have no effect on oncoming drivers.
option_c: It could enable them to see the vehicle more clearly.
option_d: They could mistake the vehicle for a motorcycle.
explanation: Motor vehicles (except motorcycles) are required by law to have two headlights. A vehicle with only one headlight could be mistaken for a motorcycle and other road users could believe that it is in a different position on the road than it actually is. Vehicle lights should be checked on a regular basis and repair faulty lighting immediately.

question_text: What specific observations should a driver make before reversing a vehicle fitted with an external audible warning device?
option_a: No specific observations needed, as bystanders will be aware of the vehicle.
option_b: Observations should be made by opening the driver's door and looking behind.
option_c: Observations should be made to the front, sides and rear of the vehicle, including blind spots.
option_d: Observations should be made only in blind spots.
explanation: Drivers should not rely solely on an external audible warning device to warn others that their vehicle is reversing. Before reversing, drivers must make sure it is safe to do so by taking all appropriate observations to the front, sides and rear of the vehicle, including the blind spots. Never assume it is safe to reverse just because the vehicle has an external audible warning device.

question_text: When a vehicle is stopped in a tunnel due to congestion what should a driver do?
option_a: Keep the engine ticking over in a low gear.
option_b: Switch on the fog lights.
option_c: Switch off the engine.
option_d: Only give hand signals.
explanation: If, when driving a vehicle through a tunnel, you are halted in stationary traffic for any length of time, you should switch off the engine to reduce fumes in the tunnel and conserve fuel.

question_text: What should a driver do if the right-hand headlight bulb fails when driving at night?
option_a: Drive with the hazard lights on.
option_b: Replace it temporarily with the brake light bulb.
option_c: Replace it temporarily with the left-hand headlight bulb.
option_d: Have the bulb replaced immediately.
explanation: Vehicles (except motorcycles) are required by law to have right and left headlights. Faulty lights should be repaired immediately. A vehicle with only one headlight can cause a hazard to other road users or be mistaken for a motorcycle.

question_text: When must the holder of a learner permit display L-plates on their car?
option_a: When driving to and from work.
option_b: When driving on their first learner permit.
option_c: During daylight hours.
option_d: At all times when driving.
explanation: The holder of a learner permit must display L-plates on the front and rear of their car at all times when driving on public roads.

question_text: What should a driver do to secure the towing vehicle before unhitching a trailer?
option_a: Lower the jockey wheel and then switch off the ignition.
option_b: Disconnect the electrical supply to the trailer lights and lower the jockey wheel.
option_c: Apply the handbrake, lower the jockey wheel and switch off the engine.
option_d: Apply the handbrake, switch off the ignition and engage a low gear.
explanation: Before unhitching a trailer, apply the handbrake, switch off the ignition and engage a lower gear, so that the towing vehicle does not move while you are unhitching the trailer.

question_text: When attaching a trailer to their vehicle, what must a driver check?
option_a: That the trailer has a spare wheel.
option_b: That the load is evenly spread.
option_c: That the load is positioned to the front of the trailer.
option_d: That the load is positioned to the rear of the trailer.
explanation: Proper weight distribution helps to ensure the stability of both the towing vehicle and the trailer. In the trailer, the bulk of the load should be over the axles. If a heavy load is positioned at the front of the trailer, this will result in too much nose weight on the hitch of the towing vehicle and make it difficult to steer. If a heavy load is positioned at the rear of the trailer, this will result in reduced weight on the rear axle of the towing vehicle, which will make it more unstable.

question_text: When should children be allowed to drive a tractor?
option_a: When it is being driven at very slow speeds and not towing a trailer.
option_b: Children should never be allowed to drive a tractor.
option_c: When accompanied by a fully licensed driver.
option_d: When it is being driven at very slow speeds and without a front loader.
explanation: Persons under 16 years of age are not permitted to drive a tractor in a public place.

question_text: When a vehicle is stopped in a tunnel due to congestion what should a driver do?
option_a: Keep close to the vehicle in front.
option_b: Switch on hazard warning lights.
option_c: Switch off the engine and leave the vehicle.
option_d: Walk to the nearest emergency exit.
explanation: If, when driving a vehicle through a tunnel, you meet traffic congestion, leave a safe distance between you and the vehicle in front and switch on your hazard warning lights when stationary.

question_text: How would a driver calculate the maximum overall permitted weight of their vehicle?
option_a: By checking the unladen weight of the vehicle.
option_b: By adding the unladen weight of the vehicle to the load permitted to be carried.
option_c: By calculating the unladen weight of the vehicle plus the weight of the fuel.
option_d: By checking the weight of the load which may be carried.
explanation: The maximum permitted weight of a vehicle is the sum of the unladen weight of the vehicle plus the maximum load that may be carried in it. It is an offence to overload a vehicle, as it reduces your ability to control it effectively.

question_text: What effect can wet weather have on the vehicle's exterior mirrors?
option_a: It has no effect.
option_b: It can short-circuit the electrically heated mirrors.
option_c: It can keep them clean.
option_d: It can distort the rear vision of the driver.
explanation: When driving in the rain, water droplets can adhere to the exterior mirrors and obscure the driver''s view to the side and rear of the vehicle. If the vehicle has heated mirrors, turn them on to clear them. Alternatively, stop periodically to clear them manually.

question_text: What lights should be shown on a parked car, tractor or works vehicle at night on an unlit public road?
option_a: At least one side lamp front and rear on the side nearest the kerb.
option_b: Dipped headlights.
option_c: Tail lights only.
option_d: At least one side lamp front and rear on the side nearest the centre of the road.
explanation: When leaving a vehicle on an unlit public road at night this creates a potential danger for other road users. Drivers should therefore leave side/parking lights on, so that the vehicle can be seen by other road users. Drivers should not leave headlights on when parked as this may cause other road users to become disoriented.

question_text: How can sunlight affect visibility in a car with grimy windows?
option_a: It can enhance visibility.
option_b: It can seriously reduce visibility.
option_c: It can cause objects to seem further away than they are.
option_d: It can cause objects to seem closer than they are.
explanation: It is essential that all vehicle windows are clear and clean at all times so that drivers can see road and traffic conditions all around. Dirty windows are a particular hazard when the sun is low in the sky. Dirty windows also decrease visibility during hours of twilight and darkness.

question_text: When is a red flag a sufficient marker for a rear load overhang that exceeds one metre?
option_a: Only during the day.
option_b: At no time.
option_c: At all times.
option_d: Only during the night.
explanation: During daylight hours, you must use a red flag to mark any load that is protruding more than one metre. At night, you must use a red light.

question_text: What should a driver do if they intend to reverse their vehicle into an area which they cannot see?
option_a: Open driver's door and look behind.
option_b: Look in nearside (left) mirror when reversing.
option_c: Ask someone to guide you when reversing.
option_d: Open driver's window and look behind.
explanation: Do not attempt to reverse into an area that you cannot see into properly. You should get assistance from somebody who can guide you safely into the area.

question_text: What should a driver do in order to keep alert during a long journey?
option_a: Increase speed to shorten the journey.
option_b: Turn up the heater to maintain driver comfort.
option_c: Keep the radio turned on and windows closed.
option_d: Increase the air circulation and stop if necessary.
explanation: While on a long journey, a driver should take regular rest breaks. A short walk and a caffeinated drink (tea or coffee) can help to revive them. The vehicle should be kept cool and well ventilated with a steady flow of fresh air.

question_text: What should a driver do if dazzled by headlights reflecting in the rear-view mirror of their car?
option_a: Use the night driving mode on their rear-view mirror.
option_b: Switch the lights off and on to remind the following driver to dip their lights.
option_c: Turn on the rear fog lights to signal to the following vehicle to turn off their headlights.
option_d: Adjust the mirror to reflect the light back towards the following driver.
explanation: If a driver is being dazzled by the lights of following traffic, they should adjust their rear-view mirror to the night driving mode. This will allow them to concentrate on the road ahead and not be distracted by lights from following traffic.

question_text: What is the immediate effect of a head-on collision between two cars at speed?
option_a: All persons in each vehicle are thrown violently backwards only.
option_b: Only rear seatbelts will activate.
option_c: All persons in each vehicle are thrown violently forward.
option_d: Only front seatbelts will activate.
explanation: In a head-on collision passengers in both vehicles are propelled forwards, and if they are not wearing seatbelts they may go through the windscreen. It is the drivers responsibility to ensure that all passengers under the age of 17 wear seatbelts. Older passengers are themselves responsible for wearing seatbelts.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down in a tunnel?
option_a: Wait in the vehicle until help arrives.
option_b: Use the emergency telephone to call for help.
option_c: Walk to the end of the tunnel and call the GardaÌ_.
option_d: Flag down a passing motorist and ask for help.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down or is involved in a collision in a tunnel, switch on your hazard warning lights, switch off your engine, go to an emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator.

question_text: What should a driver do before towing a caravan?
option_a: Have an extended mirror fitted to the driver's side of the vehicle only.
option_b: Have extended mirrors fitted to the towing vehicle.
option_c: Ensure that only adult passengers are seated in the caravan.
option_d: Ensure all passengers are securely seated in the caravan.
explanation: If a driver intends towing a caravan, they should fit extended mirrors to both sides of the towing vehicle. This will allow the driver to better observe the traffic situation behind and to the sides.

question_text: Where should L-plates be displayed on cars?
option_a: Both front and rear.
option_b: On the rear only.
option_c: On the driver's side only.
option_d: On the front only.
explanation: The holder of a learner permit must display L-plates on the front and rear of their car at all times when driving on public roads.

question_text: What should a driver do if the vehicle's windows and mirrors are covered in ice?
option_a: Switch on the heating system and use a scraper to clear the ice before driving.
option_b: Switch on the windscreen wipers.
option_c: Use boiling water with salt to clear the ice.
option_d: Drive at a reduced speed until the heating system has cleared the ice.
explanation: Make sure all the windows and mirrors are completely clear of ice so that the driver can safely observe road and traffic conditions all around. This is especially important when driving in slippery conditions. It is good practice to carry a can of de-icer in the vehicle and if possible to fill the washer reservoir with a de-icing agent.

question_text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?
option_a: Doctor on call.
option_b: Mountain rescue.
option_c: Ambulance.
option_d: Breakdown recovery.
explanation: In the course of their duty GardaÌ_, Fire Brigade and ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be extra careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

question_text: If the vehicle''s windows are covered with ice, what should the driver do?
option_a: Fully clear ice from all windows.
option_b: Use boiling water to clear the ice.
option_c: Clear enough space in the windscreen to be able to see ahead.
option_d: Drive slowly until the heater and demister have cleared the ice.
explanation: Make sure all the windows are completely clear of ice so that the driver can safely observe road and traffic conditions all around. This is especially important when driving in slippery conditions. It is good practice to carry a can of de-icer in the vehicle and if possible to fill the washer reservoir with a de-icing agent.

question_text: How should a driver negotiate a bend when driving a fully loaded vehicle?
option_a: At a faster speed than when empty.
option_b: At the same speed as when empty.
option_c: By taking the bend more sharply than when empty.
option_d: At a slower speed than when empty.
explanation: Driving too fast on the approach to a bend and while driving through it with a fully loaded vehicle can lead to a loss of control. This can be prevented by driving in a safe and sensible manner and by reading the road ahead.

question_text: What is the maximum authorised mass (MAM) of a car that may be driven by the holder of a Category B driving licence?
option_a: 4,000 kilograms.
option_b: 3,500 kilograms.
option_c: 3,750 kilograms.
option_d: 3,000 kilograms.
explanation: The holder of a Category B driving licence is not permitted to drive a vehicle with a MAM of more than 3,500 kg. This restriction is noted on the licence.

question_text: When should the handbrake be used to bring a vehicle to a halt?
option_a: Only when going uphill.
option_b: Only when going downhill.
option_c: At any time.
option_d: Normally never.
explanation: In general the handbrake should never be used to bring a vehicle to a halt. This practice is potentially dangerous, as the rear wheels could lock up and the vehicle could skid out of control. In addition, using the handbrake does not operate the rear brake lights to warn following traffic.

question_text: What is the danger associated with applying the handbrake (parking brake) when the vehicle is moving?
option_a: The wheels could lock and cause the vehicle to skid.
option_b: The engine will stall once the handbrake is applied at speed.
option_c: The ABS could disconnect and cause the vehicle to skid.
option_d: There is no danger - the vehicle will not skid as the handbrake can be released quickly.
