explanation: Except in an emergency, the handbrake (parking brake) should never be used when the vehicle is moving. This practice is potentially dangerous, as the wheels could lock up and the vehicle could skid out of control. In addition there is no warning to following traffic from the brake lights.

question_text: What is the maximum number of passengers that may be carried in a vehicle driven by the holder of a Category B driving licence?
option_a: 9 passengers.
option_b: 10 passengers.
option_c: 7 passengers.
option_d: 8 passengers.
explanation: The holder of a Category B driving licence is not permitted to drive a vehicle that has seating for more than 8 passengers excluding the driver.

question_text: Generally what lighting must a car, tractor or works vehicle have when driving?
option_a: Headlights and a reversing light.
option_b: Headlights, number plate and rear reflectors only.
option_c: Headlights, brake lights and indicators only
option_d: Headlights, front and rear side lights, rear number plate light, red rear reflectors, brake lights and indicators.
explanation: In general all cars, tractors and works vehicles are required by law to have headlights, front and rear side lights, rear number plate light, rear reflectors, brake lights and indicators. There are some exceptions to this, such as Electric cars with a maximum speed of 38 km/h.

question_text: What should a driver do when they intend to reverse into a side road?
option_a: Angle the door mirrors down before reversing.
option_b: Focus totally on the left side door mirror while reversing.
option_c: Check carefully all around before and during the reverse.
option_d: Open the left side door fully to look behind.
explanation: Before and while reversing into a side road, check all around to make sure it is safe and clear to carry out the manoeuvre, paying particular attention to pedestrians crossing behind the vehicle and any other road users.

question_text: What should a driver do when there are dark clouds and visibility is reduced during daylight hours?
option_a: Drive with main beam headlights switched on.
option_b: Keep close to any vehicle in front with headlights off.
option_c: Driver should not switch on lights until lighting up hours.
option_d: Drive with dipped headlights switched on.
explanation: Drivers need to see and be seen during all periods of low light levels - for example, at dusk and dawn and in some bad weather conditions. At times of low light, you should turn on dipped headlights.

question_text: What should a driver do if condensation is affecting the vehicle's windows?
option_a: Make sure that all demister vents and windows are closed.
option_b: Wipe the windows with the back of the hand.
option_c: Dry the windows with a cloth and then use the demister system.
option_d: Drive for a few kilometres with a window open.
explanation: Make sure the windows are clear and clean at all times so that the driver can see the road and traffic conditions all around. Condensation on the window can seriously impair your ability to make proper observations. Drivers should familiarise themselves with how to correctly set the vehicle's ventilation system in order to keep the windows clear.

question_text: What is the maximum gross weight of a vehicle that may be driven by the holder of a Category B driving licence?
option_a: 3,500 kilograms
option_b: 3,450 kilograms
option_c: 3,250 kilograms
option_d: 3,000 kilograms
explanation: The holder of a Category B driving licence is not permitted to drive a vehicle with a design gross vehicle weight of more than 3,500 kg. This restriction is noted on the licence.

question_text: When driving on a hill, how should a steep descent be negotiated in snow or frosty weather?
option_a: Engage a higher gear than normal in order to avoid wheel-spin.
option_b: Always keep close to the left and use short, sharp brake applications to keep the speed down.
option_c: Keep the clutch depressed and use gentle braking.
option_d: Engage a lower gear early and use gentle braking applications to keep the speed down.
explanation: In snow or ice, a vehicle takes longer to stop. Before starting a steep descent in a large vehicle, the driver should reduce speed and select a lower gear, brake gently and only when needed. If the vehicle is fitted with a manually selectable retarder, engage it before starting the descent.

question_text: Before entering a tunnel, what should a driver do in order to improve vision?
option_a: Drive close to the vehicle in front.
option_b: Take off sunglasses.
option_c: Pull down the visor to eliminate overhead light glare.
option_d: Wear sunglasses to prevent glare from the lights.
explanation: Be aware that there is considerably less light available in a tunnel, even with the tunnel lights on. To improve your vision remove your sunglasses before entering the tunnel.

question_text: What can a driver do to stay alert on a long journey?
option_a: Roll down the window and allow fresh air in.
option_b: Turn up the temperature in the vehicle.
option_c: Stop, park in a safe place and have a cup of coffee.
option_d: Listen attentively to the radio.
explanation: If a driver continues to drive fighting sleep it can be the same as being over the drink driving limit. Stopping the vehicle in a safe place, drinking caffeine and taking a nap for 15 minutes will revive the driver allowing them to continue for a short period.

question_text: What danger could be associated with driving a tractor and trailer over a humpbacked bridge?
option_a: The trailer's parking brake could automatically engage.
option_b: The trailer could become detached
option_c: The tractor's suspension could smooth out the bump.
option_d: The trailer could jack-knife.
explanation: Before towing a trailer, a driver should ensure that the tow hitch has sufficient ground clearance. If this hits the road, for example when travelling over a humpbacked bridge, there is a danger that the trailer will become detached. Drivers should also plan and carry out their journey with an awareness of this risk.

question_text: What should a driver do if dazzled by lights at night reflecting in their interior mirror?
option_a: Temporarily adjust the angle of the mirror.
option_b: Switch on hazard lights.
option_c: Switch on the rear fog lights.
option_d: Adjust the mirror to reflect the light back towards the following driver.
explanation: If the lights of following traffic reflecting in your interior mirror are dazzling you, activate the night driving/anti dazzle mode. If the vehicle is not equipped with this feature drivers should temporarily adjust the angle of the interior mirror to relieve the glare and allow them to drive without distraction.

question_text: If a vehicle being driven through a tunnel goes on fire, what should the driver do?
option_a: Leave the vehicle immediately and use the emergency phone at the nearest emergency station.
option_b: Drive to the nearest emergency exit as quickly as possible.
option_c: Stay in the vehicle and phone the emergency station to report the fire.
option_d: Wait for the tunnel traffic radio to announce the fire drill.
explanation: If there is smoke or fire in the vehicle, switch off the engine, leave the vehicle immediately, go to the emergency station and use the emergency phone to alert the tunnel operator and leave the tunnel by the nearest available exit.

question_text: When can the holder of a Category W learner permit carry a passenger?
option_a: Only when the passenger holds a Category AM driving licence.
option_b: Only when the passenger also holds a Category W driving licence.
option_c: Only when the passenger holds a Category AM driving licence and the vehicle is designed to carry a passenger.
option_d: Only when the passenger also holds a Category W driving licence and the vehicle is designed to carry a passenger.
explanation: The holder of a Category W learner permit may carry a passenger in the vehicle only if: the vehicle is designed to take a passenger, and the passenger has held a full driving licence in Category W for two or more years.

question_text: When is a driver allowed to carry more passengers in a car than there are seat belts available?
option_a: It is always allowed.
option_b: When the driver's visibility is not interfered with.
option_c: It is never allowed.
option_d: When the driver has the appropriate insurance cover.
explanation: A driver must make sure that each passenger in the vehicle has a seatbelt. Failure to wear a seatbelt is an offence. It is the drivers responsibility to ensure that passengers under the age of 17 wear seatbelts. Older passengers are themselves responsible for wearing seatbelts

question_text: When should rear fog lights be used?
option_a: Only in light fog.
option_b: Always when driving at night in an unlit area.
option_c: In dense fog or falling snow.
option_d: When the vehicle behind is too close.
explanation: A driver must only use rear fog lights in dense fog or falling snow. Using fog lights in normal road and weather conditions can dazzle or blind following motorists. Also, fog lights may make brake lights harder to see.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle breaks down on an automatic railway level crossing?
option_a: Walk along the track to give warning to any approaching trains.
option_b: Turn on the warning bells at the crossing.
option_c: Get passengers clear of the crossing and phone the signal operator so that trains can be stopped.
option_d: Try to push the vehicle clear of the crossing as soon as possible.
explanation: In this situation, you and all passengers should get out of the vehicle and immediately use the emergency phone at the crossing to contact the signal operator so that trains can be stopped. If necessary, warn other motorists. Do not return to the vehicle until instructed by the signal operator or emergency services.

question_text: When towing a high and wide-bodied trailer what should a driver do?
option_a: Drive with a red flag at the rear left of the trailer.
option_b: Make use of extended mirrors to check for following traffic.
option_c: Drive with hazard warning lights flashing at all times.
option_d: Drive with a red flag to the front right-hand side of the trailer.
explanation: When towing a high and wide-bodied trailer, a driver should use extended mirrors on both sides of the towing vehicle. This will allow the driver to better observe the traffic situation behind and to the sides.

question_text: What is the likely effect of motorists ‰Û÷rubbernecking' at the scene of a traffic incident?
option_a: It can cause additional incidents as drivers become distracted.
option_b: It can increase traffic flow near an incident.
option_c: It allows traffic to change course without attention.
option_d: It allows traffic to change speed without attention.
explanation: When approaching or being near to the scene of an incident, motorists are often seen ‰Û÷rubbernecking''. This means turning your head and stretching your neck to get a better view of what''s happening. It can be the cause of traffic jams as drivers slow down to ‰Û÷rubberneck''. It can also cause road incidents as drivers become distracted and change their speed and/or direction while other drivers are also distracted.

question_text: What precautions could a driver take against the risk of fire in their vehicle?
option_a: Use low-octane unleaded petrol in the vehicle.
option_b: Keep all water levels filled to the maximum at all times.
option_c: Carry a suitable fire extinguisher in the vehicle.
option_d: Avoid driving the vehicle with a full tank of fuel.
explanation: A strong smell of fuel is usually an indication that something is wrong, and you should stop and investigate as soon as possible. Leaking or spilling petrol can be dangerous because it is so combustible. It is good practice to carry a fire extinguisher in your vehicle, so that you can deal with any small fires

question_text: What action should a driver take when they meet a vehicle with flashing blue lights?
option_a: Flash the headlights and come to an immediate stop.
option_b: Move to the left, reduce speed and stop if necessary.
option_c: Switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights.
option_d: Flash the headlights and drive up onto the footpath on the left.
explanation: When a driver notices an emergency vehicle approaching in the distance, they should check their mirror and move to the left to allow the vehicle to pass. On some occasions it may be necessary to stop.

question_text: What should a driver do when they see road works machinery with amber flashing lights up ahead?
option_a: Slow down and engage 1st gear.
option_b: Do a U-turn, as the road ahead is blocked.
option_c: Continue at the same speed along the road.
option_d: Slow down and prepare to stop if necessary.
explanation: When you notice works vehicles ahead, slow down and be prepared to stop for the road works. Be extra careful driving through road works as the road surface could be uneven or slippery.

question_text: How are emergency vehicles identified?
option_a: By continuously lit red lights.
option_b: By flashing green lights.
option_c: By flashing red or blue lights.
option_d: By flashing amber and white lights.
explanation: If you hear or see an emergency vehicle approaching sounding its siren or flashing lights, be extra careful and give way if it is safe to do so.

question_text: Can a driver break a red light or break the speed limit to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass?
option_a: Yes, a driver may legally break a red light to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
option_b: No except where the junction or road is clear, then a driver can break a red light or speed up to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
option_c: Yes, a driver may break the speed limit to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
option_d: No, a driver should never break a red light or speed up to allow an emergency service vehicle to pass.
explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

question_text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?
option_a: Breakdown recovery.
option_b: Doctor on call.
option_c: Mountain rescue.
option_d: Garda.
explanation: In the course of their duty GardaÌ_, Fire Brigade and ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be extra careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle gets a puncture on a motorway?
option_a: Stop in the traffic lane and switch on the hazard warning lights.
option_b: Drive on to the next service area and get assistance.
option_c: Stop in the hard shoulder and get a passenger to warn traffic.
option_d: Pull in where safe on the hard shoulder and call for assistance.
explanation: Don''t try to change a wheel on a motorway, as this could be very dangerous. Drive the car on to the hard shoulder, and when it is safe to do so, get out of the vehicle and move behind the barrier. Call for assistance from a motorway emergency phone or using a mobile phone (call the GardaÌ_).

question_text: How should a driver react to emergency services vehicles with flashing blue lights and/or sirens on?
option_a: Check their mirrors before looking for space to move aside.
option_b: Only move aside if it is an ambulance.
option_c: Mount kerb on offside of the road to make room.
option_d: Brake suddenly and stop to avoid causing obstruction.
explanation: If you see any emergency vehicle approaching with lights and/or sirens activated, check your rear view mirrors to gauge the speed of the emergency vehicle/s and also look out for pedestrians, cyclists, motorcyclists and other road users. Indicate your intention to pull over. Pull over only in a space that has enough space for the emergency vehicle/s to pass safely. Move off safely with appropriate observations and signals after the emergency vehicle has passed.

question_text: When should a driver use hazard warning lights on a motorway?
option_a: When driving on the hard shoulder.
option_b: When the vehicle has broken down.
option_c: When another vehicle is following too closely.
option_d: When the vehicle is towing a trailer.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on a motorway, drive it to the hard shoulder and switch on the hazard warning lights to warn following traffic. When it is safe to do so, get out of the vehicle and move behind the barrier. Call for assistance from a motorway emergency phone or using a mobile phone (call the GardaÌ_).

question_text: What should a driver never do when an emergency service vehicle approaches with flashing blue lights?
option_a: Pull over in a place which has enough space for the emergency service vehicle to pass safely.
option_b: Brake suddenly or block the road.
option_c: React quickly, safely and carefully to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
option_d: Clear the way as soon as possible.
explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

question_text: Which vehicle is exempt from speed limits when being used in an emergency?
option_a: Fire brigade.
option_b: Mountain rescue.
option_c: Breakdown recovery.
option_d: Doctor on call.
explanation: In the course of their duty GardaÌ_, Fire Brigade and ambulance personnel are exempt from some traffic laws including speed limits, as long as they do not put other road users in danger. If you hear or see a Garda or emergency vehicle approaching under emergency conditions, be extra careful and give way, if it is safe to do so.

question_text: What should a driver do if a front tyre bursts while driving?
option_a: Relax the hold on the steering wheel.
option_b: Grip the steering wheel firmly.
option_c: Brake firmly and quickly.
option_d: Apply the handbrake immediately.
explanation: If a front tyre bursts on a vehicle, the steering on the vehicle will become unstable. Don''t panic - slow down gradually while keeping a firm hold on the steering wheel. Stop in a safe place to change the wheel, and alert other road users by switching on your hazard warning lights.

question_text: When driving behind a heavy goods vehicle that is signalling to turn right, what should a driver do?
option_a: See if the vehicle can complete the turn without stopping, and if not, overtake it yourself.
option_b: Sound the horn and overtake the heavy goods vehicle on the right.
option_c: Overtake it slowly on the inside by driving partly on the footpath if necessary.
option_d: Stay behind until there is sufficient space to overtake it on the inside or until it has completed the turn.
explanation: Heavy goods vehicles need extra space on the road, and when they are turning the overhang of the vehicle may swing out into the path of overtaking or passing traffic. For that reason, it is a good idea to stay back and let the heavy goods vehicle complete its turn unless there is sufficient space to overtake safely.

question_text: What should a driver do if an ambulance is stopped up ahead with its flashing blue lights on?
option_a: Reduce speed and prepare to stop if necessary.
option_b: Stop immediately to see what is happening.
option_c: Stop and offer assistance
option_d: Move to the centre of the road to stop other vehicles from overtaking.
explanation: When you come upon an emergency vehicle stopped on the road, you should slow down and be prepared to stop. Do not stop to see what is happening as this could be dangerous and you might cause an obstruction to the flow of traffic.

question_text: What can cause a vehicle to skid?
option_a: Stopping in fourth gear.
option_b: Excessive heavy braking.
option_c: Coasting to a stop.
option_d: Controlled acceleration.
explanation: Heavy braking can cause a vehicle to skid, particularly if the road surface is wet or uneven, or if the tyres are worn or incorrectly inflated. Read the road well ahead and try to avoid heavy braking, particularly in wet or slippery conditions.

question_text: What should a driver do if their vehicle is broken down on a motorway and they are awaiting assistance?
option_a: Stand out on the roadway and direct traffic to pass.
option_b: Try to flag down other traffic from the rear of the vehicle for assistance.
option_c: Get out of the vehicle and wait at the rear of it.
option_d: Switch on the vehicle hazard warning lights, get out of the vehicle and stand safely to the side.
explanation: If your vehicle breaks down on the road, always switch on the hazard warning lights and stand clear of the vehicle while awaiting assistance - this will warn other traffic that there is a vehicle stopped on the road.

question_text: What should a driver do when an emergency service vehicle approaches with flashing blue lights?
option_a: Increase speed to prevent obstructing the emergency service vehicle.
option_b: Brake suddenly to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
option_c: Do nothing and ignore the emergency service vehicle.
option_d: React quickly, safely and carefully to allow the emergency service vehicle to pass.
explanation: A driver needs to know what to do when they see an emergency vehicle. A driver must react quickly, safely and carefully to allow emergency service vehicles to pass. It is important to be alert and attentive at all times.

question_text: What does worn tread along the edge of the inside of a tyre suggest?
option_a: Air pressure is low.
option_b: Steering alignment may be faulty.
option_c: Air pressure is high.
option_d: The vehicle has been driven too fast around corners.
explanation: If a driver notices the inside edge of the tyre is worn, this may indicate a problem with the steering alignment. This is a potentially dangerous problem, and should be fixed by a competent person as soon as possible. Failure to do so may result in a blow-out and loss of control of the vehicle.

question_text: What should a driver do before checking the engine oil level on a vehicle?
option_a: Make sure that the engine is switched on and hot.
option_b: Make sure that the engine is switched off and cold.
option_c: Make sure that the vehicle is in a low gear.
option_d: Make sure that the engine is running.
explanation: Drivers need a basic knowledge of the regular checks that should be carried out on their vehicle. Checking the engine oil level is important - do this with the vehicle parked on level ground with the engine switched off and cold for a more accurate reading. Refer to the vehicle handbook for further information and guidance.

question_text: How should a child restraint system be fitted in a vehicle?
option_a: It should be fitted in accordance with the manufacturers instructions.
option_b: It should be placed on the floor.
option_c: It should be left unsecured.
option_d: It should be placed on a front passenger seat only.
explanation: It is recommended to fit the child seat correctly, according to the manufacturers instructions, it is safer to fit the seat in the back seat of the car and to buy a child car seat only from a retailer who will check that it fits both the car and the child.

question_text: What is the effect of an incorrectly adjusted driver's seat?
option_a: It improves the driver's ability to operate the clutch.
option_b: It enables the driver to relax more on a long journey.
option_c: It gives the driver a better view in the rear-view mirror.
option_d: It can delay the driver from operating a control.
explanation: Before starting a journey, you should adopt a suitable and comfortable driving position by adjusting the drivers seat to a position where all the vehicle controls can be operated efficiently.

question_text: What is an effect of under-inflated tyres on a vehicle?
option_a: Improved fuel economy and braking.
option_b: Improved braking and steering.
option_c: Impaired braking and steering.
option_d: Increased wear on the vehicle's engine.
explanation: Drivers should check their vehicle''s tyre pressures (including the spare) regularly at least once a week. Under-inflated tyres adversely affect many of a vehicle''s systems, including braking ability, suspension, steering, fuel consumption and premature tyre wear. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturers guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

question_text: When a wiper blade fails to clear the windscreen what should the driver do?
option_a: Have the wiper blades replaced as soon as possible.
option_b: Bend the wiper arm to apply more pressure on the windscreen.
option_c: Apply a light film of oil to both of the wiper blades.
option_d: Switch the wiper control from high speed to low speed repeatedly.
explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

question_text: What effect does automatic transmission have on engine braking power?
option_a: It increases it.
option_b: It transfers the braking ability to the handbrake.
option_c: It reduces it.
option_d: Its transfers the braking ability to all the wheels.
explanation: When driving an automatic vehicle, it may not slow at the same rate as a vehicle with a manual gearbox when the driver releases the accelerator. Drivers should be aware of this, as they may need to apply the brake earlier in order to stop where required.

question_text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a child wears a child restraint system in a vehicle?
option_a: The driver only.
option_b: Any adult passenger.
option_c: The parents of the child only.
option_d: The child, if over 12 years of age.
explanation: Where the passenger is over the age of 17 and travelling in a car it is their legal responsibility to comply with the child restraint regulations. Below that age, it is the drivers responsibility.

question_text: Why should the valve be replaced when having a tubeless tyre fitted?
option_a: To ensure the tyre will remain inflated.
option_b: To ensure the wheel remains aligned.
option_c: To ensure the wheel nuts remain tight.
option_d: To ensure the wheel remains balanced.
explanation: When fitting a new tubeless tyre to a vehicle it is recommended to change the valve. This is because the old valve has been on the wheel since the old tyre was fitted. The old valve may break down, leak or cause air to escape.

question_text: If driving a vehicle with automatic transmission, what in particular should a driver be aware of?
option_a: That driving on a motorway is not permitted.
option_b: That engine braking power is reduced.
option_c: That the gear box may overheat while being driven in low gear.
option_d: That wheel-spin occurs more often.
explanation: When driving an automatic vehicle, it may not slow at the same rate as a vehicle with a manual gearbox when the driver releases the accelerator. Drivers should be aware of this, as they may need to apply the brake earlier in order to stop where required.

question_text: Under what circumstances would a driver increase the air pressure in the tyres?
option_a: When taking a journey with additional passengers.
option_b: When the journey exceeds 200 km.
option_c: When higher speeds are anticipated on motorway driving.
option_d: When the tread depth on the tyres is below 2 mm.
explanation: Before starting a journey with extra passengers or loads, drivers should check the air pressure and when they inflate the tyres, they should increase the vehicles tyre pressures in accordance with the vehicle manufacturers recommended tyre pressure. This information can be found in the vehicle manufacturers handbook.

question_text: What lighting must be on a tractors trailer during lighting-up hours?
option_a: An unloading light.
option_b: Brake lights and indicators only.
option_c: Indicators, two white or yellow headlamps and rear number plate lights only.
option_d: Indicators, brake lights, rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.
explanation: A trailer being towed by a tractor must have rear indicators, brake lights, a rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights whilst being towed on a public road.

question_text: How is a learner driver likely to react in unusual traffic situations?
option_a: Slower than an experienced driver.
option_b: Quicker than an experienced driver.
option_c: Better than an experienced driver.
option_d: In the same way as an experienced driver.
explanation: You should be patient when driving behind a learner driver. Learners may not anticipate and react to unusual traffic situations as well as an experienced driver might.

question_text: Is it permissible to drive a vehicle on a public road when the brake lights are not working?
option_a: Yes, during lighting-up times
option_b: Yes, outside of lighting-up times.
option_c: No, it is never permitted to be driven.
option_d: No, unless driving in a built-up area.
explanation: A driver must always ensure that their vehicles brake-lights are clean and working correctly before driving on a public road. Never drive a vehicle when the brake lights are not working properly.

question_text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger over 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?
option_a: The driver only.
option_b: The driver when the passenger is in the front seat.
option_c: The passenger only.
option_d: Both the driver and the passenger.
explanation: Where the passenger is over the age of 17 and travelling in a car it is their legal responsibility to comply with the seat belt regulations. Below that age, it is the drivers responsibility.

question_text: On a motorway, when should a driver use the hazard warning lights?
option_a: When towing another vehicle.
option_b: When another vehicle is following too closely.
option_c: When parked in the hard shoulder to take a phone call.
option_d: When the vehicle has broken down.
explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if your vehicle has broken down and is stopped on the hard shoulder, you can use the hazard warning lights to warn following vehicles of your presence.

question_text: What does blue smoke coming from the vehicle's exhaust generally mean?
option_a: The air filter needs to be replaced.
option_b: The catalytic converter is worn out.
option_c: The engine is burning oil.
option_d: The engine is overheating.
explanation: A vehicle can give off blue smoke from the exhaust when it is burning oil. Poor maintenance and worn engines are typical causes. This blue smoke is harmful to the environment and may be costly. Drivers should have the vehicle checked by a competent person.

question_text: When should tyre pressure be checked?
option_a: At service intervals only.
option_b: When the tyres are part-worn.
option_c: When the tyres are cold.
option_d: When the tyres are hot.
explanation: Drivers should check the tyre pressure in their vehicle at least once a week and before commencing a long journey. For accuracy, do this when the tyres are cold and using a reliable gauge. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturers guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

question_text: Under what circumstances could both cross-ply and radial tyres be fitted to a vehicle?
option_a: When heavy loads are being carried.
option_b: When each type is fitted on a different axle.
option_c: When driving in slippery road conditions.
option_d: When towing a trailer in snow.
explanation: In general, you should fit the same type of tyres all round the vehicle. However if you need to fit a mix of cross-ply and radials, the tyres on any axle should be of the same type.

question_text: What is the main reason for maintaining the correct tyre pressures?
option_a: To help provide optimum road holding.
option_b: To help maintain the correct ground clearance.
option_c: To stop the vehicle from sloping to the left.
option_d: To reduce engine wear.
explanation: The vehicle manufacturer specifies the pressure to which tyres on a vehicle should be inflated. This is the pressure that gives the best performance in road holding, efficient braking and fuel consumption. Some manufacturers specify different pressures for front and rear tyres.

question_text: What does this light mean?
option_a: The gear box is over-heating.
option_b: The engine is over-heating.
option_c: The oil level is too low.
option_d: The battery is not charging.
explanation: If the battery warning light comes on whilst driving, it means there is some kind of problem with the electrical charging system of the vehicle and the battery is not being charged properly. The driver should get this checked by a professional as soon as possible. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicles warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicles handbook.

question_text: If a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, what should a person do?
option_a: Turn on the full beam headlights to alert other drivers.
option_b: Place a red warning triangle on the motorway to warn other drivers.
option_c: Ask a passenger to stand on the road to warn other traffic.
option_d: Use a roadside phone to contact GardaÌ_ and never try to carry out repairs yourself.
explanation: When a vehicle breaks down on a motorway, a driver should move the vehicle to the hard shoulder, use the roadside phone to contact the GardaÌ_, and do not place a warning device on the motorway. The driver should never try to do repairs themselves in the hard shoulder.

question_text: What effect can a worn shock absorber have on a vehicle?
option_a: It can trigger the release of the airbags.
option_b: It can increase fuel consumption.
option_c: It can cause an electrical short-circuit.
option_d: It can cause the vehicle to ‰Û÷bounce' in an unstable manner.
explanation: A worn shock absorber can seriously affect the control of the vehicle especially on uneven surfaces or when cornering and can cause unnecessary wear and tear on tyres. It may increase stopping distance by not keeping the tyres in proper contact with the road under harsh braking.

question_text: What is the purpose of the red reflectors at the rear of a vehicle?
option_a: They are a substitute in case of brake-light failure.
option_b: They warn the driver behind to switch to main beam.
option_c: They warn pedestrians of the vehicle's location.
option_d: They reflect light at night to make other road users aware of the vehicle.
explanation: Motor vehicles are fitted with red reflectors to make it easier to be seen by other road users. Drivers should keep reflectors clean, intact and check them by shining a light on them to make sure that they are working effectively. Whilst driving, drivers should be cautious as red reflectors may be an indication of both parked/stationery or moving vehicles ahead.

question_text: What effect can wet weather have on a vehicle's exterior mirrors?
option_a: Water can cause a short-circuit in the electrically heated mirrors.
option_b: Water droplets can obscure the reflected image.
option_c: Water droplets can make the reflected object appear closer than it really is.
option_d: Water droplets help to keep them clean.
explanation: When driving in wet weather conditions, small water droplets can form on the glass of the exterior mirrors. This could make it more difficult to see the road behind and to the sides. Switch on the mirror demisters, if they are fitted. If necessary, stop and clear them.

question_text: What does the speed rating of a tyre indicate?
option_a: The maximum speed the vehicle can overtake at
option_b: The maximum speed for which the tyre is designed.
option_c: The minimum speed for which the tyre is designed.
option_d: The maximum speed the vehicle can be driven at.
explanation: The speed rating of a tyre is the maximum speed for which the tyre is designed. This relates to the speed capability of the tyre. It does not relate to the speed at which the tyre should or could legally be driven.

question_text: What is the most common cause of heavy steering?
option_a: Over-inflated tyres.
option_b: Badly worn brakes.
option_c: Poorly oiled steering.
option_d: Under-inflated tyres.
explanation: Heavy steering is when a driver needs to use more effort than usual to turn the steering wheel, this may be as a direct result of under-inflated tyres. Check your tyre pressures but be aware there may be other causes of heavy steering such as low power steering fluid level. Seek advice from a competent person and have this investigated immediately.

question_text: What is the purpose of a catalytic converter?
option_a: It increases engine power.
option_b: It decreases engine power.
option_c: It filters exhaust gases and reduces air pollution.
option_d: It allows the engine to quickly reach its normal operating temperature.
explanation: The purpose of a catalytic converter (CAT) is to remove toxic or polluting gases such as carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and unburned hydrocarbons from the exhaust emissions. When the CAT is faulty, an engine management warning light illuminates on the dashboard and drivers should seek advice from a competent person.

question_text: When is it recommended to use coolant?
option_a: Summer only.
option_b: Winter only.
option_c: In petrol engines only.
option_d: All year round.
explanation: The purpose of coolant is to keep the engine cool during operation. Coolant is usually a mixture of water and anti-freeze - this ensures that the engine is kept cool and that the coolant does not freeze in very cold weather.

question_text: Which of the following is a driver required to keep in good condition?
option_a: Radio.
option_b: Seatbelts.
option_c: Upholstery.
option_d: Paintwork.
explanation: Drivers are responsible for their vehicles roadworthiness and should check them at regular intervals. Among the checks they should make are that all the seatbelts (drivers and passengers) are clean, untangled and in good working order.

question_text: In general, how often should a driver check the tyre pressure of a vehicle?
option_a: Annually.
option_b: Six monthly.
option_c: Monthly.
option_d: Regularly.
explanation: Drivers have a legal responsibility to make sure that their vehicle is roadworthy. To do this, they should carry out regular, weekly and periodic checks, including a weekly tyre pressure check. Incorrectly inflated tyres may cause vehicle instability, uneven tyre wear and longer stopping distances.

question_text: What is the primary purpose of the battery fitted to a petrol - or diesel - powered motor vehicle?
option_a: To provide braking.
option_b: To reduce fuel consumption.
option_c: To provide heat to the engine.
option_d: To start the engine.
explanation: The primary purpose of the battery is to start the engine. When the engine is running, it produces its own electricity to charge the battery and run the various electrical components, including lights, heating, radio and so on.

question_text: How do you make sure your vehicle is parked safely?
option_a: Avoid reversing your vehicle into a space.
option_b: Don't park it where it may endanger other road users.
option_c: Park your vehicle opposite another vehicle on a narrow road.
option_d: Drive into parking space as quickly as possible.
explanation: When parking make sure you do not interfere with normal traffic flow and that your vehicle does not disturb, block or endanger other road users.

question_text: On a motorway, when should a driver use the hazard warning lights?
option_a: When driving on the hard shoulder.
option_b: When slowing down quickly because of danger ahead.
option_c: When another vehicle is following too closely.
option_d: When towing another vehicle.
explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if you have to slow down sharply because of a build-up of traffic ahead, you can use the hazard warning lights to warn following vehicles that they need to slow down.

question_text: What is the purpose of engine oil?
option_a: It lubricates the braking system.
option_b: It lubricates the exhaust system.
option_c: It lubricates the wheel bearings.
option_d: It lubricates the engine.
explanation: The purpose of engine oil is to lubricate and cool the moving parts of the engine. Refer to the vehicle handbook for further information and guidance.

question_text: What effect do the hazard warning lights have on the brake lights?
option_a: They cause the left and right brake lights to flash alternately.
option_b: They cause the brake lights to switch off completely.
option_c: They have no effect.
option_d: They cause the brake lights to flash repeatedly.
explanation: The hazard lights work independently of the other lights on the vehicle (except the direction indicators), and have no effect on the brake lights. Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead, when your vehicle is broken down and causing an obstruction, or when you needs to slow down sharply on a motorway.

question_text: A driver wishes to drive at night, but the off-side (right-hand side) headlight bulb is blown. What should the driver do?
option_a: Drive with the hazard lights on.
option_b: Not drive until the bulb is replaced.
option_c: Replace it temporarily with the near-side (left-hand side) bulb.
option_d: Replace it temporarily with the brake-light bulb.
explanation: A driver is responsible for their vehicles roadworthiness and they should check it at regular intervals. Drivers must not drive on the road unless their vehicles headlights are in good working order, adjusted properly and clean.

question_text: If the brake pedal of a vehicle feels soft or spongy when applied, what does this mean?
option_a: Worn brake pads.
option_b: The parking brake is on.
option_c: A fault in the hand-brake cable.
option_d: A fault in the brake fluid system.
explanation: If the brake pedal feels soft or spongy when pressed, it could indicate that the brake fluid level is low and there is a fault in the system. Each time a driver sets out on a journey, they should test the brakes. If a fault is detected, have it checked by a competent person. Drivers should check brake fluid levels regularly.

question_text: What does this light mean?
option_a: The headlight beam should be dipped.
option_b: The number plate light is faulty.
option_c: The high-beam headlights are switched on.
option_d: The reversing light is switched on.
explanation: All vehicles are fitted with warning lights to alert the driver to different things. This light comes on when the full beam headlights are turned on. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicles warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicles handbook.

question_text: What effect would a weak battery have on a vehicle's driving performance?
option_a: It would have no effect.
option_b: The headlights would not function.
option_c: The fuel would burn less efficiently.
option_d: Uphill acceleration would be reduced.
explanation: It might be difficult to start a car with a weak battery, but once the engine is running, it makes no difference. If the battery fails to charge or maintain its full charge seek advice from a competent person.

question_text: In general how regularly should a vehicle be serviced?
option_a: Every 30,000 kilometres.
option_b: Once every year.
option_c: Every 30 months.
option_d: As per the manufacturer's recommendation.
explanation: Drivers should have their vehicle serviced regularly in accordance with the manufacturers guidelines. This helps the vehicle to perform properly, and as a result saves fuel and reduces emissions. In addition, drivers should also carry out their own daily and weekly checks on fluid levels and tyres.

question_text: What does a rev counter provide information on?
option_a: Engine revolutions.
option_b: Heater-fan revolutions.
option_c: Wheel revolutions.
option_d: Wheel revolutions.
explanation: The rev counter measures the speed of the engine, in revolutions per minute. Generally, the higher the revs, the more fuel the engine is using, so drivers should keep an eye on the rev counter to help drive in a more eco-friendly manner.

question_text: If the vehicle''s oil-pressure gauge is reading low or the red oil-pressure warning light comes on, what should a driver do?
option_a: Drive at a faster pace to reach the destination before the oil runs out.
option_b: Drive in a low gear until the oil level is topped up.
option_c: Drive at lower speeds until the oil level is topped up.
option_d: Drive to a safe place, stop the vehicle and check the oil level.
explanation: Oil circulation is essential for the safe running of the vehicles engine. If the warning lights or gauges indicate that the oil or the oil-pressure is low, the driver should stop as soon as they can in safe place, check the oil level, and top up if necessary. Continuing to drive may damage the engine. If the problem is not just related to the oil level, have the vehicle checked by a competent person.

question_text: When a driver operates the indicator switch and hears a more rapid clicking noise than normal, what could this mean?
option_a: An indicator bulb may have blown.
option_b: The hazard warning lights are on.
option_c: The hazard warning light switch is faulty.
option_d: The voltage regulator is not functioning properly.
explanation: A rapid clicking noise when you turn on an indicator is usually a sign that one of the indicator bulbs has failed. Drivers are responsible for making sure that their vehicle is roadworthy. This should include a regular check that all lights, reflectors and indicators, are working properly.

question_text: While driving, the driver notices the vehicle temperature gauge showing red. What should they do?
option_a: Drive to the nearest service depot and top-up the water in the radiator.
option_b: Stop in a safe place and have the problem investigated.
option_c: Remove the filler cap from the radiator and check for leakage.
option_d: Do not drive until an anti-waxing agent is added to the coolant.
explanation: Many vehicles are fitted with various warning lights and gauges. A warning light or a red zone on a temperature gauge means the engine is starting to overheat and the vehicle should not be driven until the problem is rectified. Refer to the vehicle handbook for further information and guidance or seek advice from a competent person.

question_text: What may happen if the vehicle's engine oil is not changed as required?
option_a: The vehicle's fuel consumption may decrease.
option_b: The vehicle's fuel consumption may increase.
option_c: The engine may overheat.
option_d: Parts of the engine may suffer increased wear.
explanation: Engine oil becomes inefficient over time, losing its viscosity and lubricating qualities, and therefore must be changed as required in accordance with the manufacturer''s recommendations. Failure to do so may result in costly and extensive engine damage. The oil change is usually done when the vehicle is being serviced.

question_text: What may indicate a problem with the vehicle's braking system?
option_a: The vehicle's parking brake is more effective.
option_b: The vehicle's stopping ability is affected.
option_c: The vehicle's fuel consumption is reduced.
option_d: The vehicle's suspension is affected.
explanation: Drivers should test their brakes before setting out on a journey. If when driving they notice that it is taking longer than usual to bring the vehicle to a stop, they should have the brakes checked immediately by a competent person.

question_text: What should a driver do if a red system warning light lights up on the dashboard of their vehicle?
option_a: Stop and investigate the cause.
option_b: Drive to the nearest garage and have it checked.
option_c: Continue on and see if it goes out.
option_d: Continue on and listen for any unusual sounds.
explanation: If a red system warning light comes on while you are driving, you should stop in a safe place as soon as possible and investigate the problem before deciding what action to take. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicles warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicles handbook.

question_text: What should the driver be able to see in the vehicle mirrors when they are properly adjusted?
option_a: The passenger area of the vehicle.
option_b: The position of the left-side wheels.
option_c: The area behind and to each side of the vehicle.
option_d: The position of all the wheels.
explanation: Properly adjusted vehicle mirrors enable drivers to see the road behind and to the sides. This helps drivers to take into account what''s happening behind them, so that they can make informed, correct and safer decisions.

question_text: If the oil pressure gauge shows little or no pressure, or the warning light comes on, what could the problem be?
option_a: The oil level is too low.
option_b: The oil level is too high.
option_c: The oil is too cold.
option_d: The oil is too thick.
explanation: Drivers should check the oil level in their vehicle regularly, and if it is low, top it up. If it needs to be topped up very often, have the vehicle checked by a competent person to see if there is a problem.

question_text: What should the driver do to secure the vehicle when changing a front nearside (left-hand side) wheel?
option_a: Point the front wheels towards the kerb.
option_b: Point the front wheels away from the kerb.
option_c: Ensure that the vehicle cannot roll when jacked up.
option_d: Ensure the gear lever is in neutral.
explanation: If a driver has to change a front nearside (left-hand side) wheel, make sure to do it in a safe place on level ground. Take care, wear high visibility vest/jacket, use a warning triangle and hazard warning lights as appropriate. The vehicle should be secured by applying the parking brake (hand brake), switching off the engine, engaging a low gear and using a wheel chock if necessary. If unfamiliar with how to change a wheel seek assistance from a competent person.

question_text: What can be affected by driving on under-inflated tyres?
option_a: The exhaust system.
option_b: Braking ability.
option_c: Climate control system.
option_d: Engine temperature.
explanation: Under-inflated tyres may adversely affect many of the vehicle''s systems, including its braking ability, suspension, steering and fuel consumption. In particular, under-inflated tyres can affect the vehicle''s braking ability and can result in premature tyre wear. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturers guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

question_text: Whilst driving, why might a driver suspect that the brake fluid level in their vehicle is low?
option_a: The brakes feel spongy and soft.
option_b: The brakes feel hard to press.
option_c: The brakes are unusually sharp.
option_d: The brakes take longer than usual to release.
explanation: If the brake pedal feels soft or spongy when pressed, it could indicate that the brake fluid level is low and there is a fault in the system. Each time a driver sets out on a journey, they should test the brakes. If a fault is detected, have it checked by a competent person. Drivers should check brake fluid levels regularly.

question_text: How would a driver know that a brake-light bulb is not working?
option_a: They would notice the brake pedal getting softer under pressure.
option_b: They would notice the brake pedal become firmer under pressure.
option_c: By standing at the rear of the vehicle and getting another person to turn on side lights.
option_d: By standing at the rear of the vehicle and checking as another person presses the brake pedal.
explanation: In order for a driver to know that the rear brake lights are working correctly, they should stand at the rear of the vehicle and check that the brake lights come on while another person presses the brakes.

question_text: During a weekly check, a driver notices a badly worn front tyre. What should the driver do?
option_a: Fit the worn tyre on one of the rear wheels.
option_b: Have the worn tyre replaced.
option_c: Check the tyre pressure to ensure it remains constant.
option_d: Reduce speed when driving on wet roads.
explanation: The tyres are the vehicles only contact with the road, the area of contact is small and, if worn, will not grip properly and safely. The quality of the tyres on a vehicle is an important factor in the vehicles road holding and braking ability. Drivers should check their tyres regularly and if they notice that a tyre is badly worn, they should replace it immediately. Whilst the minimum legal tread depth for tyres on most vehicles is 1.6 mm (1 mm for motorcycles), drivers should replace a tyre before it becomes this worn.

question_text: What should a driver do to secure the vehicle before leaving it?
option_a: Leave the engine running with the parking brake on.
option_b: Apply the parking brake and switch off the engine.
option_c: Leave the engine running with the exhaust brake on.
option_d: Apply the exhaust brake and switch off the engine.
explanation: Before you leave your vehicle, apply the parking brake and switch off the ignition. Check to make sure that you can open the door safely without endangering others, and alight when it is safe to do so.

question_text: The vehicle's exterior mirrors are covered by a film of mud and dust. What should the driver do?
option_a: Drive in the slip stream of other traffic, as this will eventually clean the mirrors.
option_b: Angle the mirrors towards the front for a distance in order to clean them.
option_c: Clean them with a cloth or tissue before starting their journey.
option_d: Continue on and clean them after reaching the destination.
explanation: The purpose of mirrors is to increase the drivers view to the rear and sides of the vehicle and to enable them to take into account all visible hazards. Proper use will enable drivers to make informed, correct and safer decisions. Drivers should ensure that all mirrors, including the exterior ones, are clean and properly adjusted at all times to ensure optimum view.

question_text: What should a driver do if a system warning light lights up on the dashboard of their vehicle whilst driving?
option_a: Stop and check the problem.
option_b: Continue to drive and listen for any unusual sounds.
option_c: Continue for a distance to see if the light goes out.
option_d: Carry on and check the problem later.
explanation: If a system warning light lights up while you are driving, you should stop in a safe place as soon as possible and investigate the problem before deciding what action to take. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicles warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicles handbook.

question_text: In general, how should children under 3 years of age be secured in a vehicle?
option_a: They should always be carried in an adult's lap.
option_b: They should always sit on the rear passenger seat.
option_c: They should always be secured in the correct child seat.
option_d: They should always be placed in the front passenger seat wearing a seat belt.
explanation: Safety belts are designed mainly for adults and older children. Children under 3 years of age must be restrained in an appropriate child restraint system. Warning; Never use a rearward facing child car seat in a seat protected by an active frontal airbag.

question_text: What does the load index of a tyre indicate?
option_a: The maximum load of the vehicle.
option_b: The maximum air pressure of the tyre.
option_c: The maximum load per axle.
option_d: The maximum load a tyre can carry.
explanation: The load index indicates the maximum weight that a tyre can support safely. When replacing a tyre on your vehicle, you should make sure that the new tyre maintains the proper load index for the vehicle.

question_text: What does the warning light and/or red zone on a fuel gauge mean?
option_a: There is a leak in the fuel system.
option_b: The fuel tank has been over-filled.
option_c: There is leaded fuel in the tank.
option_d: The level of fuel in the tank is low.
explanation: Many vehicles are fitted with various warning lights and gauges. A red zone or a warning light on a fuel gauge means the vehicle is low in fuel and should be refuelled as soon as possible.

question_text: What does Anti-lock braking system (ABS) do?
option_a: ABS locks the brakes to prevent skidding during harsh braking.
option_b: ABS deploys the airbags during a collision.
option_c: ABS prevents the wheels from locking under harsh braking conditions.
option_d: ABS displays the name of the radio station playing on the car radio.
explanation: Anti-lock braking system (ABS) is a type of braking system found in most modern cars. It comes into play automatically when the driver brakes harshly. In the wet it can help prevent the wheels from skidding so that, if necessary, the driver can continue to steer while braking. Be aware that ABS does not reduce the braking distance.

question_text: In general, how frequently should a vehicle''s lights be checked?
option_a: At minor service intervals.
option_b: Daily before driving.
option_c: When wintertime approaches.
option_d: At major service intervals.
explanation: A driver is responsible for their vehicles roadworthiness and they should check it daily before driving. Among the checks they should make are that all the lights are clean and in working order.

question_text: When should a driver use the vehicle side lights?
option_a: When driving in foggy conditions.
option_b: When driving in an unlit area at night.
option_c: When parking on an unlit road.
option_d: When parking at all times.
explanation: When leaving a vehicle on an unlit public road at night this creates a potential danger for other road users. Drivers should therefore leave side/parking lights on, so that the vehicle can be seen by other road users. Drivers should not leave headlights on when parked as this may cause other road users to become disoriented.

question_text: What type of noise might fast cornering create?
option_a: Exhaust backfire.
option_b: Engine backfire.
option_c: Tyre squeal.
option_d: Brake squeal.
explanation: If you drive around a corner too fast, the tyres begin to lose contact with the surface of the road, and this causes a squealing sound. If you continue driving in this way, you can lose control of the vehicle.

question_text: What is the recommended method of driving a car with automatic transmission?
option_a: Use the handbrake to bring the vehicle to a halt.
option_b: Operate the accelerator and brake with the left foot.
option_c: Operate the accelerator with the right foot and the brake with the left foot.
option_d: Operate the accelerator and brake with the right foot.
explanation: When driving a car with automatic transmission, drivers should use the right foot to operate both the accelerator and the brake, just as in vehicles with a manual gear box. In general it is important to avoid using the accelerator and the brake at the same time.

question_text: What is the minimum legal tread depth for tyres on cars?
option_a: 0.6 millimetres
option_b: 2.6 millimetres
option_c: 1 millimetre
option_d: 1.6 millimetres
explanation: All road vehicles, except motorcycles and vintage vehicles, must have a minimum tyre tread depth of 1.6 mm over the main tread. However, for safety reasons, you should replace the vehicles tyres before they become this worn.

question_text: At road junctions, what type of road users are particularly vulnerable?
option_a: Tractor drivers.
option_b: Car drivers.
option_c: Pedestrians.
option_d: Van drivers.
explanation: Vehicles do not have an automatic right of way at junctions. As a driver you should pay particular attention to vulnerable road users such as pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists and be aware that they are entitled to use the road in safety.

question_text: When driving, where should a driver rest their left foot?
option_a: Under the clutch pedal.
option_b: Under the brake pedal.
option_c: On the clutch pedal.
option_d: On the floor or foot rest.
explanation: When driving a driver should rest their left foot on the floor or foot rest but not under the pedals. To do so may cause delayed response time in an emergency. Resting the foot on the pedal may result in coasting, which may inadvertently increase the speed of the vehicle, or clutch mechanism damage.

question_text: What is the effect of a worn exhaust?
option_a: Fuel efficiency is increased as the fumes escape more quickly.
option_b: The filtering of fumes is reduced and engine noise is louder.
option_c: The engine overheats.
option_d: Gear-changing is more difficult.
explanation: A worn exhaust system can have a number of effects, including increased noise from the engine and more environmentally damaging fumes (as as they are not filtered properly). There are requirements to ensure vehicles are compliant with EU and Irish legislation. Vehicles are tested for compliance during road worthiness testing.

question_text: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, which of the following should be checked after a short distance?
option_a: The tyre air valve.
option_b: The brake pad clearance.
option_c: The wheel nut tightness.
option_d: The tyre tread depth.
explanation: After changing a wheel on a vehicle, check the tightness of the wheel nuts or studs on the replacement wheel after driving a short distance to ensure they are securely fitted. If in doubt seek assistance from a competent person.

question_text: What happens if the vehicle has a flat battery?
option_a: The engine will not start.
option_b: The head light bulbs will have to be replaced.
option_c: The battery will have to be replaced.
option_d: The battery will leak acid into the engine.
explanation: All motor vehicles have a battery to supply power, primarily to start the engine. If the battery is flat, the driver will not be able to start the engine in the normal way. When the engine is running, it produces its own electricity to recharge the battery and run the various electrical components, including lights, heating, the radio and so on. If the battery is completely dead it will have to be replaced.

question_text: What does this dial provide information on?
option_a: Gearbox revolution.
option_b: Engine revolution.
option_c: Oil Level.
option_d: Fuel level.
explanation: The rev counter measures the speed of the engine, in revolutions per minute. Generally, the higher the revs, the more fuel the engine is using, so drivers should keep an eye on the rev counter to help drive in a more eco-friendly manner.

question_text: What effect can a broken lens have on headlights?
option_a: It can cause other bulbs to blow if not fixed immediately.
option_b: It can reduce and distort the beam.
option_c: It can increase the brightness of the beam in the other headlight.
option_d: It can cause the bulb to overheat.
explanation: A driver is responsible for their vehicles roadworthiness and they should check it at regular intervals. Among the checks they should make are that all the lights are in working order. If they find defects in the lights, such as a broken lens, they should have them repaired or replaced as soon as possible.

question_text: When should a driver use their vehicle's hazard warning lights?
option_a: When a following vehicle is too close.
option_b: When double parking.
option_c: When the brake lights are not working.
option_d: When causing an unavoidable obstruction.
explanation: Use the hazard warning lights to warn other road users of a danger ahead. For example, if a drivers vehicle is causing an unavoidable obstruction such as being broken down, they should use the vehicles hazard warning lights to warn other road users of their presence.

question_text: What does this light mean?
option_a: Low battery fluid level.
option_b: Low brake fluid level.
option_c: Low engine coolant level.
option_d: Low engine oil level.
explanation: If the engine oil warning light comes on, it means that the engine oil level/pressure has dropped. You should not drive the vehicle until the problem is fixed. If the light comes on while driving, pull over and stop in a safe place as soon as possible. It is important to understand the meaning of your vehicles warning lights, information on which can be found in the vehicles handbook.

question_text: What can be affected by driving on under-inflated tyres?
option_a: The coolant system.
option_b: The exhaust system.
option_c: Oil pressure.
option_d: Fuel consumption.
explanation: Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicles systems, including brakes, suspension and steering. In particular, under-inflated tyres can increase the vehicles fuel consumption. Check tyre pressures regularly and ensure they are inflated as per manufacturer''s recommendations.

question_text: What effect could hitting or mounting the kerb have on a vehicle's tyres?
option_a: It could wear the tread.
option_b: It could strengthen the sidewalls.
option_c: It could damage the sidewalls.
option_d: It could increase the air pressure.
explanation: Drivers should avoid hitting or mounting the kerb as it causes damage to the sidewalls of the tyre. The damage caused could cause the tyre to blow-out later. If this happens at high speed the driver may lose control of the vehicle with dangerous consequences.

question_text: The parking brake (hand brake) generally works on which wheels?
option_a: The rear wheels.
option_b: The rear right-hand wheel.
option_c: The front wheels.
option_d: All the wheels.
explanation: In most vehicles, the parking brake operates on the rear wheels only. The function of the parking brake (handbrake) is to stop the vehicle from moving when it is parked or when it is stopped on a hill. Drivers normally use the parking brake when the vehicle is already stationary and should generally not use it to stop the vehicle. It is even more important to use the parking brake when parked on a hill or when stationary in a vehicle with automatic transmission to prevent creep.

question_text: Who is responsible for ensuring that a passenger under 17 years of age is wearing a seat belt while travelling in a car?
option_a: The driver, but only when the passenger is in the front seat.
option_b: The passenger's parents.
option_c: The passenger only.
option_d: The driver only.
explanation: Where the passenger is over the age of 17 and travelling in a car it is their legal responsibility to comply with the seat belt regulations. Below that age, it is the drivers responsibility.

question_text: On a busy road, how should a driver allow passengers out of a vehicle?
option_a: Signal to following traffic to overtake before allowing the passengers to get out.
option_b: Stop and allow them to get out on the side nearest the kerb.
option_c: Stop and allow them to get out from whichever side of the vehicle they are sitting.
option_d: Stop and encourage them to get out as quickly as possible.
explanation: Before allowing any door to be opened, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Passengers should exit on the side nearest the kerb, without getting in the way of pedestrians.

question_text: What is a possible effect of over-filling the engine with oil?
option_a: It could burst the oil filter.
option_b: It could damage the catalytic converter.
option_c: It could reduce the oil pressure.
option_d: It could damage the oil pump.
explanation: It is essential that the vehicles engine is not over filled with oil as this can permanently damage the Catalytic converter which is part of most vehicles exhaust systems and removes up to 75% of the carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons from the vehicles exhaust. Damaging this increase exhaust emissions.

question_text: While driving, a driver notices a strong smell of fuel. What should they do?
option_a: Open the windows and continue on.
option_b: Turn on the fan to clear the air.
option_c: Stop where safe and investigate.
option_d: Drive at a reduced speed.
explanation: A strong smell of fuel is usually an indication that something is wrong, and drivers should stop and investigate as soon as possible. Leaking or spilling petrol can be dangerous because it is so combustible, and leaking diesel fuel can make the road very slippery.

question_text: What is the purpose of a catalytic converter?
option_a: To curb exhaust noise levels only on diesel-powered vehicles.
option_b: To curb exhaust noise levels only on petrol-powered vehicles.
option_c: To allow the exhaust system to be reconditioned.
option_d: To reduce harmful exhaust emissions.
explanation: Catalytic converters are part of a vehicles exhaust system. They help to protect the environment by removing up to 75% of the carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons from the vehicles exhaust.

question_text: What should the driver be able to see in the exterior mirrors of a vehicle when they are properly adjusted?
option_a: The back of the vehicle only.
option_b: 60% angled to the vehicle and 40% to the road.
option_c: The sides of the vehicle only.
option_d: The area to each side of the vehicle.
explanation: Exterior mirrors enable drivers to see the area on each side of the vehicle. Drivers must take into account all visible hazards in order to make informed, correct and safer decisions.

question_text: What should be considered when reversing out of a parking space?
option_a: Avoid switching on your rear wiper.
option_b: Check behind using interior rear view mirror only.
option_c: Always reverse quickly to get out of space.
option_d: Check for pedestrians and vehicles all around.
explanation: Some car parks are designed for you to park forwards to make it easier to load shopping. In these cases take extra care as you reverse out of the parking space because pedestrians and vehicles may pass behind you.

question_text: What lighting must be on a two-axle car-trailer?
option_a: Flashing rear tail lights.
option_b: Indicators, brake lights, rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.
option_c: Brake lights and indicators only.
option_d: Indicators and rear number plate lights only.
explanation: All vehicles, including trailers, must have rear indicators, brake lights, a rear number plate light, red reflectors and rear tail lights.

question_text: What safety precaution should a driver take when getting out of their vehicle?
option_a: Check all around for approaching traffic and pedestrians before opening the door.
option_b: Ensure all valuables are secured and out of sight.
option_c: Ensure the gear lever is in neutral.
option_d: Open the door and try to get out as speedily as possible.
explanation: Before opening any door, check for other road users passing, and in particular look out for pedestrians, cyclists and motorcyclists. Exit the vehicle only when it is safe to do so, and close the door as soon as possible. Passengers should exit on the side nearest the kerb wherever possible.

question_text: What effect does low tyre-pressure have on a vehicle?
option_a: The brakes can overheat.
option_b: The vehicle accelerates faster.
option_c: The engine noise increases.
option_d: Braking and cornering are impaired.
explanation: Incorrect tyre pressure adversely affects many of a vehicles systems, including suspension, steering and fuel consumption. In particular, under-inflated tyres can affect the vehicles braking ability and its effectiveness when cornering. Tyres should always be inflated according to the vehicle manufacturers guidelines, information on which can be found in the vehicle handbook.

question_text: A fault in which component may lead to uneven or excessive tyre wear?
option_a: Suspension.
option_b: Clutch.
option_c: Accelerator.
option_d: Gearbox.
explanation: If a vehicle has a worn suspension it may lead to uneven or excessive tyre wear. If drivers notice that their tyres are unevenly worn, they should investigate the reason and have it repaired by a competent person.

question_text: What could a driver do in order to avoid excessive exhaust pollution from their vehicle?
option_a: Have the vehicle's air filters changed regularly.
option_b: Drive at a higher speed in order to reduce the time spent on the road.
option_c: Drive a diesel powered vehicle.
option_d: Use a fuel additive to increase the fuel octane rating.
explanation: Drivers should have their vehicle serviced regularly in accordance with the manufacturers guidelines. A vehicle with a dirty air filter uses more fuel and creates more exhaust pollution. Air filters should be changed as part of normal servicing. If a vehicle is used in dusty conditions, the air filter may need to be changed more often. More information is available in the vehicle owners handbook.

question_text: If, when driving along, the driver notices that the engine power is lower than normal, what should they do?
option_a: Adjust the fuel mixture control mechanism.
option_b: Switch to a different fuel.
option_c: Have the vehicle checked by a competent person.
option_d: Replace the engine oil filter.
explanation: If the driver notices that the vehicle seems underpowered when driving, this could present a number of problems, e.g. lack of power when overtaking. The driver should have it checked by a competent person as soon as possible as there may be a number of causes, some of which may deteriorate further.

question_text: When must a tractor or works vehicle be fitted with a rear-view mirror?
option_a: A rear-view mirror must be fitted only when towing a trailer.
option_b: A rear-view mirror must be fitted only when towing a trailer over 8 metres long.
option_c: A rear-view mirror must always be fitted.
option_d: A rear-view mirror is not required in a tractor or works vehicle.
explanation: All vehicles used on a public road must have a rear-view mirror. The mirror should be used to enable the driver to see the traffic and road conditions behind and to each side.

question_text: Where safety belts are fitted to a car when must adult occupants wear them?
option_a: Only on journeys exceeding 10 kilometres.
option_b: Only on journeys outside built-up areas.
option_c: Only on long journeys.
option_d: At all times.
explanation: The driver and all passengers in a car must wear a safety belt or, in the case of a child, a suitable restraint system.

question_text: When a driver is making a left-hand turn, what mirrors should they particularly concentrate on?
option_a: The interior and right exterior mirror.
option_b: The interior and left exterior mirror.
option_c: The right exterior mirror.
option_d: The interior mirror.
explanation: When turning left, drivers should in particular be aware that cyclists and other vehicles may come up on their near side (left hand side). For that reason, when checking mirrors, it is particularly important to check both the left exterior and the interior mirror before turning. Drivers must always use the mirrors-signal-mirror-manouevre routine when turning. They should be particularly careful if crossing the path of a bus and/or cycle lane.

question_text: If a vehicle is driven with low oil pressure, what effect does this have on its engine?
option_a: It increases fuel consumption.
option_b: It increases fuel efficiency.
option_c: It increases wear and tear on the engine.
option_d: It increases exhaust emissions.
explanation: Low oil pressure is usually related to low oil level or to a faulty oil pump. Low engine oil level should be topped up in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. Failure to do so may result in costly and extensive engine damage.

question_text: How should a driver secure their vehicle before getting out of it?
option_a: Angle the wheels towards the kerb and stop the engine.
option_b: Engage a low gear and stop the engine.
option_c: Apply the parking brake, stop the engine and engage a low gear.
option_d: Angle the wheels away from the kerb and stop the engine.
explanation: Before leaving your vehicle, apply the handbrake, switch off the engine and engage a low gear. If the vehicle is fitted with automatic transmission, select P (park).

question_text: Is a driver allowed to use rebated (green) diesel fuel in a car on a public road?
option_a: Green diesel may never be used in a car
option_b: Green diesel may be used in a car only if the car is a taxis.
option_c: Green diesel may be used in a car only in summer months.
option_d: Green diesel may be used in a car only in winter months.
explanation: If, in its normal use, a vehicle is used on a public road, it must use unmarked (white) diesel, as the appropriate excise duties are included in the purchase price. Drivers can be prosecuted for using green diesel in a vehicle on a public road.

question_text: Why is it important to ensure that the vehicle headlights are correctly aligned?
option_a: To enable the driver to see properly.
option_b: To increase the lifespan of the headlights.
option_c: To enable the driver to drive faster in the dark.
option_d: To reduce battery consumption.
explanation: A driver should ensure their headlights are properly aligned so as not to dazzle oncoming drivers and also to see properly themselves.

question_text: A driver notices that the wiper blades are worn. What should they do?
option_a: Have the blades replaced as soon as possible.
option_b: Wipe the windscreen with newspaper.
option_c: Use the windscreen washer system while it is raining.
option_d: Roll down the window and drive slowly.
explanation: Use the windscreen wipers to keep the windscreen clear of rain, spray, snow or fog. Check them regularly to ensure that they are in good working order, and replace them when they become worn, before they become ineffective.

question_text: What advice should a driver give to passengers before opening doors?
option_a: Check all around and open door with caution.
option_b: Make sure that you have proper clothing protection on.
option_c: Remove seat belt and exit vehicle immediately.
option_d: Leave windows slightly open to allow circulation of air.
explanation: Before opening any doors, check for other road users nearby, in particular motorcyclists and pedestrians

question_text: What should a driver do if they notice steam rising from the engine compartment?
option_a: Top up with anti-freeze immediately.
option_b: Stop where safe and investigate the cause.
option_c: Increase speed to increase the air flow into the engine compartment.
option_d: Remove the filler cap from the coolant bottle.
explanation: If a driver notices steam rising from the engine compartment of their vehicle, they should stop where safe and only investigate the cause once it has cooled down. Do not remove a radiator or header tank cap when the engine is hot. Steam rising from the engine is an indication that the engine is overheating and it should not continue to be driven. Refer to the vehicle handbook for further information and guidance or seek advice from a competent person.

question_text: With regard to tyres, what should a driver do before starting a long journey?
option_a: Reduce the air pressure in the tyres.
